ARTICLE II. - CITY COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Code of ethics for public officers and employees, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; public meetings, F.S. § 286.011; public records, F.S. § 119.01 et seq.; procedure for adoption of ordinances, F.S. § 166.041. 
 
Sec. 2.01. - City employees as candidates for city offices to take leave of absence. 
Any person holding any position, whether voluntary or for compensation, in the municipal government where such position is under the direct or indirect jurisdiction of the city manager, shall, at the time of filing qualifying statement as a candidate for election to the office of mayor-commissioner or commissioners, take a leave of absence from the position which is under the direct or indirect jurisdiction of the city manager. The leave of absence to be in effect until such time as the candidate's status as mayor-commissioner or commissioner shall have been determined by the certification of the voting at the election. 
(Code 1970, § 2-2)  
Sec. 2.02. - Meetings. 
(a)  The city commission shall meet in regular session at 7:00 p.m. on the first and third Mondays of each and every month. 
(b)  All meetings of the commission shall be held at the city hall; provided that meetings may be held at other times or places in the city when deemed proper or feasible by the commission. 
(Code 1970, § 2-3; Ord. No. 2017-19, § 2, 6-8-2017) 
State Law reference— All meetings … at which official acts are to be taken, are declared to be public meetings open to the public at all times, F.S. § 286.011.  
ARTICLE III. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Code of ethics for public officers and employees, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; public meetings, F.S. § 286.011; public records, F.S. § 119.01 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 2. - ADVISORY BOARDS AND COMMITTEES 
 
Sec. 2.03. - Applicability. 
(a)  The provisions of this division shall apply to all advisory boards or committees created by the city commission, with the exception of the personnel review board and the fire pension board, unless specifically exempted by this Code or an ordinance or resolution adopted by the city commission, and except as otherwise provided for by state statute. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a), the code of conduct contained in section 2.09 of this division shall apply to the personnel review board in addition to all other advisory boards and committees created by the city commission governed by this division. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 2.04. - Residency requirement. 
All advisory board or committee members governed by this division must be a resident of the city at the time of their appointment, and shall remain a resident for the entire appointed term. If at any time an advisory board or committee member is no longer a resident of the city, a vacancy shall be created and may be filled in the manner provided for the filling of vacancies on said advisory board or committee. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 2.05. - Term limits. 
(a)  Except as provided in this section, no person shall be eligible to hold a position on an advisory board or committee governed by this division for more than three (3) consecutive full terms. Thereafter, no such person may be reappointed to the same advisory board or committee for a period of one (1) year from the date of the expiration of their third consecutive term. 
(b)  In the event there are no qualified applications timely filed to fill the position of the term-limited member, the city commission may reappoint the term-limited member. 
(c)  The term limits set forth in subsection (a) above shall apply only to appointments made after June 1, 2015. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 2.06. - Attendance. 
All advisory board or committee members governed by this division shall regularly attend all meetings of their respective board or committee. Board members who miss three (3) meetings within any twelve (12) month period shall automatically forfeit such appointment and the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with the procedure applicable to the board or committee. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 2.07. - Removal. 
Each advisory board or committee member of a board or committee governed by this division is appointed and shall serve at the pleasure of the city commission. The city commission may remove any advisory board or committee member at any time without cause. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 2.08. - Compensation. 
All advisory board or committee members shall serve as volunteers without compensation of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 2.09. - Code of conduct. 
The following code of conduct is hereby adopted for all advisory boards or committees governed by this division: 
(1)  No member of an advisory board or committee shall represent themselves, a client or his/her employer, or act on behalf of an organization of which they are an officer, board member, or director, to advocate for, on behalf of, or in opposition to any matter before the board or committee. 
(2)  No member of an advisory board or committee shall make any representations, either implicitly or overtly, to any citizen, outside of a properly noticed meeting of the member's respective board or committee, regarding what action their respective board may or may not take in the future. No member shall make any promises to any individual that their respective board will take any action on a given subject. 
(3)  No member of an advisory board or committee shall represent to the public that the member has the authority to act individually or independently on behalf of an advisory board or committee or the city, unless such authority has been specifically granted to the member. 
(4)  No member of an advisory board or committee shall represent themselves as a member of an advisory board or committee in a threatening, antagonistic, or otherwise hostile manner towards the public. No member shall represent to the public that they have any powers beyond those specifically granted to the member by virtue of their appointment to an advisory board or committee. 
(5)  All members of boards or committees which sit in a quasi-judicial capacity and have final decision making authority, including but not limited to the code enforcement board and board of appeals, shall remain impartial on matters which may come before their board or committee and avoid the appearance of impropriety on all matters which come before their board or committee. Members shall avoid creating the appearance of impropriety by refraining from engaging in public and private discussions about specific agenda items, specific applicants or parties to a proceeding before their board or committee, or items which may come before their board or committee. Members should further refrain from participating in any proceeding in which their impartiality may be reasonably questioned. A member whose personal, employment, or business relationship with a person or entity that is the subject of a matter which may come before the board or committee should disclose such relationship to the city commission. The provisions of F.S. ch. 112, the code of ethics for public officers and employees, shall govern conflict of interest situations and determinations. 
(6)  Nothing contained in this section 2.09 shall be construed to alter the provisions of section 2.07, to change that all members of every board or committee serve at the pleasure of the city commission, or to require that the city commission find a violation of this code of conduct to remove any member of any board or committee at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2015-11, § 1, 5-18-2015; Ord. No. 2017-09, § 2, 2-20-2017)  
Sec. 2.10. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1987, enacted provisions creating the Safety Harbor Municipal Code Enforcement Board to be included as a new Ch. 27. For purposes of facilitating reference and indexing and keeping related Code provisions together, such provisions have been codified as Art. III, Div. 3, §§ 2.10.01—2.10.11 of this chapter at the discretion of the editor. 
Charter reference— Jurisdiction of city, Art. I, § 11; general powers of city, Art. I, § 12; powers of city commission, Art. II, § 15; establishment of boards, Art. VI, § 105. 
Cross reference— Building code, § 5.01; electrical code, § 5.07; plumbing code, § 5.11; housing code, § 5.14; unsafe building code, § 5.15; fire codes, § 8.01; local business tax receipts, Ch. 14; sign regulations, Ch. 19; streets, sidewalks, etc., Ch. 20; subdivisions, Ch. 21; zoning, Ch. 26. 
 
Sec. 2.10.01. - Creation, membership. 
(a)  There is hereby created within the city the city code enforcement board, which shall be composed of seven (7) regular members and one (1) alternate member, all of whom shall be residents of the city. 
(b)  The alternate member of the board shall serve a three-year term. If there is one (1) regular board member absent from a code enforcement board meeting, the alternate will sit as a voting member. If there are no regular board members absent at a meeting, the alternate member will sit as a nonvoting member, but will be allowed to participate in the discussion of the board. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87; Ord. No. 93-18, § 1, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 96-07, § 1, 2-19-96)  
Sec. 2.10.02. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
City commission: The legislative body of the City of Safety Harbor, Florida. 
Code inspector or enforcement officer: Any authorized agent or employee of the city, whose duty is to ensure code compliance with the city's codes and ordinances including but not limited to the City Code, land development code, and other technical codes, including but not limited to fire and building codes, which are subject to this division, or any law enforcement officer or other individual authorized by Florida law to enforce the city's codes and ordinances. 
Enforcement board: The City of Safety Harbor code enforcement board created pursuant hereto. 
Repeat violation: A violation of a provision of a code or ordinance by a person whom the enforcement board has previously found to have violated the same provision within five (5) years prior to the violation. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87; Ord. No. 91-04, § 1, 2-4-91; Ord. No. 2017-36, § 1, 11-20-2017)  
Sec. 2.10.03. - Functions, appointment, term of office. 
(a)  The code enforcement board shall have the purpose of conducting hearings relating to the enforcement of the business tax receipts, fire, building, zoning, sign, subdivision, regulations, Land Development Code regulations, the City Code, and other related technical codes presently in force in the city; to issue findings of fact and to issue orders affording the proper relief consistent with the powers granted by this division and in accordance with Chapter 162, Florida Statutes (1994), as amended from time to time. 
(b)  Appointment to the code enforcement board shall be made by the city commission, in the sole discretion of the city commission, and appointment of a majority of the membership shall be made on the basis of experience or interest in the fields of zoning, building, and development control. Whenever possible, the board shall include an architect, a businessperson, an engineer, a general contractor, a subcontractor and a real estate agent. 
(c)  The initial terms of members of the board shall me as follows: 
(1)  Two (2) members shall be appointed for a term of one (1) year; 
(2)  Three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years; and 
(3)  Two (2) members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. 
(d)  Thereafter, appointment shall be for a term of three (3) years. Members may be reappointed upon the concurrence of the city commission. Appointment to fill any vacancy on the board shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term of office. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87; Ord. No. 94-29, § 1, 10-3-94; Ord. No. 95-07, § 1, 2-20-95; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 1, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 2015-14, § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 2.10.04. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-14, § 2, adopted May 18, 2015, repealed § 2.10.04, which pertained to attendance; removal from office and derived from Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1987; and Ord. No. 95-07, § 2, adopted Feb. 20, 1995.  
Sec. 2.10.05. - Organization and expenses. 
(a)  At the first meeting of the board, the members may elect one (1) of the members to be chairman. The person so elected shall function as chairman for a one-year term. 
(b)  Four (4) or more members of the board present at any meeting shall constitute a quorum in order for the board to conduct its business. Members of the board shall serve without compensation but may be entitled to be reimbursed for such mileage expenses as the city commission shall authorize by ordinance. 
(c)  The city attorney shall act as counsel for the city, and either he or his assistant shall be present at all meetings of the board. The city manager may obtain independent counsel to advise the board. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87; Ord. No. 94-29, § 1, 10-3-94)  
Sec. 2.10.06. - Enforcement procedure. 
Except where the inspector charged with enforcing a particular technical code identified herein has reason to believe that a code violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety and welfare, the code enforcement procedure under this division shall be as follows: 
(1)  It shall be the duty of the code inspector to initiate enforcement proceedings with respect to each technical code. 
(2)  Where a code inspector finds or is made aware of a code violation, the code inspector shall notify the violator, and such notice of violation shall provide a time within which to correct the violation. Should the violation continue beyond the time specified in the correction notice, then the code inspector shall notify the code enforcement board and request a hearing pursuant to sections 2.10.07 and 2.10.08 of this division. Notice of such hearing request shall be provided to the violator in the manner provided by section 2.10.11 of the Safety Harbor Code of Ordinances. 
(3)  If the code inspector has reason to believe a violation or condition causing a violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety and welfare, the code inspector shall make a reasonable effort to notify the violator and may immediately notify the board and request a hearing. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87; Ord. No. 90-17, § 1, 8-6-90; Ord. No. 94-29, § 1, 10-3-94)  
Sec. 2.10.07. - Hearing procedures. 
(a)  The chairman of the code enforcement board may call enforcement board hearings, and such hearings may also be called by a written notice signed by three (3) members of the board. The code enforcement board may at any hearing set a future hearing date. 
(b)  The board shall attempt to convene at least once every month, but may convene more often as the case demand dictates. 
(c)  Minutes shall be kept of all hearings held by the enforcement board, and all such hearings shall be open to the public. 
(d)  The city commission shall provide clerical and administrative personnel as may be required to assist the board in the proper performance of its duties. 
(e)  Each case before the enforcement board shall be presented by a member of the city staff. If the city prevails in prosecuting a case before the board, it shall be entitled to recover all costs incurred in prosecuting the case before the board. 
(f)  Cases scheduled for a particular day shall be heard. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. The board shall take testimony from the code inspector, the violator and any other person familiar with the case or having knowledge about the case. The board shall not be bound by formal rules of evidence; however, it shall act to ensure fundamental due process in each of its hearing cases. 
(g)  At the conclusion of each hearing, the enforcement board shall issue findings of fact based on evidence of record and conclusions of law, and it shall issue an order providing relief consistent with this division. Each finding and order shall be by motion approved by a majority of those present and voting, except that at least four (4) members of the board must vote in order for the action to be official. 
The order may include a notice that it must be complied with by a specified date and that a fine may be imposed and, under the conditions specified in subsection 2.10.09(a), the costs of repairs may be included along with the fine if the order is not complied with by such date. A certified copy of such order may be recorded in the public records of the county and shall constitute notice to any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest or assigns if the violation concerns real property, and the findings therein shall be binding upon the violator and, if the violation concerns real property, any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest or assigns. If an order is recorded in the public records pursuant to this subsection and the order is complied with by the date specified in the order, the enforcement board shall issue an order acknowledging compliance that shall be recorded in the public records. A hearing is not required to issue such an order acknowledging compliance. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87; Ord. No. 91-04, § 2, 2-4-91; Ord. No. 94-29, § 1, 10-3-94)  
Sec. 2.10.08. - Powers of the code enforcement board. 
The Safety Harbor code enforcement board shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings; 
(2)  Subpoena alleged violators and witnesses to its hearings. Such subpoenas shall be served by the sheriff's department; 
(3)  Subpoena evidence; 
(4)  Take testimony under oath; 
(5)  Issue orders which shall have the force of law and which shall set forth the steps necessary to be accomplished in order to bring a violation into compliance with the code that has been violated. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87)  
Sec. 2.10.09. - Fines, costs of repair, liens and foreclosure. 
(a)  Upon being notified by the code inspector that a previous order of the code enforcement board is not being complied with within the time established in such order, or upon finding that the same violation has been repeated by the same violator, the code enforcement board may order the violator to pay a fine to the city not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day that the violation continues past the date set for compliance for a first violation, and not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for each day the repeat violation continues, beginning with the date the repeat violation is found to have occurred by the code inspector. In addition, if the violation is a violation described in subsection 2.10.06(3), the board shall notify the city, which may make all reasonable repairs which are required to being the property into compliance and charge the violator with the reasonable costs of the repairs along with the fine imposed pursuant to this section. Any fine imposed pursuant to this section may include all such costs of repairs. 
(b)  A certified copy of an order imposing a fine may be recorded in the public records of Pinellas County, Florida, and thereafter, such order shall constitute a lien against the land on which the violation exists or, if the violator does not own the land, upon any other real or personal property owned by the violator. 
(c)  The lien may be enforced in the same manner as a court judgment by the sheriff, including levy against the personal property, but shall not be deemed to be a court judgment except for enforcement purposes. 
(d)  After three (3) months from the filing of any such lien which remains unpaid, the enforcement board may authorize the city attorney to foreclose on such lien in the manner provided by statute for the foreclosure of other municipal liens, except that the lien may not be foreclosed on real property which is homestead under Section 4, Article I of the Florida Constitution. 
(e)  A fine imposed pursuant to this division shall continue to accrue until the violator comes into compliance or until judgment is rendered in a suit to foreclose on a lien filed pursuant to this section, whichever occurs first. 
(f)  A lien arising from a fine imposed pursuant to this section runs in favor of the city and the city may execute a satisfaction or release of lien entered pursuant to this section. 
(g)  Any lien or fine imposed pursuant to this section may only be reduced or waived by the city commission. The city commission may adopt by resolution a procedure and establish criteria for considering applications for reduction of code enforcement. 
(h)  The prevailing party in any action to foreclose a lien imposed pursuant to this section shall be entitled to recover all costs, including reasonable attorney's fees, incurred in the foreclosure action. 
(i)  The city shall be entitled to collect all costs incurred in recording and satisfying a valid lien. 
(j)  No lien provided under this division shall continue for a period longer than twenty (20) years after the certified copy of an order imposing a fine has been recorded, unless within that time an action to foreclose on a lien is commenced in a court of competent jurisdiction. The continuation of the lien effected by the commencement of a foreclosure action shall not be good against creditors or subsequent purchasers for valuable consideration without notice, unless a notice of lis pendens is recorded. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87; Ord. No. 90-17, §§ 2—4, 8-6-90; Ord. No. 91-04, § 3, 2-4-91; Ord. No. § 1, 10-3-94; Ord. No. 2010-18, § 1, 2-7-2011)  
Sec. 2.10.10. - Appeal. 
Any aggrieved party may appeal a ruling or order of the Safety Harbor code enforcement board by certiorari to the circuit court of Pinellas County, in accordance with Florida Statute 162.11 (1986). The appeal provided for herein shall be filed within thirty (30) days of the execution of the order to be appealed. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87)  
Sec. 2.10.11. - Notices. 
All notices to be provided by this division shall be by certified mail, return receipt requested, or when mail would not be effective, by hand delivery by the code inspector or by leaving the notice at the violator's usual place of residence with any person residing therein who is above fifteen (15) years of age and informing such person of the contents of the notice, or as otherwise provided for in accordance with Florida Statute 162.12, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 87-46, § 1, 12-7-87; Ord. No. 90-17, § 5, 8-6-90; Ord. No. 91-04, § 4, 2-4-91)  
Sec. 2.10.12. - Supplemental code enforcement procedures, civil citations. 
(a)  Supplemental authority. The provisions of this section are supplemental means of obtaining compliance with the city's codes and ordinances. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prohibit the city from enforcing its codes by any other means. 
(b)  Authorization. Pursuant to F.S. § 162.21, as may be amended from time to time, city code inspectors are authorized to issue a citation to a person when, based upon personal investigation, the code inspector has reasonable cause to believe that the person has committed a civil infraction in violation of a duly enacted code or ordinance. The county court will hear such charge(s). Each violation of the city's codes or ordinances shall be a separate civil infraction, and each day the violation continues to exist shall constitute a separate violation. 
(c)  Notice. Prior to issuing a citation, the code inspector shall provide notice to the person in that the person has committed a violation of a code or ordinance and shall establish a reasonable time period within which the person must correct the violation. Such time period shall be no more than 30 days, or as otherwise provided in F.S. § 162.21. If, upon personal investigation, a code inspector finds that the person has not corrected the violation within the time period, a code inspector may issue a citation to the person who has committed the violation. A code inspector does not have to provide the person with a reasonable time period to correct the violation prior to issuing a citation and may immediately issue a citation if a repeat violation is found or if the code inspector has reason to believe that the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety, or welfare, or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible. 
(d)  Form of citation. A citation issued by a code inspector shall be in a form prescribed by the city and shall contain: 
(1)  The date and time of issuance; 
(2)  The name and address of the person to whom the citation is issued; 
(3)  The date and time the civil infraction was committed; 
(4)  The facts constituting reasonable cause for the violation; 
(5)  The number or section of the code or ordinance violated; 
(6)  The name and authority of the code inspector; 
(7)  The procedure for the person to follow in order to pay the civil penalty or to contest the citation; 
(8)  The applicable civil penalty if the person elects to contest the citation; 
(9)  The applicable civil penalty if the person elects not to contest the citation; and 
(10)  A conspicuous statement that if the person fails to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed, or fails to appear in court to contest the citation, the person shall be deemed to have waived his or her right to contest the citation and that, in such case, judgment may be entered against the person for an amount up to the maximum civil penalty. 
(e)  Deposit of citation with county court. After issuing a citation to an alleged violator, a code inspector shall deposit the original citation and one copy of the citation with the county court. The alleged violator may contest the citation in county court. 
(f)  Civil infractions. A violation of the city's codes or ordinances is a civil infraction, subject to the maximum civil penalty of $500.00. If the person who has committed the civil infraction does not contest the citation, a civil penalty of less than the maximum civil penalty may be imposed pursuant to subsection (i) below. 
(g)  Refusal to sign and accept citation a misdemeanor. Any person who willfully refuses to sign and accept a citation issued by a code inspector shall be guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree, punishable as provided in F.S. § 775.082 and 775.083. 
(h)  Non-applicability of article provisions in certain instances. The provisions of this article shall not apply to the enforcement pursuant to F.S. § 553.79 and 553.80 of the Florida Building Code adopted pursuant to F.S. § 553.73, as applied to construction, provided that a building permit is either not required or has been issued by the city. 
(i)  No contest of citation; schedule of civil penalties. A person who receives a citation from a code inspector for the violation of this Code or a city ordinance and who elects not to contest the citation shall be subject to a civil penalty in accordance with the schedule of fines and penalties established by the Sixth Judicial Circuit Court Administrative Order No. 2012-028 PA-CTY, as may be amended from time to time. 
(j)  Waiver of right to contest citation. Any person who fails to pay the appropriate civil penalty within the time allowed, or who fails to appear in county court to contest the citation, shall be deemed to have waived his/her right to contest the citation, and judgment may be entered against the person for an amount not to exceed the maximum civil penalty of $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 2017-36, § 2, 11-20-2017)  
DIVISION 4. - RESERVED[5] 

Footnotes:

ARTICLE V. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference— Charter officers, Art. III. 
State Law reference— Code of ethics for public officers and employees, F.S. § 112.311 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2.10.20. - Defense, indemnification of mayor-commissioner, commissioners, officers and employees; scope of coverage. 
(a)  The city shall defend any civil action brought against the mayor-commissioner, any commissioner, officers or employees of the city for acts or omissions arising out of and in the scope of their employment or function, unless, in the case of a tort action, such mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee acted outside the course and scope of his employment, in bad faith, with malicious purpose or in a manner exhibiting wanton and wilful disregard of human rights, safety or property. Defense of such civil actions shall include, but not be limited to, any civil rights lawsuits seeking relief personally against such mayor-commissioner, any commissioner, officers or employees for acts or omissions under color of state law, custom or usage wherein it is alleged that such mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee has deprived another person of rights secured under the Federal Constitution or laws, unless such mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee acted in bad faith, with malicious purpose, outside the course and scope of his or her employment or in a manner exhibiting wanton and wilful disregard of human rights, safety or property. 
(b)  In an action for which the city shall provide a defense under paragraph (a), the city will do or cause to be done the following: 
(1)  Defend such person in the lawsuit by the city attorney, by an attorney selected by the city commission or by the city's insurer for this purpose; obtain and present such available evidence as would be necessary or proper and reasonably procurable under the circumstances for the proper defense of such person in such action; and pay the necessary court costs in and incident to such lawsuit. 
(2)  Pay or settle any judgment or damages against such person obtained as the proximate result of such lawsuit. 
(3)  Reimburse such person for any personal expense he has reasonably and necessarily sustained in such litigation and judgment. 
(4)  Do whatever else is necessary or proper, in the sole discretion of the city commission, to protect the mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee under the facts and circumstances of the particular case. 
(c)  This protection and reimbursement shall cover only situations where the mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee of the city has been determined to have been acting or failing to act as the mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee of the city within the scope of duties or responsibilities of his or her particular office or employment and as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 90-33, § 1, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 95-13, § 1, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.10.21. - Conditions of coverage. 
The duty to defend or indemnify and save harmless as prescribed by section 2.10.20 shall be conditioned upon: 
(1)  The mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee providing his or her full cooperation to the city in the defense of any action and in the prosecution of any appeal. This shall include, but not be limited to, providing a statement and all evidence to the city's attorney promptly upon request. 
(2)  The mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee shall not give any statements or otherwise give evidence against his or the city's interest to anyone, other than the city or its representative without the city's consent. 
(3)  The mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee shall tender to the city attorney the complaint, summons, process or other pleading within five (5) days after the mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee is served with such documents. 
(4)  The city shall, in its sole discretion, select the counsel for such mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee, who shall be the city attorney unless a conflict of interest exists, or an attorney selected by the city's insurer. 
(5)  The city shall have full right to compromise all claims, and the city retains the right to settle any claim against any mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee, for which the city will defend or indemnify the mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employer under section 2.10.20, without the mayor-commissioner's, commissioner's, officer's or employee's consent. 
(6)  In the event of damages arising from a counterclaim against any aggrieved party, the city shall be entitled to all damages from such party. 
(7)  All funds received by any affected mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee from a collateral source shall be deducted from any amount which the city shall become obligated to indemnify such mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee. Such mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee shall subrogate all rights to the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-33, § 2, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 95-13, § 2, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.10.22. - Exclusions from coverage. 
There shall be no coverage, indemnification or reimbursement under section 2.10.20: 
(1)  If the mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee of the city has been guilty of intentional misconduct or of intentional omission of duty or where it is determined that he or she acted in bad faith, with malicious or in a manner exhibiting wanton and wilful disregard of human or civil rights, safety or property. This shall include, but not be limited to, actions for fund, libel and slander. 
(2)  For criminal charges where there is a finding of guilty. 
(3)  For any act or omission that was taken outside the scope of employment or duties of the office of the mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee. 
(4)  The city shall not in any way become liable to the plaintiff or any other aggrieved party. 
(5)  For punitive or exemplary damage awards. 
(Ord. No. 90-33, § 3, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 2.10.23. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to all actions and proceedings pending upon or instituted after the effective date of these provisions. As used herein, an action shall be construed to be pending where the action has not been tried or, if tried, where the judgment has not become final by reason of the completion of any appellate proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 90-33, § 4, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 2.10.24. - Reservation of rights and immunities. 
(a)  The city may undertake the defense of its mayor commissioner, any commissioner, officer or employee, as indicated in this article, but reserves its right to seek indemnification and/or recovery for any judgment or settlement paid, all court costs incurred and all attorney's fees incurred in the defense of the mayor-commissioner, any commissioner, officer or employee from such mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee [where it is determined that such] acted or failed to act because of fraud, corruption or malice; where it is determined that such mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee acted in bad faith, with malicious purpose or in a manner exhibiting wanton and wilful disregard of human or civil rights, safety or property; where it is determined that the mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee was not entitled to protection under this article or state law or where such mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee fails [failed] to cooperate in good faith in the defense of the claim, as described in section 2.10.21. Nothing contained herein shall require the city to provide a defense under this article under a reservation of rights. The city may elect not to provide a defense if at any time it determines that the mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee is not entitled to protection under this article or state law. 
(b)  The provisions of this article shall not be construed to impair, alter, limit or modify the rights and obligations of any insurer or insured under any policy of insurance. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be construed as a waiver by the city or any mayor-commissioner, commissioner, officer or employee of any claim of immunity including sovereign immunity, applicable to any action. 
(Ord. No. 90-33, § 5, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 95-13, § 3, 4-3-95)  
ARTICLE VI. - PERSONNEL[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Charter reference— Civil service, § 12(45). 
State Law reference— Civil service system, Art. III, § 14, State Constitution; merit or civil service system; applicability, F.S. § 447.601. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2.11. - Personnel policy declared. 
It is hereby the declared personnel policy of the city that: 
(1)  Employment in the city government shall be based on merit and fitness, free of personal and political considerations. 
(2)  Just and equitable incentives and conditions of employment shall be established and maintained to promote efficiency and economy in the operation of the city government. 
(3)  The employees of the city shall be productive employees who perform a useful city purpose. 
(4)  Tenure of employees covered by this article shall be subject to good behavior, the satisfactory performance of work, necessity for the performance of work, and the availability of funds. 
(5)  High morale shall be maintained by fair administration of this article, and by every consideration of the rights and interest of the public and the city. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-2)  
Sec. 2.12. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the below listed terms shall have the meanings as shown unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
Appointing authority shall mean the city manager who, by Charter, is authorized to appoint, assign, or remove employees over which he has jurisdiction, subject to the provisions of this article and the personnel rules. 
Board shall mean the personnel review board as provided for herein. 
City service shall mean all persons employed by and under the jurisdiction of the commission as members of the classified service or members of the exempt service. 
Classified service shall mean the persons employed by the city who are subject to the coverage and regulations of this article and to the personnel rules provided for herein. 
Exempt service shall mean the persons employed by the city who are not subject to the coverage and regulations of this article, nor to the personnel rules provided for herein. 
Personnel shall mean a personnel program based upon merit principles which attempts to provide an objective and impartial career and public service system. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-3; Ord. No. 95-14, § 2, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.13. - Personnel department established. 
There is hereby established a personnel department and a personnel director in charge thereof. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-4)  
Sec. 2.14. - Appointment, qualifications and duties of director. 
(a)  The personnel program established by this article shall be administered by the personnel director who shall be appointed by, and serve at the will of, the city manager. 
(b)  The personnel director shall be experienced in the field of personnel administration, and knowledgeable of the application of merit principles in public employment. With the consent of the commission, the city manager may serve as personnel director. 
(c)  The personnel director shall: 
(1)  Apply and carry out the personnel rules as adopted; 
(2)  Foster and develop, in cooperation with the city manager, heads of the various departments, elected officials, and other interested parties, programs for the improvement of employee effectiveness and morale; 
(3)  Encourage and exercise leadership in the development of effective personnel administration within the several departments of the city and to make available the facilities of the personnel department for this purpose: 
(4)  Establish and maintain a roster of all classified service employees which shall set forth, as to each employee, the class title, rate of pay, status, and related data; 
(5)  Prepare and recommend revisions and amendments to the personnel rules: 
(6)  Attend all meetings of the personnel review board and may serve as its executive secretary; 
(7)  Perform any other lawful acts necessary or desirable to carry out the purpose and provisions of this article and the personnel rules. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-5; Ord. No. 95-14, §§ 3—6, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.15. - Classified and exempt service. 
All offices and positions of the city are divided into the classified service and the exempt service. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-6)  
Sec. 2.16. - Exempt service. 
The exempt service shall include the following: 
(1)  All elected officials and members of boards and commissions appointed by the commission; 
(2)  Department heads and assistant department heads appointed by the commission or city manager; 
(3)  Volunteer and temporary personnel; 
(4)  Consultants and counsel rendering temporary professional service, or persons employed under limited term contractual agreements to perform specialist or technical services for the city; 
(5)  Such other additional positions as the commission may include because of the professional, unique, specialized nature of the position. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-7)  
Sec. 2.17. - Classified service. 
The classified service shall include all other positions in the city service that are not specifically placed in the exempt service by this article. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-8)  
Sec. 2.18. - Probationary period. 
All employees occupying positions in the classified service for six (6) consecutive months or more immediately prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article was derived shall be deemed to have satisfactorily completed their probationary period of service and shall automatically be considered permanent status employees. Those employees who have occupied their positions in the classified service for less than six (6) consecutive months immediately prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article was derived shall automatically be considered probationary status employees, and shall be required to serve a probationary period until they have satisfactorily completed six (6) consecutive months of service. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-9; Ord. No. 95-14, § 7, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.19. - Assistance in carrying out legislative intent. 
All officials and employees of the city shall assist in carrying out the intent of this article and the personnel rules. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-10; Ord. No. 95-14, § 8, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.20. - Personnel rules. 
(a)  The personnel director shall draft, in consultation with the city manager, such rules as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this article. Following a public hearing conducted by the board, the rules recommended by the city manager, containing any revisions agreed upon as a result of the public hearing, shall be submitted to the commission by the city manager for adoption by resolution of the commission. If not adopted, amended, or rejected by the commission within sixty (60) calendar days after submission to it, they shall automatically become effective. The personnel rules shall have the force and effect of law when placed into effect. Amendments to the rules shall be made in accordance with the above procedure. 
(b)  The personnel rules shall provide, among other things: 
(1)  For open competitive examinations which shall determine the relative fitness and abilities of applicants meeting announced requirements for the respective, competitive positions in the classified service. Job opportunities shall be announced publicly with a fixed date for closing the filing of applications. Notice for promotional examinations shall be posted in conspicuous places where they may be seen by employees eligible to compete. Nothing shall prevent the personnel director from continuing to receive applications, conduct examinations, and certify candidates following announced filing or examination dates long enough to assure a sufficient number of eligibles to meet the needs of the city. 
(2)  For unassembled examinations for classes of employment where, in the opinion of the personnel director, written examinations would not be practical or feasible. 
(3)  For establishment of eligible registers, if appropriate, for initial appointment and promotion, upon which lists shall appear the names of successful candidates in order of their relative performance or ranking in the respective examinations. Such registers shall be valid for use normally for one (1) year from the date of certification. 
(4)  For the rejection of candidates who fail to comply with announced job requirements in regard to such factors as conduct, character, education and experience, or who have attempted any deception or fraud with respect to an application or examination. 
(5)  For a probationary period of six (6) months from the date of initial employment or promotion, or longer if extended by the city manager, during which time a new appointee may be discharged, demoted, or suspended without right of appeal, and a promotional probationer who has served more than one (1) full continuous year, including promotional time, may be demoted without the right of appeal. Promotional probationers who have served less than one (1) full continuous year, including promotional time, may be discharged, demoted, or suspended without right of appeal. 
(6)  For provisional employment without competitive examination where there is no appropriate eligible register available. 
(7)  For temporary employment with or without examination for not more than six (6) months. 
(8)  For keeping of records of performance of all employees in the classified service. 
(9)  For the development and operation of programs to improve the effectiveness and morale of employees in the classified service which may include training, safety, health, welfare, recreation, and other related areas. 
(10)  For disciplinary actions of discharge, demotion, or suspension without pay, only for just cause. All employees who are awarded such disciplinary actions shall be presented with a written notice stating the specific reasons for the disciplinary action, and whenever it is practical and possible, such written notice shall be personally presented to the affected employee on or before the effective date of such action, or shall be sent by registered mail, return receipt requested, to the employee's last known address. A copy of the disciplinary action shall be filed with the personnel director. 
(11)  For procedures governing layoff, re-employment, disciplinary actions, and grievances. 
(12)  For hours of work, holidays, overtime pay, vacation, sick, and other leaves, with or without pay. 
(13)  For general prohibitions relating to political activity. 
(14)  For other rules not inconsistent with this article, and which shall aid in its effectiveness. 
(c)  All personnel rules of the city in effect at the time of adoption of the ordinance from which this article was derived shall remain in full force and effect until repealed or amended by the commission. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-11; Ord. No. 95-14, §§ 9—15, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.21. - Appropriations to carry out chapter. 
A sufficient sum of money shall be appropriated each year by the commission to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-12)  
Sec. 2.22. - Amendments. 
This article may be amended by the commission without referendum. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-14)  
DIVISION 2. - PERSONNEL REVIEW BOARD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Code of ethics for public officers, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; public meetings, F.S. § 286.011; public records, F.S. § 119.01 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2.23. - Created; membership. 
(a)  There is hereby created a personnel review board, consisting of three (3) members. 
(1)  One member shall be appointed by the commission on the recommendation of the city manager. 
(2)  One member shall be elected by a simple majority vote (fifty (50) percent plus one) of all classified service employees voting in the election. 
(3)  The third member shall be appointed by the other two (2) members thus selected. 
(b)  Members of the board shall select from their own membership a chairman and a vice-chairman to serve at the pleasure of the board. 
(Code 1970, §§ 5½-20, 5½-25; Ord. No. 95-14, § 17, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.24. - Compensation. 
Members of the board shall serve without compensation. However, they shall be reimbursed for reasonable and necessary expenses. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-28)  
Sec. 2.25. - Qualifications. 
(a)  The members of the board shall be persons in sympathy with the application of merit principles to public employment and public personnel administration. 
(b)  No member of the board shall be employed by or be an official of the city, nor shall they be a member of any local, state, or national committee of a political party or an official or a member of a committee in any partisan political club or organization nor shall they hold or be a candidate for any elective office. 
(c)  Each member of the board shall be over twenty-one (21) years of age, of good moral character, of good reputation in the community, a citizen of the United States, and must have been a resident of the city for two (2) years immediately prior to appointment. 
(d)  No member of the board shall be the husband, wife, or near relative of a member of the city service. 
(e)  No person who has been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude shall be eligible for service on the personnel review board. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-21; Ord. No. 95-14, § 18, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.26. - Terms. 
Each board member selected shall serve a three (3) year term except that after the initial formation of the board, board members shall, by the drawing of lots, select one (1) member to serve a one (1) year term, one (1) member to serve a two (2) year term, and one (1) member to serve a three (3) year term. On the expiration of the term of membership for those initially selected, their successors shall be selected for a full three (3) year term. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-22)  
Sec. 2.27. - Removal, vacancies. 
Members of the board may be removed by the commission for incompetency, neglect of duty, malfeasance in office, or for other just cause. In the event of resignation or death or removal from office of a board member, the successor shall be selected without delay in accordance with the procedures hereinabove set forth to serve the balance of the unexpired term. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-23)  
Sec. 2.28. - Quorum. 
Two (2) members of the board shall constitute a quorum necessary for the conduct of the business of the board. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-24)  
Sec. 2.29. - Meetings. 
(a)  The board shall meet at the call of the chairman, or in his absence, the vice-chairman, or at the call of the personnel director. 
(b)  Meetings of the board shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1970, §§ 5½-26, 5½-27)  
DIVISION 3. - HEARINGS 
 
Sec. 2.30. - Procedure. 
(a)  If an employee affected by disciplinary actions of discharge, demotion, or suspension without pay has the right of appeal, the employee shall be allowed ten (10) working days to reply thereto in writing and request a hearing before the personnel review board. 
(b)  A copy of the appeal for hearing shall be filed with the personnel director. 
(c)  The personnel review board shall begin such hearing within thirty (30) calendar days following the receipt of the request for hearing by the employee. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-35; Ord. No. 95-14, §§ 19, 20, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 2.31. - Conduct of hearing. 
(a)  In a hearing, the board shall not be bound by technical rules of evidence, but shall use reasonable grounds and discretion to secure a fair and complete hearing of the facts of the case. 
(b)  The employee and the appointing authority who awarded the disciplinary action may be represented by counsel if desired; however, the appointing authority shall only be provided such counsel if the employee first elects to so do. The board may also have advice of counsel at such hearings. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-36)  
Sec. 2.32. - Administering oaths; issuing subpoenas. 
Each member of the board shall have the power to administer oaths and the board is authorized to compel, by subpoena, the attendance and testimony of witnesses, the production of papers, books and other documents relative to such hearing, the subpoenas to be served by the law enforcement officers of the city. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-38)  
Sec. 2.33. - Witness fees. 
All witnesses demanding witness fees for attendance shall be entitled to a per diem of one dollar ($1.00) to be paid by the city, but no employee of the city subpoenaed to appear before the board shall be entitled to any compensation, nor suffer any loss of pay for such attendance. No employees requesting hearings may, without the consent of the city, summon more than four (4) witnesses before the board at the expense of the city, but may summon any number of witnesses in excess of four (4) at his own expense. 
(Code 1970, § 5½-40)  
ARTICLE VII. - PURCHASE AND SALE OF REAL PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 2.34. - Procedure for conveyance of city property. 
(a)  The commission is expressly authorized to sell and convey any real property belonging to the city whenever the commission determines that it is in the best interest of the city to do so to the highest and best bidder for the bid use the commission determines to be the highest and best. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided herein, no sale of any real property shall be made unless notice thereof is published once a week for at least two (2) weeks in a newspaper of general circulation published in the county, calling for bids for the purchase of real estate so advertised to be sold. 
(c)  The bid of the highest bidder in the case of a sale complying with the terms and conditions set forth in such notice shall be accepted unless the commission rejects all bids because they are too low. The commission may require a deposit to be made or a surety bond to be given in such form or in such amount as the commission may determine with each bid submitted. 
(Ord. No. 82-06, § 1, 4-19-82)  
Sec. 2.35. - Exception. 
(a)  When the commission finds that the value of a parcel of real property is two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or less or when, due to the size, shape, location and value of the parcel, it is determined by the commission that the parcel is of use to one (1) or more adjacent property owners, the commission may effect a private sale of the parcel. The commission may, after sending notice of its intended action to owners of adjacent property by certified mail, effect a sale and conveyance of the parcel at private sale without receiving bids or publishing notice. 
(b)  However, if within ten (10) days after receiving such mailed notice, two (2) or more owners of adjacent property notify the commission of their desire to purchase the parcel, the commission shall accept sealed bids for the parcel from such property owners and may convey such parcel to the highest bidder or reject all offers. 
(Ord. No. 82-06, § 1, 4-19-82) 
(c)  An exception to section 2.34 for the provision of low to moderate income affordable housing shall be permitted as follows: 
(1)  The city may convey for such price, whether nominal or otherwise, as the city commission may fix, to the United States or any department or agency thereof, the state, county, corporation or not-for-profit organization, surplus real property for the purpose of providing affordable housing; 
(2)  The city commission shall have the sole discretion to determine what real property is surplus and suitable for conveyance, the entity that receives the property, and the conditions to be attached to the conveyance which will ensure that the property is used for its intended purpose; 
(3)  Affordable housing, as used in this subsection, shall have the same meaning ascribed to that term by the county community development department. 
(d)  [As] an exception to section 2.34 for the disposal of property in a community redevelopment area, the city shall follow the procedures set forth in Section 163.380, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 82-06, § 1, 4-19-82; Ord. No. 93-09, § 1, 4-19-93; Ord. No. 96-11, § 1, 3-18-96)  
Secs. 2.36—2.40. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 92-34, § 1, adopted December 7, 1992, adopted the Safety Harbor Land Development Code. Section 8.00 of such LDC repealed §§ 2.36—2.40 of the City Code. Formerly, such sections pertained to citizen participation in the comprehensive planning process and derived from Ord. No. 88-21, §§ 1—5, adopted July 18, 1988.  
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; prohibited on Safety Harbor Municipal Pier, § 16.02; prohibited in parks, § 16.03; zoning, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Municipal license tax prohibited, F.S. § 561.342(3). 
 
Sec. 3.01. - Compliance with chapter. 
No person, firm or corporation shall engage in the business of selling, bartering, exchanging or in anywise dealing in liquors, wines, beers and/or other beverages containing more than one (1) percent of alcohol by weight, within the city, without a state license and except under and in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 3-2)  
Sec. 3.02. - Definitions. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverages means any beer, wine, or liquor as defined by the state beverage law. 
(b)  Business establishment means and includes any place of business, whether or not licensed under the state beverage law, of any vendor, club, organization, corporation, firm, person, partnership or similar entity which dispenses alcoholic beverages. This shall include any establishment commonly known as a bottle club which may permit persons to carry alcoholic beverages onto the premises of such establishment with the knowledge, actual or implied, that such beverages will be consumed thereon. 
(c)  Dispense or dispensing means the storing, handling, preparation, distribution, serving, sale, or gift of any alcoholic beverage. For the purpose of this definition, permitting or allowing any person to carry alcoholic beverages onto the premises of a business establishment with such beverages to be consumed thereon shall be deemed as dispensing such beverages. This definition includes the dispensing of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption and for off-premises consumption. 
(d)  State beverage law means F.S. Chapters 561, 562, 563, 564 and 565, including subsequent amendments or successors thereto. 
(Ord. No. 2003-15, § 1, 10-20-2003) 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 2003-15, adopted Oct. 20, 2003 created § 3.02. Formerly, Ord. No. 92-34, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1992, adopted the Safety Harbor Land Development Code. Section 8.00 of such LDC repealed § 3.02 of the City Code. Formerly, such section pertained to location of business selling alcoholic beverages to public school or church and derived from § 3-9 of the 1970 Code.  
Sec. 3.03. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 92-34, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1992, adopted the Safety Harbor Land Development Code. Section 8.00 of such LDC repealed § 3.03 of the City Code. Formerly, such section pertained to waivers for distance restrictions regarding restaurants selling alcoholic beverages and derived from Ord. No. 81-54, § 1, adopted Jan. 4, 1982; and Ord. No. 83-23, § 1, adopted June 6, 1983.  
Sec. 3.04. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 92-34, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1992, adopted the Safety Harbor Land Development Code. Section 8.00 of such LDC repealed § 3.04 of the City Code. Formerly, such section pertained to waiver application fees and derived from Ord. No. 82-03, § 1, adopted Mar. 1, 1982.  
Sec. 3.05. - Hours of sale. 
(a)  All business establishments in the city, licensed or unlicensed, dispensing alcoholic beverages, public or private, directly or indirectly, shall remain closed from the hours of 2:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. on each day of the week except Saturday and Sunday. 
(b)  All business establishments in the city, licensed or unlicensed, dispensing alcoholic beverages, public or private, directly or indirectly, shall remain closed from the hours of 3:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. on Saturday and Sunday. 
(c)  Exceptions: 
(1)  Drug stores or prescription shops dealing only in medicines and drugs dispensed for medical purposes shall not be within the prohibitions of this section. 
(2)  Business establishments that dispense alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption are specifically included in the provisions of this section, with the exception that such business establishments shall not dispense alcoholic beverages between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m., each day. 
All business establishments which are engaged in a business primarily outside the purview of this section but which maintain a separate department or section within such establishment for the sale of alcoholic beverages, shall close that department or section in conformance with this chapter. 
(3)  A special event that is granted a special event permit by the city shall comply with the provisions of this chapter with regard to the sale of alcoholic beverages and shall be permitted to sell alcoholic beverages during the hours provided in this section that are applicable to business establishments selling alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption 
(Code 1970, § 3-14; Ord. No. 95-51, § 1, 12-18-95; Ord. No. 2003-15, § 2, 10-20-2003; Ord. No. 2010-13, § 1, 11-1-2010; Ord. No. 2017-16, § 1, 6-19-2017) 
State Law reference— Uniform closing hours for Pinellas County except municipalities may enact shorter opening hours, Chapter 63-1790, Laws of Florida, 1973, as amended by Chapters 76-474 and 80-586, Laws of Florida.  
Sec. 3.06. - Maintenance of premises; persons to whom beverages sold restricted. 
(a)  No licensee herein shall permit any portion of the premises occupied by or used in connection with the business licensed to be kept in an unsanitary condition nor shall such licensee engage in or permit any disorderly conduct on such premises nor in any way operate or permit the operation of the business in such a manner as to constitute a nuisance. 
(b)  No alcoholic beverage, packaged or otherwise, shall be sold, given or served to any person who is intoxicated at the time or who is forbidden by any law of the state or ordinance of the city from entering such place of business or consuming such beverage. 
(Code 1970, § 3-15) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate sanitary conditions, F.S. § 562.45(2); furnishing of alcoholic beverages to habitual drunkard, F.S. § 562.50.  
Sec. 3.07. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 95-51, adopted Dec. 18, 1995, repealed § 3.07 in its entirety. Formerly, § 3.07 pertained to transporting of illicit whiskey products and derived from § 3-22 of the 1970 Code.  
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Animals prohibited on Safety Harbor municipal pier, § 16.02; garbage and refuse, Ch. 10; health and sanitation, Ch. 11; licenses, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, F.S. § 828.02 et seq. 
 
Sec. 4.01. - Bird sanctuary. 
What is commonly known as a bird sanctuary is hereby established within all of the territory of the city, as is now or will be in the future, embraced by the city limits. 
(Code 1970, § 4-5)  
Sec. 4.02. - Restrictions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any animal of a bovine or equine species, as well as sheep, goats, swine, fowl or poultry on a parcel of land having an area of less than one and one-quarter (1¼) acres, except as provided for in the land development code and except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(b)  However, the keeping of the swine referred to as miniature Vietnamese, pot-bellied pigs solely as household pets is exempted from these restrictions subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The number of such pigs shall be limited to one (1) per any residence or premises. 
(2)  The breeding of such pigs is specifically prohibited. 
(3)  Male pigs four (4) weeks of age or older shall be neutered. 
(4)  The maximum weight of such pigs shall not exceed one hundred (100) pounds. 
(5)  Such pigs shall be controlled by a leash, tether or adequate enclosure at any time said animals are outside the residence of the owner or other person harboring, keeping or maintaining said pig. An adequate enclosure must meet the setback requirements for accessory structures provided in the city's land development regulations. "Adequate enclosure" for the purposes of this section shall not include a fence or other similar structure surrounding the entire rear, side or front yard. 
(6)  A certification from a veterinarian licensed in the state that all necessary and appropriate vaccinations have been administered. Such certification must be provided on a yearly basis. 
(7)  The area where the pigs are kept must be cleaned of feces and urine and sanitized daily. 
(c)  The keeping of chickens solely as household pets is exempt from the restrictions of section 4.02(a) subject to the following regulations: 
(1)  The number of chickens shall be limited to four (4) per any detached single-family residence; 
(2)  The breeding of chickens is specifically prohibited and the keeping of roosters is not allowed; 
(3)  No person shall slaughter any chickens; 
(4)  The chickens shall be provided with a covered enclosure (i.e., henhouse/coop) and must be kept in the covered enclosure or a fenced enclosure at all times. Chickens must be secured within a henhouse/coop during non-daylight hours; 
(5)  The yard area accessible to the chickens must be fenced with fencing adequate to contain the chickens to the property on which they are kept (the property). The henhouse/coop and the yard area available to the chickens for foraging shall be screened from view with opaque fencing; 
(6)  The space per chicken in the henhouse/coop shall not be less than four (4) square feet per chicken; 
(7)  The covered enclosure or fenced enclosure shall be located in the rear yard or a side yard of a corner lot; 
(8)  The property must be maintained so that odors from chickens, chicken manure, or other chicken related substances are not to be detectable at the property's boundaries; 
(9)  All enclosures for the keeping of chickens shall be so constructed and maintained as to prevent rodents or other pests from being harbored underneath or within the enclosure. The henhouse/coop must be impermeable to rodents, wild birds and predators, including dogs and cats. Enclosures shall be kept in neat condition, including provision of clean, dry bedding materials and regular removal of waste materials. All manure not used for composting or fertilizer shall be removed promptly; 
(10)  All feed and other items associated with the keeping of chickens that are likely to attract or to become infested with or infected by rodents or other pests shall be kept in secure containers or otherwise protected against access by rodents and other pests; 
(11)  The sale of eggs or any other chicken products derived from the keeping of chickens is prohibited. 
(Code 1970, § 4-2; Ord. No. 92-04, § 1, 3-2-92; Ord. No. 95-21, § 1, 4-3-95; Ord. No. 2017-12, §§ 1, 2, 6-8-2017)  
Sec. 4.03. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2003-08, § 1, adopted Apr. 27, 2003, repealed § 4.03, which pertained to maintenance of places where kept and derived from Code 1970, § 4-3.  
Sec. 4.04. - Traps prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person (other than authorized personnel of the Game and Fresh Water Commission of the State of Florida) to set or contrive, at any time, any trap, snare or other device or instrument which would constitute a hazard endangering the life or limb of any person, wild or domesticated animal or fowl, within the city, other than in the yard or enclosure of the residence of such person. 
(Code 1970, § 4-4)  
Sec. 4.05. - Destruction of fowl or animals prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful to trap, shoot or in any manner to kill any birds or animals, or to attempt to do so, or to disturb the nests, eggs or young of birds. 
(Code 1970, § 4-6)  
Sec. 4.06. - Potentially rabid animals. 
(a)  The owner or any other person having knowledge shall immediately report to the county animal control any dog, cat or other animal, whether vaccinated or not, which: 
(1)  Has been bitten by another animal, which animal exhibits symptoms of, or is suspected of, having rabies; 
(2)  Which has bitten any person; or 
(3)  Which exhibits symptoms of rabies. 
(b)  Such dogs, cats, or other animals shall be kept under such observation as required by the county animal control. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person who has reasonable notice that a dog, cat, or other animal is rabid to fail to notify the county animal control or to dispose of any dog, cat, or other animal inconsistent with this article. 
(d)  If any dog, cat, or other animal showing symptoms of rabies or suspected of having rabies cannot safely be taken, enclosed or kept impounded according to the provisions hereof, the county animal control may order same destroyed, at the expense of the owner. 
(Code 1970, § 4-22; Ord. No. 95-21, § 2, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 4.07. - Retail sale of cats and dogs. 
(a)  Prohibited sales. No retail establishment shall display, sell, barter, or offer for sale any cat or dog within the city. For purposes of this section, "retail establishment" shall have the same meaning as "retail sales" establishment defined in section 271.00 of the Safety Harbor Comprehensive Zoning and Land Development Code. 
(b)  Exemptions. The following organizations are exempt from the prohibitions of this section: 
(1)  Publicly operated animal shelters or publicly operated animal control facilities; 
(2)  Duly incorporated nonprofit organizations operated for the purpose of rescuing and securing adoptions for stray, abandoned, or surrendered animals, and which do not breed animals; 
(3)  A retail establishment providing space for adoption of cats or dogs from either organizations described in subsection (b)(1) or (b)(2) above; and/or 
(4)  A person or entity that causes or allows the home breeding or studding of a cat or dog resulting in no more than two (2) litters per adult animal per calendar year, provided such activity is not conducted from a retail establishment. 
(Ord. No. 2016-24, § 2, 11-7-2016) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2003-08, § 1, adopted Apr. 27, 2003, repealed § 4.07, which pertained to certain animals running at large prohibited and derived from Code 1970, § 4-1.  
Sec. 4.08. - Impounding of animals running at large. 
If any dog, cat, or other animal is found running at large, it shall be taken up and impounded by the county animal control in accordance with their regulations. 
(Code 1970, § 4-23; Ord. No. 95-21, § 3, 4-3-95)

Chapter 5 - BUILDING AND PROPERTY MAINTENANCE REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-18, § 2, adopted Feb. 7, 2011, repealed ch. 5, §§ 5.01—5.18, and enacted a new ch. 5, §§ 5.01—5.28, to read as set out herein. Former ch. 5 pertained to similar subject matter. For a complete derivation of the former provisions see the Code Comparative Table. 
Charter reference— Building regulations, § 12(40). 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; code enforcement board, § 2.10.01 et seq.; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; finance, Ch. 7; public safety building construction, § 8.18 et seq.; flood prevention and control, Ch. 9; health and sanitation, Ch. 11; licenses, Ch. 14; sign regulations, Ch. 19; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20; subdivisions, Ch. 21; public service tax, Art. II, Ch. 22; utilities, Ch. 24; zoning, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Minimum standards—building codes, F.S. § 553.73; inspection warrants, F.S. § 933.20 et seq.; thermal efficiency code, F.S. § 553.900, et seq.; Pinellas County countywide building regulation act, Ch. 75-489, as amended by Ch. 78-594, Laws of Florida. 
 
ARTICLE I. - BUILDING CODE 
 
Sec. 5.01. - Establishing the Florida Building Code as the building code of the city. 
(a)  Building code established. The Florida Building Code, as promulgated by the Florida Building Commission, as amended by the Pinellas County Construction Licensing Board and/or the Florida Building Commission, is established as the minimum building code of the city pursuant to F.S. § 553.70 et seq. and includes, but is not limited to, the following volumes: the Florida Accessibility Code, Florida Energy Code, Building, Plumbing, Electrical, and Mechanical Codes, Gas Code, and Swimming Pool Code. 
(b)  Scope. The Florida Building Code shall be viewed as minimum requirements for the purpose of regulating the construction, alteration, movement, enlargement, replacement, repair, equipment, use and occupancy, location, maintenance, removal and demolition of every building or structure or any appurtenances connected or attached to such buildings or structures in the city. 
(c)  Appeals. Appeals of decisions and interpretations of the technical codes by the building official shall be considered and decided by the Pinellas County Construction Licensing Board of Adjustment and Appeals. Notices of appeal of decisions and interpretations of the building code shall be in writing and filed within thirty (30) calendar days after the decision is rendered by the building official. Appeals shall be in a form acceptable to the building official and the Pinellas County Construction Licensing Board. 
(d)  Permits required. Any owner or authorized agent who intends to construct, enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish, or change the occupancy of a building or structure, or to erect, install, enlarge, alter, repair, remove, convert or replace any required impact-resistant coverings, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, the installation of which is regulated by this chapter, or to cause any such work to be done, shall first make application to the building official and obtain the required permit. The building official shall not issue a permit for any property within the jurisdiction to an owner or authorized agent who has an expired permit, performed work for which a permit is required without first obtaining a permit, or otherwise violated this chapter until the said violation has been corrected. 
(e)  Minor repairs. Ordinary minor repairs or installation of replacement parts may be made without a permit, provided the repairs do not include the cutting away of any wall, partition or portion thereof, the removal or cutting of any structural beam or loadbearing support, or the removal or change of any required means of egress, or rearrangement of parts of a structure affecting the egress requirements. Ordinary minor repairs also does not include addition to, alteration of replacement or relocation of any standpipe, water supply, sewer, drainage, drain leader, gas, soil, waste, vent or similar piping, electric wiring systems or mechanical equipment or other work affecting public health or general safety. 
(f)  Application for permit. To obtain a permit, the applicant shall first file a written application on a form furnished by the building department for that purpose. Each application shall be inscribed with the date of application, and the Florida Building Code in effect as of that date. 
(g)  Expiration. Every permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall become invalid unless the work on the site authorized by such permit is commenced within one hundred eighty (180) days after its issuance, or if the work authorized on the site by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days after the time the work is commenced. Failure to obtain an approved inspection within one hundred eighty (180) days of the previous approved inspection shall constitute suspension or abandonment. The building official is authorized to grant in writing, one (1) or more extensions of time, for periods not more than ninety (90) days each. The extension shall be requested in writing and justifiable cause demonstrated. Permits issued for the demolition of a structure shall expire sixty (60) days from the date of issuance. For a justifiable cause, one (1) extension of time for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days may be allowed. Such request shall be in writing to the building official. 
(h)  Fees. A schedule of permit fees for required permits shall be adopted by resolution of the city commission and provided with the building permit application form. 
(i)  Penalties. Any person violating any provision of the building code or any other provision stated in this chapter shall be subject to all penalties and remedies available under state law or city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2010-18, § 3, 2-7-2011)  
Sec. 5.02. - Duties and powers of the building official. 
(a)  General. The building official is hereby authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of articles I, II and III of this chapter. The building official shall have the authority to render code interpretations and to adopt policies and procedures in order to clarify the application of relevant provisions. Such interpretations, policies and procedures shall be in compliance with the intent and purpose of this chapter, and shall not have the effect of waiving requirements specifically provided for in this chapter. 
(b)  Building official qualifications. The building official shall be licensed as a building code administrator in the State of Florida. 
(c)  Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring a building official to perform an act or duty, it is to be construed to authorize the building official to designate, delegate and authorize professional level subordinates to perform the required act or duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
(d)  Applications and permits. The building official shall receive applications, review construction documents and issue permits for the erection, alteration, demolition and moving of buildings and structures, inspect the premises for which such permits have been issued and enforce compliance with applicable code provisions. 
(e)  Revocation of permits. The building official is authorized to suspend or revoke a permit issued under the provisions of this code wherever the permit is issued in error or on the basis of incorrect, inaccurate or incomplete information, or in violation of any ordinance or regulation or any code provision. 
(f)  Requirements not covered by code. Any requirements necessary for the strength, stability, or proper operation of an existing or proposed building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, or for the public safety, health and general welfare, not specifically covered by this code, shall be determined by the building official. 
(g)  Stop work order. Whenever the building official finds any work regulated by this code being performed in a manner either contrary to the provisions of this code or dangerous or unsafe, the building official is authorized to issue a stop work order. The stop work order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property involved, or to the owner's agent, or to the person doing the work. Upon issuance of a stop work order, the cited work shall immediately cease. The stop work order shall state the reason for the order, and the conditions under which the cited work will be permitted to resume.
