Editor's note— Ord. No. 90-34, §§ 1—26, adopted Jan. 7, 1991, amended this chapter in its entirety, in effect repealing former §§ 6.01—6.03, relative to elections, and enacting similar new provisions as Arts. I—VII, §§ 6.01—6.26. Formerly, this chapter derived from §§ 6-1 and 6-2 of the city's 1970 Code, as amended by Ord. No. 86-41, § 1, adopted Oct. 6, 1986, and Ord. No. 90-23, § 1, adopted Oct. 8, 1990. 
Charter reference— Government and legislative form of government, Art. II; elections, Art. IV. 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 6.01. - Definitions. 
The following terms, as used in this chapter, shall have the following meanings: 
Ballot or official ballot when used in reference to: 
(1)  Voting machines, except when reference is made to write-in ballots, means that portion of the printed strips of cardboard, paper, or other material that is within the ballot frames containing the names of candidates, or a statement of a proposed constitutional amendment or other question or proposition submitted to the electorate at any election. 
(2)  Paper ballots means that printed sheet of paper containing the names of candidates, or a statement of proposed constitutional amendments or other questions or propositions submitted to the electorate at any election, on which sheet of paper an elector casts his or her vote. 
(3)  Electronic or electromechanical devices means a ballot which is voted by the process of punching or marking with a marking device for tabulation by automatic tabulating equipment or data processing equipment. 
Candidate means any person to whom any one (1) or more of the following applies: 
(1)  Any person who receives contributions or make expenditures, or gives his or her consent for any other person to receive contributions or make expenditures, with a view to bringing about his or her election to, or retention in, public office. 
(2)  Any person who appoints a treasurer and designates a primary depository. 
(3)  Any person who meets the requirements of Article IV, City Charter, and sections 6.04, 6.05 and 6.06 of this Code. 
Election means any city election, be it to choose elected officials or consider issues, including regular elections, issue elections and special elections. 
Election board means the clerk and inspectors appointed to conduct an election. 
Elector is synonymous with the word "voter" or "qualified elector or voter" and means a qualified resident of the city on the day of the election, properly registered in accordance with F.S. § § 97.041 through 97.105. 
Issue means a proposed amendment to the City Charter; an ordinance proposed by initiative pursuant to section 30, City Charter; a proposed repeal of an ordinance by referendum pursuant to section 30, City Charter; the recall of an elected official; an authorization to issue bonds or other forms of indebtedness; a proposed annexation of territory into the city; straw ballot; or any other public question to be voted upon by the electors of the city pursuant to state law, City Charter, local ordinance or call of the city commission. 
Issue election means an election called for the purpose of approving or disapproving an issue. 
Newspaper of general circulation means a newspaper printed in the language most commonly spoken in the area within which it circulates and which is readily available for purchase by all inhabitants in the area of circulation, but does not include a newspaper intended primarily for members of a particular professional or occupational group, a newspaper the primary function of which is to carry legal notices, or a newspaper that is given away primarily to distribute advertising. 
Nonpartisan office means an office for which a candidate is prohibited from campaigning or qualifying as a candidate for election or retention in office based on party affiliation. 
Office or city office means a city position filled by the electors at an election. 
Persons with disabilities means individuals who have a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more major life activities. 
Polling place is the building which contains the polling room where ballots are cast. 
Polling room means the actual room in which ballots are cast. 
Precinct means that geographic area designated by the board of county commissioners upon recommendation of the county supervisor of elections. 
Qualifying means the procedure pursuant to Article IV, City Charter, and sections 6.04, 6.05 and 6.06 of this Code, whereby an individual causes his or her name to be placed on the next city election as a candidate for city office. 
Special election means an election called for the purpose of filling a vacancy in elected city office or to approve or disapprove an issue. 
Supervisor means the Supervisor of Elections of Pinellas County, Florida. 
Voting booth or booth means that booth or enclosure wherein an elector casts his or her ballot, be it a paper ballot, a voting machine ballot, or a ballot cast for tabulation by an electronic or electromechanical device. 
Voting machine means that electromechanical or electronic equipment or device approved or certified by the secretary of state pursuant to Sections 101.28, 101.294 or 101.5605, Florida Statutes, used to cast ballots in an election and owned or provided by the supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 1, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 95-16, § 1, 4-3-95; Ord. No. 96-25, § 1, 7-15-96; Ord. No. 99-20, § 1, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 2003-03, § 1, 4-7-2003)  
Sec. 6.02. - Duties of city clerk. 
The city clerk shall see that all city elections are conducted in a proper and legal manner. Subject to the approval of the city commission, the clerk may delegate any or all of the responsibilities for administering the election to the supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 2, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.03. - Voter registration. 
(a)  The city does hereby recognize and adopt the permanent single registration system for the registration of electors established by Section 97.105, Florida Statutes. Individuals residing within the corporate limits of the city otherwise qualified and registered to vote in accordance with Sections 97.041 through 97.105, Florida Statutes, are the electors of the city. 
(b)  No individual residing within the corporate limits of the city registering to vote less than thirty (30) days prior to any election shall be permitted to vote in that election. 
(c)  Any registered elector of the city may be removed from the registration records pursuant to Section 98.081, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 3, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 96-25, § 2, 7-15-96)  
Sec. 6.03.1. - Applicability of state election code. 
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, all provisions of the state election code, Chapters 97 through 106, Florida Statutes, that do not expressly apply to municipal elections shall not govern city elections. 
(Ord. No. 96-25, § 7, 7-15-96) 
Editor's note— Section 7 of Ord. No. 96-25, adopted July 15, 1996, amended the Code by adding § 6.27. For purposes of classification, such provisions have been codified herein as § 6.03.1 at the discretion of the editor.  
ARTICLE II. - CANDIDATES 
 
Sec. 6.04. - Restrictions on qualification. 
(a)  Section 99.012, Florida Statutes, is adopted, and no individual may qualify as a candidate for city office unless he or she has complied with Section 99.012, Florida Statutes. 
(b)  No individual serving on an appointed city board other than the personnel review board or committee without salary shall be required to resign from that position in order to qualify as a candidate for city office. However, a resignation is required prior to that individual assuming elected city office. Any individual serving on the personnel review board must meet the requirements of section 2.25 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 1, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 2003-03, § 2, 4-7-2003)  
Sec. 6.05. - Notice of qualifying period; method of qualifying. 
The city clerk shall cause a notice of election candidate qualifying period to be published on the city's official website one (1) time at least thirty (30) days prior to the beginning of the qualifying period. The notice shall be styled "City of Safety Harbor Notice of Election Candidate Qualifying Period" and shall state the date of the election, the dates of the qualifying period, and what offices are to be filled. The city clerk may, but is not required to, publish such notice on other digital platforms. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 5, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 2019-17, § 2, 8-5-2019)  
Sec. 6.06. - Qualifying fees for candidates. 
The candidate qualifying fees are hereby established at sixty-five dollars ($65.00) for a candidate for mayor-commissioner and forty dollars ($40.00) for a candidate for commissioner. In addition, all candidates must pay an assessment in accordance with Section 99.093(1), Florida Statutes. There shall be a charge of one (.01) cent for petition cards in excess of one hundred fifty (150) and a charge for verification of ten (.10) cents per card in excess of one hundred fifty (150). 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 6, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.07. - Vacancy in candidacy. 
(a)  Withdrawal. If the withdrawal of a qualified candidate following the end of the qualifying period results in only one (1) candidate remaining on the ballot for that office, the remaining candidate shall be declared elected and no election for that office shall be required. 
(b)  Death or removal; one candidate remaining. 
(1)  If the death or removal from the ballot of a qualified candidate following the end of the qualifying period results in only one (1) candidate remaining for that office, a special election shall be scheduled by the city commission not less than sixty (60) days nor more than one-hundred twenty (120) days after the vacancy in the candidacy has occurred. 
(2)  If a special election is called pursuant to subsection (b)(1) above, a supplemental qualifying period shall be established beginning on the day the vacancy in the candidacy has occurred and ending at noon on the forty-sixth day prior to the date of the special election. Any candidate wishing to qualify during this supplemental qualifying period shall file the qualifying statement and petition required by the City Charter, accompanied by such qualifying fees as set by the City Code, prior to the end of the supplemental qualifying period. 
(3)  The remaining candidate for that office shall not be required to requalify for election or pay a second qualifying fee. The remaining candidate shall not be declared an unopposed candidate under Chapter 106, Florida Statutes, unless no additional candidate qualifies for election during the supplemental qualifying period. The remaining candidate may continue to accept contributions until he is declared unopposed. If he is declared unopposed pursuant to this section, he shall be declared elected and the special election shall be canceled. 
(4)  The filing of campaign expense statements pursuant to Chapter 106, Florida Statutes, by candidates in a special election called under subsection (b)(1), including the remaining candidate, shall not be later than such dates as fixed by the city clerk. In fixing such dates, the city clerk shall take into consideration and be governed by the practical time limitations and the dates established for such statements in a regular city election. 
(5)  If a special election is called pursuant to subsection (b)(1) and other candidates qualify for election during the supplemental qualifying period, supplemental absentee ballots for the special election shall be mailed by the city clerk to any absentee voter who was mailed an absentee ballot for the regular election. If an absentee voter returns the initial ballot he was mailed, his vote for that office for which the special election was called will be null and void, but his votes on all other offices and issues shall be counted. 
(c)  Death, withdrawal or removal; no candidate remaining. 
(1)  If the death, withdrawal or removal from the ballot of a qualified candidate following the end of the qualifying period results in no candidates for an office, and more than twenty-one (21) days remain prior to the date of the election, qualifying shall be reopened to allow candidates to qualify for the election to that office in accordance with the City Charter and Code. Any candidate wishing to qualify shall file the qualifying statement and petition required by the City Charter, accompanied by such qualifying fees as set by the City Code, no later than noon of the twenty-first day prior to the date of the election. 
(2)  If less than twenty-one (21) days remain to the election date after the death, withdrawal or removal from the ballot of the lone qualified candidate for an office, and if a vacancy shall result on the city commission, the remaining commissioners shall appoint by majority vote a person otherwise qualified to be a commissioner, and the person so appointed shall serve as commissioner for the entire term. If the commission does not appoint a person to fill the vacancy within thirty (30) days after the first regular commission meeting held after the vacancy has occurred, a special election shall be held in order to fill the vacancy for the unexpired portion of the entire term. The special election shall be held not less than thirty (30) days nor more than ninety (90) days after the initial thirty-day period has expired. 
(3)  If the qualifying period is reopened pursuant to section 6.07(c)(1), supplemental absentee ballots reflecting the new candidates who have qualified for that office only shall be mailed by the city clerk as soon as possible to any absentee voter who was mailed an absentee ballot. If an absentee voter returns the initial ballot he was mailed, his vote for the office for which qualification was reopened will be null and void, but his votes on all other offices and issues shall be counted. 
(d)  Removal of name from ballot. The name of any qualified candidate who has withdrawn, died or been removed from the ballot shall not be printed on the ballot. If the ballot cannot be changed, any votes for that candidate shall be null and void. 
(e)  Refund of qualifying fee. A candidate withdrawing or being removed from the ballot after having qualified and paid the qualification fee shall not receive a refund of the qualifying fee. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 7, 1-7-91)  
ARTICLE III. - ISSUE ELECTIONS 
 
Sec. 6.08. - Campaign finance. 
(a)  Any individual, person, partnership, committee, association, corporation or other combination of individuals having collective capacity seeking to influence the outcome of any issue election, including any efforts to have the election called, by the receipt of contributions in an aggregate amount in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or making of expenditures in an aggregate amount in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall report such contributions and expenditures in the manner provided in Section 106.07, Florida Statutes, in the case of a political committee and Section 106.071, Florida Statutes, in the case of any individual making independent expenditures. 
(b)  A committee circulating petitions seeking a recall election of an elected official pursuant to Section 100.361, Florida Statutes, a petitioners' committee proposing an initiative pursuant to section 30, City Charter, a petitioners' committee proposing the repeal of an ordinance by the referendum provisions of section 30, City Charter, and any individual, group, association or corporation seeking to influence the results of a bond referendum shall constitute a political committee under Chapter 106, Florida Statutes, and shall register as provided in Section 106.03, Florida Statutes, prior to soliciting and collecting any petition signatures and shall file campaign finance reports as required by Section 106.07, Florida Statutes, provided such committee anticipates receiving or does receive contributions in the aggregate in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and anticipates making or does make expenditures in the aggregate in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  The city commission may appropriate funds for the purpose of providing informational materials to the public in connection with any issue election, except for a recall election. The city commission shall not be considered a political committee as defined in Section 106.011(1), Florida Statutes, and shall not be required to file reports of any such informational expenditures pursuant to Section 106.07, Florida Statutes. 
(d)  Any suspected or alleged violations of Chapter 106, Florida Statutes, in connection with any issue election shall be transmitted to the division of elections of the Florida Department of State pursuant to the enforcement provisions of Chapter 106. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 8, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 95-16, § 2, 4-3-95; Ord. No. 96-25, § 3, 7-15-96)  
Sec. 6.09. - Initiative and referendum elections. 
(a)  The petitioners' committee shall pay the supervisor the fee for verification as required by Section 99.097(4), Florida Statutes. 
(b)  If the city commission is considering an ordinance proposed under section 30, City Charter, at the time of its withdrawal under section 35, City Charter, it may, in its discretion, continue such consideration. If an election has been called prior to the petition's withdrawal, the city clerk shall, upon receipt of the request, transmit a notice thereof to the city commission and the supervisor, and the city commission shall cancel the election. 
(c)  If at any time prior to the election the city commission adopts the proposed initiative ordinance without any change in substance or repeals an adopted ordinance that is the subject of a referendum petition, and an election has been called for the electors to vote on that ordinance, the city commission shall cancel that election. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 9, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 95-16, § 3, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 6.10. - Bond authorization; involuntary annexation. 
(a)  An election required by the City Charter to approve the issuance of bonds or other forms of indebtedness shall be called and conducted pursuant to Sections 100.291 through 100.342, Florida Statutes, and this chapter. 
(b)  A referendum on the involuntary annexation of land adjacent to the corporate limits shall be held and conducted pursuant to Section 171.0413, Florida Statutes, and the provisions of this chapter to the extent not inconsistent with the statute. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 10, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.11. - Straw ballots. 
(a)  The city commission may at any time, by resolution, call an election for the purpose of having the electors of the city vote on an issue in a nonbinding referendum. The resolution shall call the election, set the date therefor and prescribe the ballot language. The city clerk shall cause a notice of election to be published in accordance with section 6.14. 
(b)  The election may be held in conjuncture with a regularly scheduled state, county or city election or at such other time as provided by the city commission and shall be conducted in accordance with this chapter and the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 11, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.12. - Election code; violations, penalties. 
The provisions of Chapter 104, Florida Statutes, are hereby adopted and made fully applicable to all city elections. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 12, 1-7-91)  
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTION ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 6.13. - Precincts. 
(a)  Those precincts approved by the board of county commissioners situated within the corporate limits of the city are hereby designated as the city precincts to be used in any and all city elections. 
(b)  The city clerk shall see that a certified copy of any annexation ordinance approved by the city commission is sent to the supervisor. Precinct boundaries may be altered to conform to the municipal boundaries as changed due to annexation. 
(c)  In the event a precinct boundary is unable to be altered to conform to annexation by the date of a city election, any qualified elector residing within the area annexed shall be eligible to vote in the city election. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 13, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 96-25, § 4, 7-15-96)  
Sec. 6.14. - Notice of election. 
(a)  The city clerk shall cause a notice of election to be published in a newspaper of general circulation at least once during the fifth week and once in the third week preceding the week in which the election is held. 
(b)  The notice shall be styled "City of Safety Harbor Notice of Election" and shall state the date of the election, what offices are to be filled and any issue to be voted upon. The ballot language of any issue shall be included in the notice. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 14, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.15. - Polling places. 
(a)  Whenever possible, those polling places designated and used by the supervisor for federal, state and county elections shall be used for city elections. 
(b)  Each polling place shall be accessible to the handicapped and comply with the standards of accessibility set forth in Section 101.715(1), Florida Statutes. 
(c)  The polling place shall be arranged in the manner prescribed in Section 101.37, Florida Statutes. 
(d)  No one except the inspectors of the elections shall be allowed to speak to the voter while in the polling place casting his or her vote, and no inspector shall speak or interfere with any voter concerning the manner of his or her voting or any ballot he or she may vote, other than to perform his or her duties as such inspector specified herein. Provided, however, that an elector may seek and receive assistance in accordance with Section 101.051, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 15, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 95-16, § 4, 4-3-95)  
Sec. 6.16. - Voting machines. 
(a)  Voting machines shall be used in each city election. The machines shall be owned by the county and supplied by the supervisor. 
(b)  The number of voting machines in each precinct for city elections shall be determined by the city clerk. In making such determination, the city clerk shall consider the traditional voting patterns and turnout in each precinct for a city election and furnish the number of machines necessary to handle efficiently the anticipated number of voters in that precinct. The clerk also shall follow the requirements of Section 101.33, Florida Statutes, in determining the number of voting machines to be used. 
(c)  The voting machines to be used in a city election shall be prepared by the supervisor in accordance with Chapter 101, Florida Statutes, and with the approval of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 16, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 96-25, § 5, 7-15-96)  
Sec. 6.17. - Ballots. 
(a)  The form of the ballot in elections for city commissioner shall be in substantially the same form as the form of the ballot for the state general election as prescribed in Section 101.151, Florida Statutes. Ballots shall be prepared by the supervisor in accordance with state law and this chapter and with the approval of the city clerk. 
(b)  Candidates shall be grouped together on the ballot by seat and for each seat in alphabetical order by the last name of each candidate. Any issue on a ballot also having candidates for elective office shall be placed in a position on the ballot so that it is separate and distinct from that portion of the ballot containing candidates' names and shall be placed on the ballot either after or to the right of the candidates' position on the ballot. 
(c)  The name of a candidate shall be printed on the ballot in the same form as the name appears on the candidate's request to be placed on the ballot. No title or evidence of incumbency shall be printed. 
(d)  The city clerk shall publish a sample ballot in a newspaper of general circulation prior to the day of the election but no more than ten (10) days prior to the election. However, the city clerk shall not be required to publish a sample ballot if the supervisor has or will publish a sample ballot that includes the city's election. Such publication shall be conspicuous and not be included within the legal notices and advertisements being published per Chapter 50, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 17, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 2003-03, § 3, 4-7-2003; Ord. No. 2012-18, § 1, 11-19-2012)  
Sec. 6.18. - Poll workers. 
(a)  The clerk shall determine and select the necessary number of poll workers for any city election with the approval of the city commission. 
(b)  Poll workers shall conduct the election in the manner provided in Chapters 101 and 102, Florida Statutes, to the extent not inconsistent with this chapter and report the results in the manner directed by the city clerk. Electors shall cast their votes in the manner provided in Chapter 101, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 18, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.19. - Absentee voting. 
(a)  An elector may request an absentee ballot and cast an absentee vote in any city election. 
(b)  An absentee ballot may be requested from the supervisor of elections for the county in the manner provided in Section 101.62, Florida Statutes, and voted in accordance with Sections 101.64 through 101.67, Florida Statutes, and returned to the office of the supervisor of elections. 
(c)  Absentee ballots for any city election must be requested from and returned to the supervisor of elections for the county and shall be received and kept in the same manner as provided in Section 101.67, Florida Statutes. 
(d)  Reserved. 
(e)  Absentee ballots shall be canvassed by the canvassing board in the manner provided in Section 101.68, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 19, 1-7-91; Ord. No. 96-25, § 6, 7-15-96; Ord. No. 98-08, §§ 1, 2, 4-20-98; Ord. No. 2003-03, § 4, 4-7-2003)  
Sec. 6.19.1. - Early voting. 
The City of Safety Harbor intends to exercise its right to exempt itself from the provisions of Section 101.657, Florida Statutes, and, therefore, shall contract with the Pinellas County Supervisor of Elections to provide facilities and services for early voting. Voters who wish to participate in early voting may do so at the offices of the Pinellas County Supervisor of Elections. 
(Ord. No. 2004-26, § 1, 12-6-2004)  
ARTICLE V. - CANVASSING, PROTESTS AND CONTESTS 
 
Sec. 6.20. - Canvassing board. 
(a)  The city commission shall meet as a canvassing board and shall canvass the returns of each city election. In the event that any commissioner is the subject of a recall election in the election being canvassed or is a candidate with opposition in the election being canvassed, he or she shall be replaced by a qualified elector of the city appointed by the city commission. Anyone so appointed shall not be a candidate with opposition in the election being canvassed or an active participant in the campaign of any candidate in the election being canvassed. However, any such appointments shall only be required to ensure that there are at least three (3) voting members of the board. Any qualified elector so appointed shall serve on the board only for purposes of the regular or special election being canvassed, and his term shall terminate upon the completion of the canvassing of said election. The city clerk and city attorney shall serve as ex officio members of the board. The board shall ensure that the ballots cast for any election are fairly and accurately counted and shall certify the results of each election. 
(b)  The board shall canvass the returns in accordance with Section 102.141(3), Florida Statutes, and shall canvass absentee ballots in accordance with Section 101.68, Florida Statutes. 
(c)  At such time as the board has canvassed the returns, disposed of any challenges thereto, and ascertained and certified the results, the city clerk shall issue a certificate of election to each candidate elected and shall issue a certificate of each issue. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 20, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.21. - Recounts. 
(a)  If the returns for any office reflect that a candidate was defeated by one-half (½) of a percent or less of the votes cast for such office, that a commissioner subject to recall was retained or not retained by one-half (½) of a percent or less of the votes cast on the question of recall, or that an issue appearing on the ballot was approved or rejected by one-half (½) of a percent or less of the votes cast on such measure, the canvassing board shall order a recount of the votes cast with respect to such office, recall or issue. A recount need not be ordered with respect to the returns for any office, however, if the candidate or candidates defeated or recalled for such office by one-half (½) of a percent or less of the votes cast for such office or their designated representatives request that a recount not be made. The canvassing board shall examine the counters on the machines or the tabulation of the ballots cast in each precinct in which the office or issue appeared on the ballot and determine whether the returns correctly reflect the votes cast. If there is a discrepancy between the returns and the counters of the machines or the tabulation of the ballots cast, the counters of such machines or the tabulation of the ballots cast shall be presumed correct and such votes shall be canvassed accordingly. 
(b)  If a machine recount ordered in accordance with subsection (a) of this section reflects a margin of one-half (½) of one (1) percent or less in an election for an office, a manual recount shall be ordered upon the request of the losing candidate or his designated representative. 
(c)  Upon request of any board member, candidate or elector for good cause shown, the canvassing board may, prior to the final certification of results, order a machine recount in whole or in part of the election in which that candidate participated or of any issue election. 
(d)  The procedures for any manual recount shall be as follows: 
(1)  A counting team of at least two (2) electors and the clerk or his/her designee or the supervisor or his/her designee shall be appointed by the canvassing board to count no more than one thousand five hundred (1,500) ballots. A counting team shall have, when possible, a representative of each candidate, who may be the two (2) electors appointed by the canvassing board. The board may appoint one (1) of its members to each counting team. 
(2)  A counting team shall count the votes of one (1) precinct at a time. The absentee ballots shall be counted at one (1) time as if a separate precinct. Each team shall record the number of votes for each position on the ballot, the number of no votes for said office or issue, the number of void ballots, and the totals for those categories for each precinct it counts. 
(3)  If a counting team is unable to determine a voter's intent in casting a ballot, the ballot shall be presented to the canvassing board for the board to determine the voter's intent. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 21, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.22. - Tie elections. 
If in any election the returns, as certified by the canvassing board, result in a tie vote, the election shall be decided by lot, which shall mean that the name of each candidate who has tied shall be placed on a piece of paper, which shall be placed in a container so that the candidates' names are not visible. A member of the canvassing board designated by the board shall then select one (1) piece of paper from the container. The candidate whose name appears on that piece of paper shall be declared elected. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 22, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.23. - Protests and contests. 
The provisions of Sections 102.166 through and including 102.169, Florida Statutes, are hereby adopted for all city elections. All protests and contests challenging the returns of any election shall be filed in accordance with these state statutes, except that the city canvassing board shall be substituted for the county canvassing board. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 23, 1-7-91)  
ARTICLE VI. - CAMPAIGN PRACTICE 
 
Sec. 6.24. - Policy. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city that all elections shall be conducted in a proper, orderly and fair manner so as to permit the will of the electorate to be determined. Likewise, issue elections shall be conducted in a manner so as to permit the free and robust exchange of ideas and opinions, yet avoiding unfair and improper campaign tactics which abuse the open debate so vital to our democratic concept of government. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 24, 1-7-91)  
Sec. 6.25. - Unfair campaign practice. 
(a)  It shall be an unfair campaign practice for a candidate to elective city office, or an agent or authorized representative thereof on behalf of such candidate, to: 
(1)  Campaign by way of announcements, publications or other forms of political advertising as a registered member of any political party; 
(2)  Campaign by way of announcements, publications or other forms of political advertising in such a manner as to indicate that such candidate is not a registered member of a particular political party; 
(3)  Solicit or accept contributions or open assistance or support from any partisan political club or association affiliated with any political party or from any political party; or 
(4)  Participate in any partisan political party function; provided, however, that such candidate or agent thereof may register and vote as a member of a political party, and may attend and speak at a political party function or event provided all candidates for city office have been invited and permitted to participate in the same manner and to the same extent. 
(b)  Any person committing an act prohibited by this section shall be guilty of an unfair campaign practice and a municipal ordinance violation punishable as provided in section 1.12 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 25, 1-7-91)  
ARTICLE VII. - CAMPAIGN FINANCES 
 
Sec. 6.26. - Application of state law. 
(a)  Any candidate for elective city office, including an elected officer sought to be recalled, is subject to and shall comply with the provisions of Chapter 106, Florida Statutes. 
(b)  Any group, club, association or other combination of persons having a collective capacity, receiving contributions or making expenditures in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), seeking to influence the results of a city election, constitutes a political committee within the definition of Section 106.011(1), Florida Statutes, and shall register and report as such pursuant to and be subject to Chapter 106, Florida Statutes. 
(c)  Any individual making independent expenditures in a city election as defined in Section 106.011(5), Florida Statutes, in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more shall be subject to and comply with Section 106.071, Florida Statutes. 
(d)  Violation of Chapter 106, Florida Statutes, shall be enforced in the manner provided in Sections 106.25 through 106.28, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-34, § 26, 1-7-91)  
Chapter 7 - FINANCE[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE II. - BUDGETS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Annual budget and tax levy, Art. X. 
State Law reference— Method of fixing millage; budget adoption, F.S. § 200.065. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 7.01. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases when used in this article shall have the following meanings respectively ascribed to them unless otherwise provided: 
Budget year shall mean the fiscal year for which a budget is made. 
Current year shall mean the fiscal year in which a budget is prepared and adopted, i.e., the fiscal year immediately preceding the budget year. 
Previous year shall mean the last complete fiscal year before the current year. 
Budget officer shall mean the city manager or a person designated by the city manager for presentation of the budget to the commission. 
Chief financial officer shall mean the finance director. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§§ 30-1.1—30.1-5), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.02. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to adopt general rules governing the commission in its proceedings for administering the financial affairs of the city by: 
(1)  Establishing a standard procedure for the preparation and administration of budgets; 
(2)  Placing responsibility for the tasks related to the budget preparation and administration; 
(3)  Determining the amount of taxes and other revenues in such manner that budgets may be balanced on the basis of actual revenues and obligations within the budget period; 
(4)  Establishing appropriations, the payment of debt and the control of other expenditures. 
(b)  The provisions are to enable the commission to make financial plans for both current and capital expenditures, to insure that the executive staff administer their respective functions in accordance with these plans, and to permit taxpayers and investors to form intelligent opinions based on sufficient information as to the financial policies and administration of the city. 
(c)  For the accomplishment of this purpose, the provisions of this article shall be liberally construed, and shall be in effect until repealed or amended. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-2.1), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.03. - Powers and duties. 
Within the provisions and for the purpose of this article, officers and employees shall have the power and be subject to the duties expressly stated or necessarily implied. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-2.2), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.04. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year of the city shall begin on the first day of October of each year and end on the last day of September of the following year. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-2.3), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.05. - Accounting continuity. 
All budget practices not covered by this article shall be in accordance with GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Practices) and in accordance with GAAFR (Government Accounting, Auditing and Financial Reporting) rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-8.1), 5-5-82)  
DIVISION 2. - PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 7.06. - Preparation and submission of budget. 
(a)  The budget officer shall submit to the commission a budget and an explanatory budget message in the form and with the contents provided by this article at least thirty (30) days prior to the beginning of each fiscal year. 
(b)  Not less than sixty (60) days prior to the beginning of the fiscal year, the budget officer shall obtain from the head of each office, department, or agency, an estimate of its revenues and expenditures. These estimates shall include a minimum of the following: 
(1)  Estimated revenues to be produced; 
(2)  Expenditures classified by: 
a.  Personal services; 
b.  Contractual services; 
c.  Material and supplies; 
d.  Capital outlay; and 
e.  Debt service. 
(3)  A list of all new programs and capital projects pending or which such department head believes should be undertaken within the budget year or within the next succeeding five years; and 
(4)  Such other supporting data as may be requested. 
(c)  The budget officer shall review the estimates with department heads and may, at his discretion, revise the estimates. The budget officer shall also obtain from the responsible officer estimates of anticipated state and federal grants and required matching funds where applicable. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-3.1), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.07. - Public record. 
The proposed budget and budget message and all supporting schedules shall be public records and shall be kept in the office of the city clerk, open to public inspection during normal working hours. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-3.2), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.08. - Public hearings on budget. 
Federal revenue sharing regulations and/or state statute requirements shall be followed for public hearings. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-3.3), 5-5-82) 
State Law reference— Method of fixing millage; budget adoption procedure, F.S. § 200.065; financial matters, F.S. Ch. 218.  
Sec. 7.09. - Further consideration of budget. 
After public hearings, the commission may insert new items or may increase or decrease the items of the budget, except those items in proposed expenditures fixed by law or prescribed in subsections (1), (2), and (3) of section 7.22 of this article, but in any event, the commission shall set the ad valorem tax millage at such a rate that total anticipated revenues shall at least equal total proposed expenditures. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-3.4), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.10. - Adoption. 
The budget shall be adopted by a majority of all the members of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-3.5), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.11. - Date of final adoption; failure to adopt. 
The budget shall be finally adopted not later than September twenty-seventh of each year. Should the governing body take no final action on the budget prior to such date, the budget of the previous year shall continue until adoption of the new budget. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-3.6), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.12. - Effective date and certification of copies. 
The budget shall be in effect for the budget year. A copy of the budget, as finally adopted, shall be certified by the budget officer and filed in the office of the chief financial officer. A copy of the budget so certified shall be kept in the office of the city clerk for inspection by the general public. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-3.7), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.13. - Appropriations. 
Adoption of the budget shall be authorization for the chief financial officer to make appropriations from surplus funds or from revenues as they are received. No appropriations may be made by the chief financial officer in excess of that authorized by the commission except as provided for in section 7.27 of this article. Outstanding encumbrances of authorized appropriations on September thirtieth of the previous budget year shall be automatically reappropriated on October first of the new budget year without any further action by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-3.8), 5-5-82)  
DIVISION 3. - SCOPE AND CONTENTS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Local financial management and reporting, F.S. Ch. 218, Part III. 
 
Sec. 7.14. - Budget message; current operations. 
The budget message submitted by the budget officer to the commission shall be explanatory of the budget; shall contain an outline of the proposed financial policies for the fiscal year; and shall describe in connection therewith the important features of the budget plan. It shall set forth the reasons for important or significant changes from the current year in appropriation and revenue items and shall explain any major changes in the financial policy of the city. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.1), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.15. - Capital improvements. 
(a)  As part of the budget message, the budget officer shall include a statement of pending capital projects and proposed capital projects, including the amounts to be appropriated from: 
(1)  Estimated revenues for the budget year; 
(2)  The issuance of bonds; 
(3)  State or federal grants; and 
(4)  Loans or other sources. 
(b)  The budget message shall include a capital program of proposed capital projects for each of the five (5) fiscal years next succeeding the budget year, together with estimated costs. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.2), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.16. - Supporting schedules. 
The budget officer shall attach to the budget message such supporting schedules, exhibits and other explanatory material, with respect to both current operations and capital improvements, as the budget officer shall believe useful to the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.3), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.17. - Financial plan. 
(a)  The budget shall provide a complete program and financial plan for the appropriation for expenditures of all funds for the budget year and shall contain for each fund: 
(1)  A general summary; 
(2)  Detailed estimates of all anticipated revenues applicable to proposed expenditures; and 
(3)  All proposed expenditures. 
(b)  The total of such anticipated revenues shall equal the total of such proposed expenditures. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.4), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.18. - Anticipated revenues—Sources. 
Anticipated revenues shall include revenue from all sources, including grants and loans and shall be classified in accordance with the chart of accounts of the city. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.5), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.19. - Same—Comparison with other years. 
In parallel columns, opposite the several items of anticipated revenue, there shall be placed: 
(1)  The amount of each item actually received during the previous year; 
(2)  The total of the amount of each item actually received to the time of preparing the budget, plus estimated receipts for the remainder of the current year; and 
(3)  The estimated amount of each item anticipated to be received during the budget year. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.6), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.20. - Fund balance. 
The fund balance available for appropriation shall be limited to the amount by which liquid or current assets are estimated to exceed liabilities at the beginning of the budget year. This estimate shall be reviewed by the budget officer as soon as practical after the end of the current fiscal year when the actual "fund balance" is determined. At this time, the estimates of revenue and authorized appropriations shall be revised if necessary. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.7), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.21. - Anticipated surplus from municipal utility or other public service enterprise. 
The anticipated revenue and proposed expenditures of each utility or other public service enterprise owned or operated by the city shall be stated in a separate section of the budget. Any anticipated surplus in excess of bond requirements, if legally available for general purposes and to the extent such surplus is to be used to support general budget operations, shall be stated as an item of revenue. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.8), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.22. - Proposed expenditures. 
The proposed expenditures shall be itemized as set out in section 7.06 and each item numbered in accordance with the classification system of the state uniform accounting system for local government units. Separate provision shall be included in the budget for at least: 
(1)  Interest, amortization, and redemption charges on bonds outstanding; 
(2)  Other statutory expenditures; 
(3)  Any budget deficit of current year; 
(4)  Administration, operation, and maintenance of each office, department, and service, function or activity; 
(5)  Contingent expense in an amount not more than five (5) percent of the total amount stated pursuant to subsection (4) of this section; and 
(6)  Expenditures proposed for capital projects. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.9), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.23. - Same—Comparison with other years. 
In parallel columns, opposite the items of proposed expenditures, there shall be: 
(1)  The amount of such item expended during the previous year; 
(2)  The total of the amount expended to the time of preparing the budget plus the expenditures for the remainder of the current year; and 
(3)  The amount of each item to be appropriated for the budget year. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.10), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.24. - Summary. 
The budget officer shall prepare and present the budget with a summary of the budget, which need not be itemized further than by principal sources of anticipated revenue, stating separately the amount to be raised by property tax, and by departments and kinds of expenditures, in such a manner as to present to taxpayers a simple and clear summary of the detailed estimates of the budget. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-4.11), 5-5-82)  
DIVISION 4. - ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 7.25. - Approval of expenditures. 
The chief financial officer shall administer the financial affairs of the city under the direction of the city manager and to that end shall supervise and be responsible for the disbursement of all monies and have control over all expenditures to insure that appropriations are not exceeded. He shall exercise financial budgetary control over each office, department, and agency and shall cause separate accounts to be kept for the items of appropriation contained in the budget, each of which account shall show the amount of the appropriation the amounts paid therefrom, the unpaid obligations against it, and the unencumbered balance. The same classification and numbering system used in the budget and required by section 7.22 shall be used. Unless he shall certify that there is a sufficient unencumbered balance available, no appropriation shall be encumbered and no expenditure shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-5.1), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.26. - Work programs; allotments. 
(a)  Before the beginning of the budget year, the head of each office, department, or agency shall submit to the budget officer, a work program for the year. The program shall show the requested allotments of appropriations for such office, department, or agency, by quarterly periods, for the entire budget year. The budget officer shall review the requested allotments and the work program, and may revise, alter, or change such allotments. The aggregate of such allotments shall not exceed the total appropriation to the office, department, or agency for the budget year. 
(b)  The budget officer shall certify a copy of the allotments approved to the chief financial officer who shall authorize all expenditures for the offices, departments, and agencies to be made from the appropriations on the basis of approved allotments. The approved allotment may be revised during the budget year in the same manner as the original allotment was made. 
(c)  If, at any time during the budget year, the budget officer shall ascertain that the available income, plus balances, for the year will be less than the total appropriations, he shall avoid the making of expenditures in excess of the income. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-5.2), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.27. - Transfer of appropriations. 
The budget officer may, at any time, transfer any unencumbered appropriation balance or portion thereof between general classifications of expenditures within a department, and service, function or activity. At the request of the budget officer, the commission by resolution may transfer any unencumbered appropriation balance or portion thereof, or from contingency, from one office, department, or agency to another. No transfers may be made from appropriations required by subsections (1), (2), and (3) of section 7.22 of this article or from any other appropriation restricted by law. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-5.3), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.28. - Certain contracts and expenditures prohibited. 
(a)  No office, department, or agency shall, during any budget year, expend or contract to expend any money or incur any liability, or enter into any contract which by its terms involve the expenditure of money in excess of the amounts appropriated for the general classification of expenditures pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Any contract, verbal or written, made in violation of this article shall be null and void. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-5.4), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.29. - Appropriations at end of year. 
All appropriations that have not been expended or lawfully encumbered shall lapse upon the adoption of a new budget. (Refer to section 7.13) 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-5.5), 5-5-82)  
DIVISION 5. - EMERGENCY APPROPRIATIONS AND BORROWING 
 
Sec. 7.30. - Emergency appropriations. 
At any time in any budget year, the commission may, by resolution, make emergency appropriations to meet a pressing need for public expenditure, for other than a regular or recurring requirement, to protect the public health, safety, or welfare. The total amount of emergency appropriations made in any budget year shall not exceed the amount of unanticipated actual revenue received in excess of the budget estimates, plus transfers from other appropriations. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-6.1), 5-5-82)  
Sec. 7.31. - Borrowing in anticipation of taxes. 
The city commission may, by resolution, borrow money and issue negotiable notes of the city in anticipation of the collection of revenues for the budget year, but not in excess of seventy-five (75) percent of such revenue then uncollected. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-6.2), 5-5-82)  
DIVISION 6. - REPORTS 
 
Sec. 7.32. - Financial reports. 
The budget officer shall, within forty-five (45) days after the end of each quarter, report to the commission on the status of the various programs authorized. The report shall include a tabular statement comparing the receipts to date by source with the revenue estimate and a tabular statement indicating for each appropriation the amount appropriated, the amount expended or encumbered to date, and the available balance. 
(Ord. No. 82-10, § 1(§ 30-7.1), 5-5-82; Ord. No. 98-09, § 1, 4-20-98)  
ARTICLE III. - MISCELLANEOUS FEES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 7.33. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 92-34, § 1, adopted December 7, 1992, adopted the Safety Harbor Land Development Code. Section 8.00 of such LDC repealed § 7.33 of the City Code. Formerly, such section pertained to planning and zoning fees and derived from Ord. No. 80-42, § 1, adopted Sept. 15, 1980.  
DIVISION 2. - ASSESSMENT FOR LAW ENFORCEMENT TRAINING 
 
Sec. 7.34. - Assessment of additional court costs for law enforcement educational expenditures fund. 
(a)  There is hereby assessed by the city, in compliance with Section 943.25(8), Florida Statutes, an additional two dollars ($2.00) as court cost against every person convicted for violation of a state penal or criminal statute or convicted for violation of a municipal or county ordinance in any proceedings, except for violations relating to parking of vehicles. In addition, two dollars ($2.00) shall be deducted from every bond estreature or forfeited bail bond related to such penal statutes or penal ordinances for any offense, except that relating to parking of vehicles. 
(b)  The funds as levied and assessed as additional court costs or taken from the bonds shall be used exclusively for law enforcement educational expenditures for the law enforcement force which has jurisdiction for the city. 
(Code 1970, § 1-9; Ord. No. 85-12, § 1, 5-20-85)  
DIVISION 3. - USER FEE FOR INFORMATION ON MUNICIPAL CHARGES 
 
Sec. 7.35. - User fee imposed. 
(a)  When it is necessary for the city clerk or designee to furnish or verify to any individual, entity or title company the present existence or nonexistence of charges due the city for water, sewer, garbage or any other municipal service, the obligation of which is not recorded in the public records, there shall be a user charge imposed for the providing of this information. 
(b)  If the individual, entity or title company requires the information within twenty-four (24) hours of the request or less, a twenty-dollar charge will be imposed for providing this service. If, however, the individual, entity or title company requesting the information does not require the information within twenty-four (24) hours, the charge for providing the service will be five dollars ($5.00). In either case, there shall be an additional charge of two dollars ($2.00) when a response by facsimile machine is requested. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to any justiciable dispute between a property owner and the city as to information provided to establish the amount or existence of an outstanding charge. 
(Code 1970, § 2-4; Ord. No. 90-27, § 1, 11-5-90; Ord. No. 93-28, § 1, 9-20-93; Ord. No. 98-09, § 2, 4-20-98)  
DIVISION 4. - LIBRARY IMPACT FEES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 90-05, §§ 1—8, adopted Apr. 2, 1990, not specifically amendatory of this Code, has been codified as Div. 4, §§ 7.36—7.43, of this article at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 7.36. - Title. 
This division shall be known as the "City of Safety Harbor Fair Share Library Impact Fee Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 1, 4-2-90)  
Sec. 7.37. - Purpose and authority. 
(a)  The city commission of the city has determined and recognized that the growth rate the city will experience through the year 2000 will necessitate a significant expansion of the city's capital library facilities and resources in order to provide adequate quality of library opportunities for city residents. 
(b)  In order to finance the capital and resource improvements necessary to comply with Florida Library Association standards, several combined methods of financing will be necessary, one (1) of which will require all residential land development in the city to pay a "fair share library fee." 
(c)  Implementing such regulatory and financing program is the responsibility of Safety Harbor in order to carry out the legislative intent of the 1985 Florida Growth Management Act as contained in Chapter 163, Part II, Title XI, Volume 1, Florida Statutes, 1989, and is in the best interest of the public health, safety and welfare. 
(d)  It is the purpose of this division to establish a regulatory system to assist in providing funding for the expansion of the city's capital library facilities and resources caused by the city's new growth. Pursuant to this division, residential land development will be required to pay a fair share library fee which does not exceed a proportionate share of the reasonable anticipated costs for the expansion of the city's capital library facilities and resources caused by new growth. 
(e)  It is not the purpose of this division to collect any money from any new residential development in excess of the actual amount necessary to offset the demand for expansion placed on the city's capital library facilities and resources. 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 2, 4-2-90)  
Sec. 7.38. - Time of payment. 
No building permit shall be issued for the development of any residential unit until the applicable fair share library fee is paid or determined to be unnecessary pursuant to the provisions of section 7.39(b) below. 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 3, 4-2-90)  
Sec. 7.39. - Fair share library fee to be imposed on new residential land development activity. 
(a)  Payment of fair share fee prior to issuance of building permit. Any person who shall receive a building permit for any new residential land development activity that places an increased demand on the city's library capital facilities and resources shall pay a fair share library fee as follows: 
Land Use Type     Fee  
Residential unit ..... $383.00 
(b)  Individual assessment of fiscal impact of land development activity on library capital facilities and resources; the library impact analysis. 
(1)  Any person who shall initiate any land development activity that places a demand on the city's library capital facilities and resources may choose to provide an individual assessment of the demand the proposed land development activity will place on the city's library facilities in order to show the capital and resource expansion costs necessitated by the proposed land development activity are less than the fair share fee established above. 
(2)  The individual assessment shall be undertaken through the submission of a library facilities analysis which shall include the following information: 
a.  The projected use of library facilities by the proposed land development activity. This projection shall be based upon either local empirical surveys or state or national information; 
b.  An assessment of the capital and resource expansion of the city's library facilities necessitated by the proposed land development, if those facilities are to be maintained at standards established by the Florida Library Association. Standard practices and methodological procedures in impact analysis shall be used to determine the capital and resource expansion of the city's library facilities necessitated by the proposed land development activity; 
c.  An assessment of the costs for providing the capital and resource expansion necessitated by the proposed land development activity. The cost figures used shall be based upon recent empirical information of the costs in Safety Harbor for acceptable library capital facilities and resources and shall include the construction costs for library space, and the planning, design and engineering costs for the necessary capital improvements; 
d.  An assessment of the projected tax revenues that will be derived from the proposed land development activity that can be reasonably determined to be available to pay for new capital and resource improvements to the city's library facilities; and 
e.  The amount of any shortfall between the projected tax revenues and the capital and resource expansion costs for the library facilities necessitated by the new land development activity. Any shortfall shall be considered the proposed fair share library fee. 
(3)  The library facilities impact analysis shall be prepared by qualified professionals in the fields of community impact analysis, economics and library capital facility and resource standards and shall be submitted to the city manager. 
(4)  Within thirty (30) days of receipt of a library facilities impact analysis, the city manager, after consulting the appropriate staff members, shall determine if it is complete. If the city manager determines the application is not complete, he shall send a written statement specifying the deficiencies by mail to the person submitting the application. Unless the deficiencies are corrected within ten (10) days of receipt of notice, the city manager shall take no further action on the library facilities impact analysis. 
(5)  When the city manager determines the library facilities impact analysis is complete, he shall review it within thirty (30) days and, after consulting the appropriate staff members, shall approve the proposed fee, if it is determined that the methodology used to determine the proposed fair share library fee is professionally acceptable and fairly assesses the costs for capital and resource improvements to the city's library facilities that are necessitated by the proposed land development activity if the city's library facilities are going to be maintained at the level of service established by the Florida Library Association. If the city manager determines the methodology is unreasonable, it shall be denied, and the developer shall pay the fair share library fee as established in subsection (a) of this section. 
(6)  Any person may appeal the city manager's decision on any library facilities impact analysis he submits by filing a petition with the city commission within thirty (30) days of a decision by the city manager. In reviewing the city manager's decision, the city commission shall use the standards established by the Florida Library Association. 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 4, 4-2-90)  
Sec. 7.40. - Credits to the fair share library fee. 
(a)  Where the person initiating the land development has entered into an agreement with the city to dedicate land, books, periodicals or video tapes or to construct a library facility, the city manager shall grant a credit against any fair share library fee imposed by this division upon any new residential land development activity placing a demand on the city's library facilities in an amount equal to the dollar value of the capital or resource improvements. No credit shall exceed the fair share library fee imposed by this division for the proposed land development activity. 
(b)  The determination of the credit shall be undertaken through the submission of a proposed credit agreement to the city manager, which agreement shall include the following information: 
(1)  The proposed donation of land, books, periodicals or video tapes or the proposed plan of specific library space improvements; and 
(2)  The projected dollar value for the suggested donations or improvements, which shall be based on local information of similar land, books, periodicals, video tapes or space improvements and may be determined by an appraisal if appropriate. 
(c)  The proposed credit agreement shall be prepared by qualified professionals in the fields of planning, impact analysis, economics and library capital facility and resource standards. 
(d)  Within thirty (30) days of receipt of the proposed credit agreement, the city manager, after consulting the appropriate staff members, shall determine if the proposal is complete. If it is determined that the proposed credit agreement is not complete, the city manager shall send a written statement to the applicant outlining the deficiencies. The city manager shall take no further action on the proposed credit agreement until all deficiencies have been corrected or otherwise settled. 
(e)  Once the city manager determines the credit agreement is complete, he shall review it within thirty (30) days and shall, after consulting the appropriate staff members, approve the proposed credit agreement, if it is determined that the proposed donation or space improvement is consistent with the standards established by the Florida Library Association as well as compatible with the capital resource improvements outlined in the annual budget and capital improvements program and the proposed valuation of the donation or space improvement, as determined by an appraisal, if appropriate, is professionally acceptable. If the city manager determines that either the proposed donation or space improvement is not compatible with the standards established by the Florida Library Association or is not consistent with the annual budget and capital improvements program, he shall deny the credit agreement, and the applicant shall pay the fair share library fee. 
(f)  If the proposed credit agreement is approved by the city manager, a credit agreement shall be prepared and signed by the applicant and the city. It shall specifically outline the donation or space improvement that will be made by the applicant and the dollar credit the applicant shall receive for the donation or space improvement. 
(g)  Any person may appeal the city manager's decision on any credit agreement he submits by filing a petition with the city commission within thirty (30) days of a decision by the city manager. In reviewing the city manager's decision, the city commission shall use the standards established by the Florida Library Association and the library capital and resource improvements outlined in the annual budget and capital improvements program. 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 5, 4-2-90)  
Sec. 7.41. - Review of fee schedule. 
Prior to the adoption of the annual budget and capital improvements program, the city commission shall receive a report from the city manager reviewing the fair share library fee schedule in section 7.39 and any recommended changes in the fee schedule. Changes in the schedule should be based on any revisions to the population projections, projections of new residential units, library costs, inflation and other relevant factors. 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 6, 4-2-90)  
Sec. 7.42. - Use of funds collected and trust funds. 
(a)  Establishment of fair share library trust fund. There is hereby established the fair share library fund (trust fund) for the purpose of ensuring that the fees collected pursuant to this division are appropriately earmarked and spent for the capital and resource expansion of the city's library facilities in accordance with the standards established by the Florida Library Association. 
(b)  Payment of fair share fees into trust fund. Fair share library fees collected pursuant to this division shall be paid into the trust fund. 
(c)  Expenditure of fair share fees in trust fund. 
(1)  Proceeds from the trust fund shall be used exclusively for capital and resource expansion of the city's library facilities in a manner consistent with the annual budget and capital improvements program. 
(2)  Any funds in the trust fund on deposit, not immediately necessary for expenditure, shall be invested in interest-bearing assets. All income derived from these investments shall be retained in the applicable trust account. These monies shall be utilized for the capital and resource expansion of the city's library facilities in a manner consistent with the annual budget and capital improvements program. 
(3)  Each year, at the time the annual city budget and capital improvements program are reviewed, the city manager shall propose appropriations to be spent from the trust fund. The proceeds shall be spent for library capital and resource improvements consistent with the capital improvements program and the standards established by the Florida Library Association. Any amounts not appropriated from the trust fund, together with any interest earnings, shall be carried over in the specific trust account to the following fiscal period. 
(d)  Refund of fair share fees not encumbered for city library facilities. 
(1)  Any fair share library fees collected shall be returned to the fee payer if the fees have not been spent or encumbered within ten (10) years from the date the fees were paid. Fair share library fees collected shall be deemed to be spent (encumbered) on the basis of the first fee collected shall be the first fee spent for library improvements. 
(2)  Any fair share library fees collected shall be returned to the fee payer if the land development activity is cancelled due to noncommencement and if the fees have not been spent or encumbered. Fair share library fees collected shall be deemed to be spent (encumbered) on the basis of the first fee collected shall be the first fee spent for library improvements. 
(3)  The refund of fair share library fees shall be undertaken through the submission of a refund application, to be submitted within six (6) months following the end of the tenth year from the date on which the fair share library fee was paid or within one (1) month of noncommencement. The refund application shall include the following information: 
a.  A notarized sworn statement that the fee payer paid the fair share library fee for the property and the amount paid; and 
b.  A copy of the receipt issued by the city for payment of the fee. 
(4)  Within thirty (30) days of receipt of the refund application, the city manager shall determine if it is complete. If the city manager determines the application is not complete, he shall send a written statement specifying the deficiencies by mail to the person submitting the application. Unless the deficiencies are corrected, the city manager shall take no further action on the refund application. 
(5)  When the city manager determines the refund application is complete, he shall review it within thirty (30) days and shall approve the proposed refund if he determines the fee payer has paid a fair share library fee which the city has not spent or encumbered within ten (10) years from the date the fees were paid or within one (1) month of noncommencement. 
(6)  Any fee payer may appeal the city manager's decision on a refund application by filing a petition with the city commission within thirty (30) days of a decision by the city manager. In reviewing the city manager's decision, the city commission shall use the standards established in this section of this division. 
(7)  If no application is received by the city pursuant to this section within ninety (90) days of the date such application could be made, the right to make such application shall terminate. 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 7, 4-2-90)  
Sec. 7.43. - Exemptions. 
The following new land development activities shall be exempted from payment of the fair share library fee: 
(1)  Alteration or expansion of an existing dwelling unit where no additional units are created and the use is not changed. 
(2)  The construction of accessory buildings or structures which are not dwelling units and which do not constitute an increase in intensity of use. 
(3)  The replacement of a destroyed or partially destroyed building or structure with a new building of the same size and use. 
(4)  The construction of any publicly owned governmental buildings. 
(Ord. No. 90-05, § 8, 4-2-90)  
Chapter 8 - FIRE PROTECTION AND PREVENTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; code enforcement board, § 2.10.01 et seq.; building and property maintenance regulations, Ch. 5; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20; subdivisions, Ch. 21; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 23; yacht basin, Ch. 25; zoning, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Fire prevention and control, F.S. § 633.01 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 8.01. - Statewide fire codes adopted. 
(a)  The Florida Fire Prevention Code and Life Safety Code as promulgated by the Florida Building Commission, as amended by the county construction licensing board and/or the Florida Building Commission, shall be the fire codes for the city. 
These codes are intended to be used in conjunction with other existing codes and ordinances adopted by the city, and nothing contained herein shall be deemed to invalidate such other codes and ordinances. In the event of a conflict between these codes and other codes or ordinances adopted by the city, the stricter provisions shall apply. 
(b)  A copy of the codes shall be maintained in the office of the city clerk and are hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as if set out at length herein and shall be controlling within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1970, § 8-1; Ord. No. 89-30, § 1, 9-5-89; Ord. No. 95-17, § 1, 3-20-95; Ord. No. 98-26, § 1, 9-21-98; Ord. No. 2001-28, § 14, 1-7-2002)  
Sec. 8.02. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2003-04, § 1, adopted Apr. 7, 2003, repealed § 8.02, which pertained to adequate access and derived from Code 1970, § 8-2(A)(7).  
Sec. 8.03. - Inspections. 
The fire prevention division shall make periodic inspections of all buildings or structures and is empowered to issue citations for violations. Wherein there is a conflict between the terms and provisions of the code as published and the requirements for fire protection above set out, then the requirements for fire protection shall prevail. 
(Code 1970, § 8-2(C)  
Secs. 8.04, 8.05. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2001-28, § 15, adopted Jan. 7, 2002, deleted §§ 8.04, 8.05 which pertained to fire district established and types of construction permitted, respectively and derived from Code 1970, §§ 8-7, 8-8; Ord. No. 80-28, §§ 1, 2, adopted July 7, 1980; Ord. No. 95-17, §§ 2, 3, adopted Mar. 20, 1995.

ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC SAFETY BUILDING CONSTRUCTION FEE 
 
Sec. 8.18. - Imposed. 
All new construction in the city shall pay a public safety building construction fee. 
(Ord. No. 80-46, § 1, 11-3-80)  
Sec. 8.19. - Rates. 
Every firm or person constructing dwellings, commercial, manufacturing or public assembly units, himself or by independent contractor, shall pay to the city, in advance, the following: 
(1)  Dwelling units. Three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) per unit; 
(2)  Commercial. Four hundred seventy-five dollars ($475.00) per unit or per five thousand (5,000) square feet, whichever is greater; 
(3)  Industrial/warehousing. Four hundred seventy-five dollars ($475.00) per unit or per four thousand (4,000) square feet, whichever is greater; 
(4)  Public assembly/institutional units. Four hundred seventy-five dollars ($475.00) per unit or per two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. No. 80-46, § 1, 11-3-80; Ord. No. 85-28, § 1, 7-1-85)  
Sec. 8.20. - Payment before permit issued. 
No permits shall be issued prior to payment of this fee. Refunds for payment made will be allowed upon application when it is determined that the unit has not been established or constructed. 
(Ord. No. 80-46, § 1, 11-3-80)  
Sec. 8.21. - Use of proceeds. 
The proceeds accumulated by reason of the establishment of the public safety building or construction fee shall be used only for public safety related capital improvements limited to facilities, vehicles, and equipment for firefighting and fire protection services and for emergency medical services. 
(Ord. No. 80-46, § 1, 11-3-80)  
Sec. 8.22. - Trust fund. 
All public safety building construction fees shall be deposited in an appropriate trust fund, to be held in separate accounts and used only for the purposes referred to in section 8.21. Funds may be disbursed from these accounts in the customary manner in accordance with appropriate law with the added requirement that such disbursement of funds shall require the approval of the city manager. Any funds on deposit in the trust fund which are not immediately necessary for expenditure may be invested by the city and all income derived from such investments shall be deposited in the trust fund hereby established. 
(Ord. No. 80-46, § 1, 11-3-80)

ARTICLE VI. - FALSE ALARMS 
 
Sec. 8.30. - Use of fire alarm system. 
Every person making use of any fire alarm system within the city shall be responsible for the proper maintenance, adjustment and usage of such system. For the purpose of this section, a fire alarm shall mean any device or system for the detection and notification of the presence of flame, heat or smoke, or any combination of such devices or systems. Each fire alarm system shall comply with all fire and building codes in effect at the time of installation and with codes as may be thereafter amended from time to time. As used in this article, the phrase "every person making use of any fire alarm system" is defined as the owner or owners of any residential, commercial, industrial, storage, assembly, educational, correctional, mercantile, detention or health care building, whether absent or not, any tenant, manager, administrator, or other person regularly in charge whether any of the aforementioned are present on the premises or not at the time of the alarm. 
(Ord. No. 84-63, § 1, 1-21-85)  
Sec. 8.31. - Fake alarm prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deliberately cause such system to give a false alarm, which, for the purposes of this section, shall be defined as any false information, alarm, indication or report that a fire is in progress. No person shall be charged with an offense under this article for a false alarm sounded under a reasonable mistake that a fire was in progress. 
(Ord. No. 84-63, § 1, 1-21-85)  
Sec. 8.32. - Corrective action required to prevent improper operation of fire alarm system. 
Where a fire alarm system has previously caused a fire alarm, it shall be unlawful for any person making use of the system to fail to take appropriate corrective action to prevent further improper operation of the system. It shall be presumed that a system caused a false alarm when the alarm is not the result of an actual fire. The presumption shall not apply when the alarm is caused by a malfunction or a disturbance of any public or private utility servicing said system. 
(Ord. No. 84-63, § 1, 1-21-85)  
Sec. 8.33. - Failure to take appropriate corrective action. 
It shall be presumed that a person failed to take appropriate corrective action to prevent improper operation of a fire alarm system where it is shown that the person, after being notified of a false alarm having occurred, allows or causes a subsequent false alarm within seventy-two (72) hours of the date and time of such notification. 
(Ord. No. 84-63, § 1, 1-21-85)  
Sec. 8.34. - Notification forms and procedures. 
The fire chief is hereby authorized and directed to establish official notification forms and procedures to carry out the notification requirements of the article. 
(Ord. No. 84-63, § 1, 1-21-85)  
Sec. 8.35. - Unlawful testing of fire alarm system.
