(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 98-16, § 1, 7-6-98; Ord. No. 2001-25, § 1, 2, 10-1-2001; Ord. No. 2002-08, §§ 1, 2, 3-18-2002; Ord. No. 2006-04, §§ 1—5, 2-6-2006; Ord. No. 2006-14, § 1, 10-3-2006; Ord. No. 2008-27, § 1, 12-15-2008; Ord. No. 2017-20, §§ 8—11, 6-8-2017)  
Sec. 10.08. - Disposal of certain materials by owner. 
(a)  The service charges referred to in this chapter shall apply only for the collection of garbage and yard waste, as defined herein, and the city shall not collect waste materials defined herein as including general "refuse building materials usually left over from a construction or remodeling project" and also trees, tree limbs, tree trunks and tree stumps. It is the responsibility of all tree surgeons, nurseries, lawn care services and landscaping contractors, general contractors, or any individual or company doing work on private property, to remove from the premises all such residue, rubbish, and/or waste resulting from said work. These above-mentioned items shall be disposed of by the owner or contractor at their sole expense. 
(b)  All construction sites shall be provided with a commercial container(s), the number and size to be determined by the city building official. Construction sites shall be kept clean and orderly at all times, and the city building official may suspend or red-tag a construction job until the premises are brought up to a satisfactory sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 2017-20, § 12, 6-8-2017)  
Sec. 10.09. - Special arrangements for the impaired or disabled. 
All garbage, trash and yard waste shall be placed at curbside for collection in accordance with section 10.05. In cases whereby the owner or person in charge is incapacitated due to injury, disability or age, such individuals may submit a request in writing to the public works department for special arrangements for collection. Such request shall be subject to approval by the public works director or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 9-18-95)  
Sec. 10.10. - Provision of services within city. 
The city shall have the exclusive right to provide sanitation services within the municipal limits of the city. Individuals or establishments requiring specialized services not provided by the city shall request approval for such services through the public works director and/or his/her designee. Entities providing such collection services must execute an agreement with the city prior to commencing service. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 9-18-95)  
Sec. 10.11. - Service outside city. 
There will be no garbage and trash collection service provided outside of the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 9-18-95)  
Sec. 10.12. - Billing. 
(a)  The monthly charges provided for in section 10.07 shall be billed and collected with the monthly utility bill issued by the city. Garbage collection charges shall be itemized separately on such statement. 
(b)  Garbage collection charges provided for herein shall be payable within twenty (20) days after the original date of billing, or such collection service shall be discontinued until all such charges shall be paid in full. 
(c)  The monthly garbage collection charges, as set forth, shall initially become due upon final inspection and approval of the facility by the building official, issuance of a certificate of occupancy, or occupancy, whichever shall first occur, and shall remain in effect thereafter. 
(d)  If garbage collection charges shall be in arrears, all utilities served to the delinquent customer shall be immediately shut off and discontinued until such arrearage becomes current. In addition, the city may collect such arrearage pursuant to the enforcement provisions as provided in the utilities chapter of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 9-18-95)  
Sec. 10.13. - Violations. 
Any person or entity violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, penalty or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation, including reasonable attorney fees for defending or prosecuting any action with regard to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 9-18-95)  
Sec. 10.14. - Contract for garbage and yard waste services with owner of property; city may bill tenant. 
The city shall contract only with the owner of the property for garbage and yard waste collection services to be furnished to the property and the fees therefor are chargeable to the property owner. The city may bill the tenant or occupant of the premises for the garbage and trash collection service charges at the express request of the owner, but this shall in no way relieve the owner of responsibility for payment. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 9-18-95)  
Sec. 10.15. - Sanitation impact fees. 
(a)  Residential. A sanitation impact fee of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) shall be paid at the time of issuance of a building permit for construction of any dwelling within the city. There shall be no distinction made as to single-family dwelling units or multifamily dwelling units. 
(b)  Commercial/industrial/institutional. A sanitation impact fee shall be paid upon the issuance of a building permit for any commercial, industrial, or institutional development at the rate of four hundred sixty dollars ($460.00) for all development up to and including five thousand (5,000) square feet and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each additional one thousand (1,000) square feet or portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 95-42, § 1, 9-18-95)  
Chapter 11 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Animals, Ch. 4; building and property maintenance regulations, Ch. 5; flood prevention and control, Ch. 9; garbage and refuse, Ch. 10; junked, abandoned or wrecked property, Ch. 12; parks and recreation, Ch. 16; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20; subdivisions, Ch. 21; utilities, Ch. 24; yacht basins, Ch. 25; zoning, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Authority to enact health regulations not inconsistent with state public health laws and rules and regulations of Department of Health and Rehabilitation Services, F.S. § 381.101; enforcement, F.S. § 381.121. 
 
Sec. 11.01. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 1 of Ord. No. 98-10, adopted April 20, 1998, repealed § 11.01 in its entirety. Formerly, § 11.01 pertained to adoption of the sanitary code and derived from § 10-1 of the 1970 Code.  
Sec. 11.02. - Sanitary facilities required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to live in, own, lease, maintain or control any temporary or permanent quarters, either stationary or mobile, within the territorial limits of the city without having, providing, and maintaining adequate sanitary facilities. 
(b)  Adequate sanitary facilities may be defined as the provision of potable water, the sanitary disposal of sewer and the disposal of solid waste in accordance with all applicable city, county, state and federal guidelines. 
(Code 1970, § 10-2; Ord. No. 95-09, § 1, 2-20-95) 
Cross reference— Plumbing code, § 5.11 et seq.; water and sewer department, Ch. 24.  
Sec. 11.03. - Hurricane precautions. 
Upon the issuance of an advisory by the U.S. Weather Bureau alerting the Pinellas County area to a hurricane condition, every owner or owners of any lot, tract, or parcel of land, occupied as well as unoccupied, within the city shall securely tie down all loose lumber, trash, and other materials located on his property. 
(Code 1970, § 10-3)  
Chapter 14 - LOCAL BUSINESS TAX RECEIPTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; code enforcement board, § 2.10.01 et seq.; finance, Ch. 7; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 17; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20; taxation, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference— Local occupational license taxes, F.S. Ch. 205; regulatory fees, F.S. § 166.221. 
 
Sec. 14.01. - Levy. 
A local business tax for the privilege of engaging in or managing any business, profession, or occupation in the city is hereby levied. Such local business tax shall be levied on: 
(1)  Any person who maintains a permanent business location or branch office within the city for the privilege of engaging in or managing any business; 
(2)  Any person who maintains a permanent business location or branch office within the city for the privilege of engaging in or managing any profession or occupation; 
(3)  Any person who does not qualify under the provisions of subsection (1) or subsection (2) and who transacts any business or engages in any occupation or profession in interstate commerce, if such business tax is not prohibited by s. [Section] 8 of Art. I of the United States Constitution. 
(Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.02. - Required. 
No person shall engage in or manage the profession, business or occupation hereinafter named within the city unless a city license shall be issued to each person on receipt of the amount hereinafter stated. 
(Code 1970, § 14-2; Ord. No. 98-22, § 1, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.03. - Persons subject to business tax. 
For the purposes of this chapter any person, holding himself out to the public, at a given location, by sign, printed matter, classified section, telephone directory, or city directory, or otherwise as being engaged in business, or as offering services or property to the public, regardless of whether such person actually transacts any business, or practices a profession, shall be considered as engaging in business and shall be liable for an local business tax therefor. 
(Code 1970, § 14-1; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.04. - Dates due and delinquent; penalties. 
(a)  All receipts shall be sold by the appropriate tax collector beginning July 1 of each year, are due and payable on or before September 30 of each year, and expire on September 30 of the succeeding year. If September 30 falls on a weekend or holiday, the tax is due and payable on or before the first working day following September 30. Receipts that are not renewed when due and payable are delinquent and subject to a delinquency penalty of ten (10) percent for the month of October, plus an additional five-percent penalty for each subsequent month of delinquency, until paid. However, the total delinquency penalty may not exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the business tax receipt for the delinquent establishment. 
(b)  The receipt shall be obtained prior to the commencement of the business or the practice of the profession. 
(c)  Any person engaging in or managing any business, occupation, or profession without first obtaining a local business tax receipt, if required hereunder, shall be subject to a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of the receipt determined to be due, in addition to any other penalty provided by law or ordinance. 
(d)  Any person who engages in any business, occupation or profession covered by this chapter who does not pay the required local business tax receipt within one hundred fifty (150) days after the initial notice of tax due, and who does not obtain the required local business tax receipt, is subject to civil actions and penalties, including court costs, reasonable attorneys' fees, additional administrative costs incurred as a result of collection efforts, and a penalty of up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(e)  No receipt shall be issued unless the federal employer identification number or Social Security number is obtained from the person to be licensed. 
(Code 1970, § 14-1; Ord. No. 95-39, § 1, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 2018-16, § 2, 9-17-2018)  
Sec. 14.05. - Subcontractors. 
For purpose of enforcement and construction of this chapter the requirement of a receipt shall not apply solely to contractors or superintendents on the job or undertaking, but shall extend to subcontractors or employees not regularly employed by a firm or person licensed by the city. 
(Code 1970, § 14-3; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.06. - Separate receipt for each category. 
Each applicant shall be required to procure a separate receipt for each category which applies to his activities. 
(Code 1970, § 14-4; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.07. - Term of receipt; half-year receipt. 
(a)  All business taxes imposed by this chapter shall be due and payable on the first day of October of each year. 
(b)  Provided however, that on and after April 1 of each year, a one-half-year receipt may be issued upon the collection of a business tax in the amount of one-half (½) of the annual business tax. 
(Code 1970, § 14-5; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.08. - Prosecution of violators; penalty. 
(a)  Should any person fail or refuse to pay the business tax, the city shall initiate code enforcement action in accordance with section 2.10.06 of the City Code, or any other appropriate means allowed by law. 
(b)  Any person who shall carry on or conduct any business, occupation or profession for which a receipt is hereby required, without first obtaining such receipt, shall, upon issuance of an order by the city code enforcement board, be punished as provided by section 14.04, or section 2.10.09 as applicable. 
(Code 1970, § 14-6; Ord. No. 95-39, § 2, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.09. - Revocation of receipt. 
The right to revoke any receipt issued under the provisions of this chapter, for cause, which shall be deemed to include any violation of the zoning ordinances of the city is reserved to the city and the revocation shall be made at the direction of the commission. 
(Code 1970, § 14-7; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.10. - When certificate required. 
No receipt shall be issued to any person otherwise required by ordinance of the city or by state law to have a certificate of competency or to have passed an examination before engaging in a business or profession in the city, until such person shall have exhibited to the city manager or city clerk proof of having a valid certificate or of having passed the examination. 
(Code 1970, § 14-8; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.11. - State license required. 
(a)  [New local business tax receipts.] Any person applying for a new local business tax receipt to practice any profession regulated by the department of professional regulation, or any board or commission thereof, must exhibit an active state certificate, registration, or license, or proof of copy of the same, before such local business tax receipt may be issued. 
(b)  Pharmacies and pharmacists. No business tax receipt shall be issued to operate a pharmacy unless the applicant shall first exhibit a current permit issued by the board of pharmacy; however, no such business tax receipt shall be required in order to practice the profession of pharmacy. 
(c)  Adult congregate living facilities. No business tax receipt for the operation of an adult congregate living facility, pursuant to part III of chapter 400 [Florida Statutes], shall be issued without first ascertaining that the applicant has been licensed by the department of health and rehabilitative services to operate such a facility at the specified location or locations. 
(d)  Pest control business. No business tax receipt shall be issued to any pest control business coming under chapter 482 [Florida Statutes], unless a current license has been procured from the department of agriculture and consumer service for each of its locations in the city. Upon presentation of the requisite licenses from the department and the required fee, a business tax receipt shall be issued. 
(e)  Health studios. No business tax receipt shall be issued or renewed for the operation of a health studio pursuant to [Florida Statutes] sections 501.012 through 501.019 or ballroom dance studio pursuant to [Florida Statutes] section 501.143, unless such business exhibits a current license, registration or letter of exemption from the department of agriculture and consumer services. 
(f)  Sellers of travel. No business tax receipt shall be issued or renewed to engage in businesses as a seller of travel pursuant to [Florida Statutes] section 559.927, unless such business exhibits a registration or letter of exemption from the department of agriculture and consumer services. 
(g)  Telemarketing businesses. No business tax receipt shall be issued or renewed for the operation of a telemarketing business under [Florida Statutes] sections 501.604 and 501.608, unless such business exhibits a current license or registration from the department of agriculture and consumer services, or a current affidavit of exemption. 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 3, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007) 
State Law reference— State certificate of competency or license required prior to issuing occupational license, F.S. §§ 205.195, 205.196, 205.197, 205.198 and 205.199.  
Sec. 14.12. - Adoption of statutes. 
There is hereby adopted, by reference, the provisions of Chapter 205, Florida Statutes pertaining to local business taxes. 
(Code 1970, § 14-89; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)

Sec. 14.14. - Special receipt categories. 
Should any person, firm or corporation required to have an business tax receipt fail to be reasonably described in any of the above and foregoing enumerated categories then in such event, the city manager shall upon investigation determine the nearest category specified which would be comparable to the occupation of the applicant and shall assess and collect such prescribed receipt fee from the applicant. 
(Code 1970, § 14-12(a); Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.15. - Receipt category appeal. 
Should any person, firm or corporation herein or hereby required to have an business tax receipt feel aggrieved by the ruling of the city manager in regard to the assignment of a receipt category then such person shall file a written protest with the city clerk whereupon such matter will be heard by the commission at its next ensuing regular meeting at which time the aggrieved person may be heard personally or through counsel and a final determination of such protest speedily determined. 
(Code 1970, § 14-12(c); Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.16. - Religious, charitable, educational, institutional, veterans, spouses of veterans and certain service members, and low-income persons exemptions; waiver. 
(a)  Religious tenets; exemption. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to require a receipt for practicing the religious tenets of any church. 
(b)  Charitable, etc., organizations; occasional sales, fund raising; exemption. No business tax receipt shall be required of any charitable, religious, fraternal, youth, civic, service, or other such organization when the organization makes occasional sales or engages in fund-raising projects when the projects are performed exclusively by the members thereof and when the proceeds derived from the activities are used exclusively in the charitable, religious, fraternal, youth, civic, and service activities of the organization. 
(c)  Upon written application on a form to be provided by the city manager, charitable, educational, religious, literary, scientific or other similar organizations, persons or groups may obtain a waiver as to the necessity of obtaining a business tax receipt which would otherwise be required by this chapter; such waiver to be granted in the following manner: 
(1)  The city manager shall determine that the applicant is, in fact, a nonprofit entity for religious, literary, scientific, charitable or educational purposes. In making such determination, the city manager shall be guided by the history of the applicant, its tax-exempt status, the affirmation of the applicant as to how any funds derived shall be used to accomplish the charitable purpose, and the criterion as set forth in F.S. § 205.022(6). 
(2)  If, in the fact, the city manager determines that the applicant is a nonprofit entity and that the funds derived from this trade, business or event shall be used for charitable purposes, then he may attach his certification to this application and waive the requisite receipt fee; except, however, when the application reveals the request: 
a.  For the use of publicly owned property such as but not limited to streets, parks or public buildings; or, 
b.  That the applicant desires to use, conduct or sponsor a circus, carnival or similar type of amusement organization or professional amusement persons. 
Either of these instances will require an action by the commission before a waiver shall be granted for the business tax receipt fee. 
(3)  As a prerequisite to any hearing by the commission, there shall be a certificate from the city manager certifying the nonprofit entities' charitable purpose; and if the application is of the type described in paragraph (c)(2)b. above, documentation shall accompany the application (either an executed contract or an affidavit by the applicant) demonstrating that an amount of not less than fifty (50) percent of the net profits earned from such circus, carnival or other similar type of amusement shall be used by the applicant to accomplish its charitable purpose. 
(d)  Pursuant to F.S. § 205.055, the following persons are entitled to an exemption from the local business tax and any fees imposed under this chapter: 
(1)  A veteran of the United States Armed Forces who was honorably discharged upon separation from service, or the spouse or unremarried surviving spouse of such a veteran; 
(2)  The spouse of an active duty military servicemember who has relocated to the county or municipality pursuant to a permanent change of station order; 
(3)  A person who is receiving public assistance as defined in F.S. § 409.2554; or 
(4)  A person whose household income is below 130 percent of the federal poverty level based on the current year's federal poverty guidelines. 
(e)  To be eligible for the exemption in subsection (d) above, a person must complete and sign, under penalty of perjury, a "Request for Fee Exemption" to be furnished by the city and provide written documentation in support of his or her request for an exemption under subsection (d). 
(f)  If a person who is exempt under this subsection (d) owns a majority interest in a business with fewer than 100 employees, the business is exempt. Such person must complete and sign, under penalty of perjury, a "Request for Fee Exemption" to be furnished by the city and provide written documentation in support of his or her request for an exemption for the business under subsection (d). 
(Code 1970, § 14-12(b); Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 2018-16, § 3, 9-17-2018)  
Sec. 14.17. - Registration of receipt issued by another jurisdiction. 
(a)  If any person, firm or corporation, required under the terms of the Code to have a business tax receipt, is in possession of a valid or current business tax receipt from any other municipality within Pinellas County, or has its primary office located within an unincorporated area of Pinellas County, the receipt shall be recognized by the clerk and shall be registered with the city. 
(b)  Upon presentation of the valid business tax receipt from another municipality, together with a registration fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), the city shall issue a registration of receipt. 
(c)  Any person engaging in or managing a business, profession or occupation regulated by the department of professional regulation, which has paid an local business tax to the local government where the permanent business is located or branch office maintained, shall not be required to pay the registration fee mentioned in section 14.17(b). 
(Code 1970, § 14-13; Ord. No. 82-28, § 1, 10-18-82; Ord. No. 89-44, § 1, 12-4-89; Ord. No. 93-24, § 1, 8-16-93; Ord. No. 95-39, § 5, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 2004-01, § 1, 1-20-2004; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.18. - Business tax receipt transfer. 
(a)  Any business tax receipt may be transferred to a new owner, when there is a bona fide sale of the business, upon payment of a transfer fee of up to ten (10) percent of the annual local business tax, but not less than three dollars ($3.00) nor more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00), and presentation of the original receipt and evidence of the sale. 
(b)  Upon written request and presentation of the original receipt, any receipt may be transferred from one location to another location in the same municipality upon payment of a transfer fee of up to ten (10) percent of the annual business tax, but not less than three dollars ($3.00) nor more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 95-39, § 6, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 2, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 14.19. - Proof of insurance required for tree service companies. 
No business tax receipt, or any renewal of any business tax receipt, shall be issued to any tree trimming service company or other persons who are employed, contracted or paid to perform tree trimming and/or maintenance within the city limits unless said entity, employee, contractor, or subcontractor has valid workers compensation insurance pursuant to F.S. ch. 440, and a minimum of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) general liability insurance of the type that allows tree work to be performed at heights greater than twelve (12) feet. 
(Ord. No. 2010-18, § 4, 2-7-2011)  
Chapter 15 - OFFENSES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Case Law reference— A municipality may enact an ordinance creating an offense against municipal law for the same act constitutes an offense in state law. Jaramillo v. City of Homestead, 322 So.2d 496 (1975). 
A municipality by ordinance may adopt state misdemeanor statutes by specific or general reference. 
Adoption of state law misdemeanors by reference includes laws both in existence at the time and those later adopted by the state legislature. State v. Smith, 189 So.2d 846. 
Cross reference— General penalty, § 1.12; administration, Ch. 2; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals, Ch. 4; building and property maintenance regulations, Ch. 5; fire protection and prevention, Ch. 8; flood prevention and control, Ch. 9; garbage and refuse, Ch. 10; health and sanitation, Ch. 11; junked, abandoned or wrecked property, Ch. 12; parks and recreation, Ch. 16; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 23; utilities, Ch. 24; yacht basins, Ch. 25; zoning, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Fines and forfeitures in County Court payable to municipality, F.S. § 34.191; punishment for misdemeanors, F.S. §§ 775.082, 775.083. 
 
Sec. 15.01. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 95-10, § 1, adopted February 20, 1995, repealed § 15.01 in its entirety. Formerly, § 15.01 pertained to adoption of state laws relating to misdemeanors and derived from § 15-1 of the 1970 Code.  
Sec. 15.02. - Advertising matter; attaching to or scattering on public or private property. 
No person within the city shall erect, fasten, attach, scatter or cast, in any way, any sign, showcard, poster or other advertising device or matter, except newspapers as defined by state statute, upon any public or private property within the city unless legally authorized to do so, by the city or the owner of such property. 
(Code 1970, § 15-2)  
Sec. 15.03. - Prohibited excessive or unnecessary noises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any loud and raucous noise, which term shall mean any sound which, because of its volume level, duration or character, annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, health, peace or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary sensibilities within the city limits. The term includes the kinds of noise generated by the activities enumerated in subsection (b), except as provided in subsection (d). 
(b)  The following specific acts and causes thereof are presumed to be in violation of subsection (a) and to constitute a loud and raucous noise. This enumeration does not constitute an exclusive list: 
(1)  Engine exhaust. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine or stationary internal combustion engine except through an operative and effective muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud and raucous noises therefrom. A muffler or other device shall be considered effective under this subsection if the muffler or other device is equal to or better than the original equipment manufacturer's specifications for preventing noise. 
(2)  Construction equipment. The operation between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on weekdays, between the hours of 6:00 pm and 8:30 am on Saturdays or at any time on Sunday, of construction equipment, including, but not limited to, any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, dredge, steam or electric hoist tractor, earth moving equipment or other construction equipment, the use of which is attended by loud and raucous noise. The operation of construction equipment prohibited during the above-stated times shall include pre-staging and set up of such equipment, and lining up vehicles with gross combination weight rating (GCWR) above 50,000 pounds, or powered industrial trucks, at or near the construction site. 
(3)  Blowers, etc. The operation of any blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes loud and raucous noise, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled or such engine is equipped with a muffler device which is operative and effective to prevent loud and raucous noise. 
(4)  Horns, signaling devices, etc. The sounding of any horn, whistle or other audible signaling device so as to create a loud and raucous noise. 
(5)  Entertainment noise. Entertainment as defined in section 271.00 of the Safety Harbor Comprehensive Zoning and Land Development Code performed outdoors between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. for the area of 2 nd Street N to 2 nd Street S, between 10 th Avenue and Bayshore Boulevard, including the land extending east from Bayshore Boulevard to Tampa Bay, and between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. at all other locations within the city. 
(6)  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, whistling or singing at any time or place so as to create a loud and raucous noise between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on any day. 
(7)  Animals, birds, etc. The keeping of any animal or bird which frequently or for continuous periods of time causes a loud and raucous noise on two (2) separate incidents of, at least, fifteen (15) minutes continuously within a fourteen-day period between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m.; or a single period of, at least, fifteen (15) minutes continuously between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(8)  Vehicles or vessels. The use or operation of any motor vehicle or vessel which produces loud, grating, grinding, rattling, irritating or other loud and raucous noise or which is not equipped with an effective motor sound suppression device equal to or better than the original manufacturer's specifications or is otherwise sufficient to prevent loud and raucous noise so as to prevent loud and raucous noise. 
(9)  Construction or repairing of buildings. The erection, including excavating, demolition, alteration or repair of any building so as to create a loud and raucous noise between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and safety and then only with permission from the building director. 
(10)  Noises heard within schools, public buildings, churches, [or] hospitals. The creation of any loud and raucous noise heard within any school, public building, church, or hospital, or the grounds thereof, while in use, which interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or annoys patients in the hospital. 
(11)  Noises to attract attention. The use of any drum or other instrument or device to create a loud and raucous noise. 
(12)  Machinery, etc. Sounds produced from machinery, manufacturing equipment, air conditioners, heating units, ventilators, or blower equipment at frequent or continuous periods of time which create a loud and raucous noise. 
(13)  Lawn maintenance equipment. Sounds produced from lawn maintenance equipment between the hours of sunset and 7:00 a.m. on any day so as to create a loud and raucous noise. 
(c)  Any person, owner, agent or supervisor in charge of operating, ordering, directing or allowing the operation or maintenance of a device or machine creating noise as prohibited in this section, any person who is in possession of any such device or machine, or any person who creates an unlawful noise as defined by this section shall be deemed guilty of violating this section. 
(d)  The term "loud and raucous noise" does not include noise or sound generated by the following: 
(1)  Cries for emergency assistance and warning calls. 
(2)  Radios, sirens, horns, and whistles on police, fire, ambulances and other emergency response vehicles. 
(3)  Parades, fireworks displays and other special events for which a permit has been obtained from the city, within such hours as may be imposed as a condition for the issuance of the permit. 
(4)  Activities on or in municipal and school athletic facilities and on or in publicly owned property and facilities, provided that such activities have been authorized by the owner of such property or facilities or its agent, including festivals, concerts, and athletic events. 
(5)  Emergency alarms, such as fire and burglar alarms, prior to the giving of notice and a reasonable opportunity for the owner or tenant in possession of the premises served by any such alarm to turn off the alarm. 
(6)  Religious worship activities, including, but not limited to, bells and organs. 
(7)  Locomotives and other railroad equipment, buses and aircraft. 
(8)  Public service vehicles, street sweeping machinery, buses or other vehicles, equipment, or machinery operated by employees of a county, city, or other public agency. 
(e)  Each violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a separate offense and shall subject the offender, upon conviction, to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a period not exceeding sixty (60) days, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(f)  Any violator of section 15.03(b)(2) shall be subject to a fine of $250.00 for the first offense, $500.00 for the second offense and $750.00 for the third offense. 
(g)  For purposes of this section, the following terms shall have the meanings prescribed below: 
(1)  "Motor boat," "personal water craft" or "vessel" shall have the meanings defined in F.S. § 327.02, paragraphs (11), (12), (16), (17), (22), (27) and (33). 
(2)  "Motor vehicle" shall have the meaning defined in F.S. § 320.01. 
(Code 1970, § 15-18; Ord. No. 96-28, § 1, 9-16-96; Ord. No. 2003-10, § 1, 4-21-2003; Ord. No. 2010-18, § 5, 2-7-2011; Ord. No. 2017-01, § 2, 3-20-2017; Ord. No. 2018-03, § 2, 4-2-2018; Ord. No. 2019-08, § 7, 8-5-2019)  
Sec. 15.04. - Signs and certain other property; injuring or removing. 
No person within the city shall tamper with, injure, deface, destroy, or remove any sign, notice, marker, fireplug, public telephone booth or the contents thereof, any part of the sewer or water system of the city or any part of any other utilities system or any other public property. 
(Code 1970, § 15-18; Ord. No. 95-10, §§ 2, 3, 2-20-95)  
Sec. 15.05. - Discharge of crossbows and other projectiles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or shoot any crossbow, slingshot, bow and arrow or boomerang within the city, except in defense of person or property. 
(Code 1970, § 15-24; Ord. No. 2011-11, § 1, 9-19-2011)  
Sec. 15.06. - Poles, extensions, and other post-like accessories on developed residential property. 
For all properties with single family detached, single family attached, or single family semi-detached dwellings, no pole, extension, or other post-like accessory which extends beyond the roofline of the primary structure may be equipped with an imaging device to record an image of privately owned real property or of the owner, tenant, occupant, invitee, or licensee of such property in areas in which a person is presumed to have a reasonable expectation of privacy without his or her written consent. For purposes of this section, a person is presumed to have a reasonable expectation of privacy on his or her privately owned real property if he or she is not observable by persons located at ground level in a place where they have a legal right to be, regardless of whether he or she is observable from the air with the use of such pole, extension, or other post-like accessory. For the purposes of this section, roofline is defined as the top edge of the roof or parapet, whichever forms the top line of the building silhouette when viewed from the ground level. 
(Ord. No. 2019-15, § 2, 9-3-2019)  
Chapter 16 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— General penalty, § 1.12; administration, Ch. 2; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals, Ch. 4; health and sanitation, Ch. 11; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 23; yacht basin, Ch. 25; zoning, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Recreation, F.S. Ch. 418. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, adopted Apr. 17, 1989, amended Art. I of this chapter in its entirety, in effect repealed former Art. I, §§ 16.01—16.09, and enacted similar new provisions in lieu thereof to read as herein set out. Formerly, Art. I pertained generally to park and recreational areas and derived from §§ 16-2—16-8 of the city's 1970 Code, as amended by Ord. No. 80-47, §§ 1, 2, adopted Nov. 3, 1980. 
 
Sec. 16.01. - Land designated as park and recreational areas. 
(a)  The following real property owned by the city, together with any vacated streets adjacent thereto, is hereby declared and designated as park and recreational property and dedicated to that purpose and use: 
(1)  Safety Harbor City Park (940 7th Street South). 
(2)  Bayview Park (329 Bayshore Drive). 
(3)  John Wilson Park (401 Main Street). 
(4)  Daisy Douglas Park (601 9th Avenue North). 
(5)  Bayshore Linear Park (Southeast side of Bayshore Boulevard). 
(6)  Safety Harbor Municipal Pier, Marina, and all adjacent municipal property. 
(7)  Church Street Park (Church Street and Phillippe Parkway). 
(8)  Marshall Street Park (500 Marshall Street). 
(9)  North City Park (2075 Swan Lane). 
(10)  Safety Harbor Community Center (650 9th Avenue South and adjacent property). 
(11)  Rigsby Recreation Center (605 2nd Street North and adjacent property). 
(12)  Safety Harbor Public Library (101 2nd Street North and adjacent property). 
(13)  Mease Area Park. 
(b)  The city may designate additional real property as park and recreational areas, either by resolution or by motion, and those areas and any other areas obtained by the city for park and recreation purposes shall be governed by the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89; Ord. No. 96-12, § 1, 3-18-96; Ord. No. 96-39, § 1, 12-2-96)  
Sec. 16.02. - Definition. 
Vehicle is defined to mean any wheeled conveyance (except a baby carriage or wheelchair) for the transportation of persons or materials, whether: 
(1)  Powered or drawn by a motor, such as an automobile, truck, motorcycle, scooter or moped; 
(2)  Animal-drawn, such as a wagon, carriage or cart; 
(3)  Self-propelled, such as a bicycle or tricycle; 
(4)  Any trailer in tow of any size, kind or description. 
Exception is made as to any recreational or park transportation service where specifically authorized by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.03. - Vehicle and bicycle laws. 
All applicable state vehicle and bicycle laws shall apply in and about park property, and in addition thereto, the following rules shall be applicable on roads and driveways within park property: 
(1)  No person shall ride, drive or propel any motorcycle, scooter, or similar vehicle on any but the regular roads within park property; 
(2)  No person shall park a vehicle any place on park property other than the designated areas or at designated times provided for that particular type of vehicle, unless directed otherwise by law enforcement officers, department employees or as authorized. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.04. - Domestic animals. 
(a)  Dogs and other pets will be excluded from any place where food and drinks are sold or consumed. 
(b)  All dogs shall at all times be restrained and on adequate leashes (not greater than six (6) feet in length). Persons bringing such animals shall clean up after their animal. Violators shall be subject to fine. 
(c)  In compliance with the regulations of the state board of health, all pets are excluded from all swimming areas and beaches. 
(d)  Seeing eye and guide dogs shall be excluded from these regulations concerning domestic animals and shall be permitted in all park areas and facilities. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.04.1. - Horseback riding. 
No person shall engage in horseback riding in any park or recreation area, other than those areas where provision for such is made by clearly marked bridle paths, trails, rings and other necessary features and then only upon thoroughly broken and properly restrained animals that are ridden with care, prevented from grazing, straying unattended, untethered to any rock, tree or shrub, and not ridden or led on any park land other than so designated. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.05. - Park hours. 
Except for unusual and unforeseeable emergencies, the park areas are to be open to the public every day of the year during the hours of daylight. The operating hours for each individual park shall be established by the director of leisure services and shall be posted therein for public information. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.06. - Projectiles. 
(a)  No person shall, without written authorization, at any time bring into or have in his possession or discharge anywhere any slingshot, bows and arrows, or any toy or instrument that discharges projectiles by air or elastic. 
(b)  Parents or guardians will be held strictly responsible and accountable for the actions of minors in regard to the prohibitions in the foregoing paragraphs. 
(c)  No unauthorized person shall carry, use or possess bows and arrows, slingshots, or boomerangs on or in any park area or property, except at and in accordance with the rules and regulations as a participant in a program sponsored by the department. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89; Ord. No. 2011-11, § 2, 9-19-2011)  
Sec. 16.06.1. - Alcohol, etc. 
(a)  The possession, sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages, liquor, beer, wine, and illegal drugs or narcotics of any form shall not be permitted in any city park. 
(b)  Upon advance application and for good cause shown, the city manager may exempt from the terms of this section any persons, organizations or city parks for such times and upon such conditions as may be set forth in the action granting such exemption. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.06.2. - Glass containers. 
No person shall carry, transport or cause to be transported any glassware, bottles or other potentially dangerous or sharp objects into any park or beach, bathing, wading or swimming pool areas. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.07. - Recreation activities; rules and regulations. 
It is the responsibility of each person to conduct recreational activities in such a manner so as to prevent injury or loss of life to any person. Therefore, it is necessary to prescribe rules and regulations to govern recreational activities in the park areas and on public bathing beaches as follows: 
(1)  Use of park facilities is governed by the leisure services department. The leisure services department will determine the suitability of activities in a particular facility. Activities scheduled by the leisure services department receive priority. 
(2)  No person shall play golf or use golf balls and clubs within the park areas or on the public bathing beaches, except in areas set aside for that purpose. 
(3)  No person shall operate or permit to be operated any engine-driven model airplane within any park area or on the public bathing beaches, except in an area specifically designated by the director of leisure services as suitable for such activity. 
(4)  No person or persons shall engage in rough or potentially dangerous games, or practice for same, such as football, baseball, softball, horseshoes, tennis, volleyball, badminton or any other games, practices or exercise involving thrown or otherwise propelled objects such as balls, stones, arrows, javelins, shuttlecocks, frisbees, model aircraft or roller skates, except in the areas suitable for such activities. 
(5)  No person or persons shall use any motorized or manually operated skateboard, roller skates, in-line skates, scooter, bicycle, or any similar devise in any park area except in those areas approved by the city manager, or his or her designee. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89; Ord. No. 2001-20, § 1, 8-20-2001)  
Sec. 16.07.1. - Safety Harbor Municipal Pier; prohibited activities. 
The regulations contained in this chapter shall apply to activity on the municipal pier and, in addition, the following specific regulations shall be applied to the pier: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his or her possession, custody or control, any alcoholic beverage (including beer) of any kind whatsoever in an open container, or to consume same on the pier, marina, or adjacent municipal property. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to swim or bathe in the waters adjacent to the municipal pier or to dive from the pier into the adjacent waters. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to bring or harbor any animals on the municipal pier. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive a bicycle or motorized vehicle on the municipal pier. This restriction shall not apply to wheelchairs or other devices used to aid the disabled. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age to be or remain upon the municipal pier after 11:00 p.m. unless such person is accompanied by a parent or guardian or other person having custody of such minor. 
(Ord. No. 95-49, § 1, 12-18-95)  
Sec. 16.08. - Preservation of property. 
Regulation of conduct with respect to protection of park property to prevent damage, removal or destruction is necessary to preserve park and recreation areas for the use of future generations. 
(1)  As all property in all parks is city property, no unauthorized person shall willfully mark, deface or injure in any way, or displace, remove or tamper with any park building or building material, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, park signs, notices or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(2)  No unauthorized person shall remove from any park area any beach sand, whether submerged or not, or any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs, plants, seeds, flowers, fruits or nuts, down timber or other wood materials, or make any search, excavation by tool, equipment, metal detector, blasting or other means or agency, or construct or erect any buildings or structures of whatever kind, whether permanent or temporary in character, or run or string any public service utility into, upon or across such lands. 
(3)  Trees, shrubbery and lawns are property assets of the city, and no unauthorized person shall cut, carve or injure the bark, or break off limbs or branches or mutilate in any way, or pick the flowers, fruits, seeds or nuts of any tree or plant, nor shall any person dig in or otherwise disturb the grass areas, or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any area, nor shall any person pile debris or material of any kind on or about any tree or plant, or attach any item that could result in damage to any tree or plant, whether temporary or permanent in character or use. 
(4)  No unauthorized person shall transplant or remove any tree or plant or part thereof. 
(5)  No person shall tie any animal to any tree or plant. 
(6)  No person shall stand or sit on any structure not intended for such use in any park. 
(7)  No person shall bring in or dump, throw, place, deposit, cause to be thrown or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, decayed meat or animal matter of whatsoever nature or kind, fruit peelings, waste paper, shavings, buckets, rubber, rags, cloth or any other refuse or trash in or on a city park. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.08.1. - Protection and preservation of wildlife. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall molest, harm, frighten, kill, net, trap, snare, hunt, chase, shoot or throw or propel by any means missiles at any wildlife creature, be it mammal, aquatic or marine life, bird or reptile roaming free about the park or in captivity in a cage, nor shall any unauthorized person remove or possess the young of any wild animal or the nest or eggs of any reptile or bird or collect, remove or possess, give away, sell or offer to sell, buy or offer to buy, or accept as a gift any specimen, dead or alive. 
(b)  No unauthorized person shall place, dump, abandon or leave any fish, mammal, reptile or bird, either wild or domestic, on park property. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.08.2. - Miscellaneous. 
Parents or guardians, shall be held strictly responsible and accountable for the actions of minors in regard to this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
Sec. 16.09. - Enforcement of regulations and permits. 
All rules and regulations and permits contained in this article are enforceable by all law enforcement officers. Those properly designated park employees and city employees may warn participants of ordinance violations and report the same to the proper law enforcement officers for compliance. 
(Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 4-17-89)  
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Code of ethics for officers and employees, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; public records, F.S. § 119.01 et seq.; public meeting, F.S. § 286.011. 
 
Sec. 16.10. - Created. 
The commission hereby establishes a permanent advisory board to assist the commission which shall be named the Parks and Recreation Advisory Board. 
(Ord. No. 80-51, § 1, 12-15-80)  
Sec. 16.11. - Membership; terms. 
(a)  The board shall consist of five (5) regular members. 
(b)  In addition to the regular board members, the board shall consist of one (1) alternate member. The alternate shall serve a term consistent with the terms of the regular board members. If there is one (1) regular board member absent at any meeting of the board, the alternate will sit as a voting member of the board. If there are no regular board members absent at a meeting, the alternate member will sit as a nonvoting member, but will be allowed to participate in the discussion of the board. 
(c)  All terms shall be for two (2) years. 
(Ord. No. 80-51, § 2, 12-15-80; Ord. No. 93-04, § 1, 3-1-93; Ord. No. 93-15, § 1, 7-6-93; Ord. No. 93-20, § 1, 7-19-93; Ord. No. 96-09, § 1, 2-19-96; Ord. No. 2015-13, § 1, 5-18-2015)  
Sec. 16.12. - Qualifications; filling of vacancies. 
(a)  No member of the board shall be employed by or be an official of the city. 
(b)  In the event of resignation or death by a member prior to the expiration of his term, the commission shall select his replacement from a list of applicants submitted by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 80-51, § 3, 12-15-80)  
Sec. 16.13. - Organization; by-laws; quorum; meetings. 
(a)  Members of the board shall select from their own membership a chairman, vice chairman and secretary. The board shall organize itself as it deems proper in order to appropriately carry out the duties assigned to it, including the enactment of by-laws or rules of procedure, which shall be approved by resolution of the commission. 
(b)  A majority of the members of the board shall constitute a quorum necessary for the conduct of the business of the board. 
(c)  Meetings shall be held by the board not less often than once a month. Meetings shall be at the call of the chairman or, in his absence, the vice chairman, or at the call of any three (3) members of the board. 
(d)  The records and minutes of the deliberations and decisions of the board shall be kept and shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(e)  All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 80-51, § 4, 12-15-80)  
Sec. 16.14. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2015-13, § 2, adopted May 18, 2015, repealed § 16.14, which pertained to compensation; attendance and derived from Ord. No. 80-51, § 5, adopted Dec. 15, 1980.  
Sec. 16.15. - Duties. 
The primary duty of the board will be: 
(1)  To advise the commission and the staff of the city as to its interpretation of the community needs and desires as to types of leisure programs and facilities; 
(2)  To prepare and from time to time to amend and revise a general plan for meeting present and future leisure requirements of all areas of the city and for all of its citizens; 
(3)  To act as a liaison group and conduit of public opinion from the citizens of the city to the commission and to the city manager; 
(4)  To coordinate with the work of any single purpose committees dealing with a single purpose project or program; and 
(5)  To perform such other duties which may from time to time be requested of it by the commission or by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 80-51, § 6, 12-15-80)  
Chapter 17 - PEDDLERS, PANHANDLERS, SOLICITORS AND SECONDHAND SALES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2010-18, § 6, adopted Feb. 7, 2011, changed the title of ch. 17 from "peddlers and solicitors" to "peddlers, panhandlers, solicitors and secondhand sales." 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; local business tax receipts, Ch. 14; signs, Ch. 19; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference— Solicitations of funds, F.S. Ch. 496; peddlers at camp meetings, F.S. § 871.03. 
 
Sec. 17.01. - Definitions. 
The following words, when used in this chapter shall be construed to have the same meaning as hereinafter defined: 
Canvasser or solicitor is defined as any individual, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, vehicle or other conveyance, from place to place, taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise or personal property of any nature whatsoever, for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such person has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale, or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. Any person who, for himself, or for another person, hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure, car, room, shop or any other place within the city, for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. 
Estate sale means a sale within the city by a relative of a deceased resident or representative of the deceased resident of items belonging to such deceased resident which shall take place at the residential site of the deceased resident and is the final sale of items of the deceased resident due to the death of the resident. 
Garage sale means a sale by a resident within the city of secondhand items belonging to such resident for a period of more than six (6) months which shall take place at the residential site of the resident conducting the garage sale. 
Mobile vendor is an individual or group selling food other than fresh fruits or vegetables from a self-contained truck, trailer, or self-propelled conveyance, independent with respect to water, sewer and power utilities, capable of moving or being moved, used for the preparation and/or sale of food products and has been issued a valid, active food permit by the Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services and does not qualify as an accessory structure to an eating establishment under the Land Development Code. 
Panhandler means any solicitation made in person requesting an immediate donation of money or other thing of value for oneself or another person or entity. Purchase of an item for an amount far exceeding its value, under circumstances where a reasonable person would understand that the purchase is, in substance, a donation, is a donation for the purpose of this section. 
Peddler is defined to include any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, vehicle, or any other type of conveyance from place to place, carrying or transporting goods, wares and merchandise, offering and exposing the same for sale or making sales and delivering articles purchased, or who shall sell or offer for sale goods, wares and merchandise from his person or from any vehicle or conveyance, not including roadside vending. Any person who solicits orders and as a separate transaction, makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this chapter, shall be deemed a peddler, subject to the provisions of this chapter. The word peddler shall include the words hawker and huckster. 
Roadside vendor is an individual or group selling goods, wares and merchandise including, but not limited to, rugs, prepared foods, crafts, fresh fruits and vegetables from a location either adjacent to or within the right-of-way or from private property. 
(Code 1970, § 17-1; Ord. No. 2004-03, § 1, 1-20-2004; Ord. No. 2010-18, § 7, 2-7-2011; Ord. No. 2012-04, § 1, 3-5-2012)  
Sec. 17.02. - Permit required. 
It shall be unlawful for a peddler, solicitor or canvasser to engage in business within the city without first obtaining a permit, which shall be issued upon the payment of any license fee due by the applicant to the city. Roadside vendors are prohibited unless a temporary permit is obtained pursuant to the Safety Harbor Comprehensive Zoning and Land Development Code. Mobile vendors operating on private property with industrial or light industrial land uses from Monday through Friday during employee breaks and between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. are exempted from permitting. Mobile vendors may be permitted on private property as an accessory use to an establishment where beer and wine is legally sold for on-site consumption upon prior approval by the planning and zoning director and payment of the mobile vendor permit fee as described below. 
(1)  Conditions of approval. The planning and zoning director may only grant such approval if the mobile vendor is stationed in a rear yard or other approved location, no other mobile vendor is concurrently approved to operate on the requested property, and the mobile vendor only operates for a time period not to exceed five (5) consecutive hours, starting no earlier than 10:00 p.m. Monday through Thursday and from 3:00 p.m. until business closing time Friday through Sunday. 
(2)  Issuance of permit. The community development director shall specify the required conditions of approval in a written permit certificate that shall be valid for one (1) year from the date of issuance unless sooner suspended or revoked. Failure to abide by the conditions of approval in subsection (1) and any additional conditions included in the permit by the planning and zoning director shall be grounds for immediate suspension and/or revocation of the permit. 
(3)  Display of permit. The permit certificate shall be attached to the mobile vending vehicle or unit where it is readily visible. 
(4)  Permit fee. The mobile vendor permit fee shall be equivalent to the fee amount established under section 14.13(20)(a) for a restaurant with one (1) to ten (10) tables. 
(Code 1970, § 17-2; Ord. No. 2004-03, § 2, 1-20-2004; Ord. No. 2012-04, § 2, 3-5-2012; Ord. No. 2017-02, § 1, 3-6-2017)  
Sec. 17.03. - Application for permit. 
Applicants for permits shall file, in duplicate, with the city manager, a sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by the city manager, which shall give the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(2)  Address (permanent and local); 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods, wares, merchandise or services, if any are to be sold; 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(5)  The length of time for which the permit is desired, the place or places within the city from which the business is to be operated (if from a vehicle, a description of the same, together with license number or other means of identification); 
(6)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or the violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the evidence, and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
(7)  Credentials from the person or firm or corporation for which the applicant proposes to do business, authorizing the applicant to act as such representative. 
(Code 1970, § 17-3)  
Sec. 17.04. - Investigation of applicant; issuance of permit. 
(a)  Upon receipt of such application, the city manager shall cause an investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public. The applicant shall pay to the city manager all costs associated with said investigation. The city manager shall have forty-five (45) days from receipt of payment of appropriate investigation fees to complete such investigation. 
(b)  After the completion of the investigation, the city manager may deny a permit to solicit or peddle if an applicant has: 
(1)  Been convicted of, or entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to, a crime against the laws of this state or any other state or the United States, involving moral turpitude, fraudulent or dishonest dealing, or the illegal use or sale of a controlled substance, or been convicted or, or entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to a violation of any of the provisions of F.S. §§ 501.210—501.055. 
(2)  Has obtained a permit by fraud, false statement, misrepresentation, or failure to truthfully answer any questions in the required permit application. 
(3)  Has failed to obtain required county or municipal business tax receipts. 
(c)  If, as a result of the investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the city shall execute a permit in the name of the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for, which shall be issued upon the payment of a ninety dollars ($90.00) license fee due by the applicant to the city. 
(Code 1970, § 17-4; Ord. No. 2004-03, §§ 3—5, 1-20-2004; Ord. No. 2007-10, § 3, 5-21-2007)  
Sec. 17.05. - Permits—Display required. 
(a)  Each permit issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be kept on the person of the individual to whom it is issued, and shall show on its face the date of its expiration. Any person engaged in solicitation activities described in this article shall prominently display, upon his person at all times that he is engaged in solicitation within the city, the permit card issued to him by the city manager authorizing him to conduct commercial solicitations and shall show on its face the date of its expiration, which in no event shall extend beyond the thirtieth day of September following the date of is issuance. 
(b)  No permit shall be transferable. 
(Code 1970, § 17-5; Ord. No. 2006-13, §§ 1, 2, 9-18-2006)  
Sec. 17.06. - Revocation of permit. 
Permits issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the city manager for just cause or upon conviction of the holder for violation of any of the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 17-6)  
Sec. 17.07. - Restrictions on garage sales and estate sales. 
(a)  Duration of sale. A garage or estate sale shall not last more than three (3) consecutive days. A garage sale may not be conducted by any resident or representative of a resident more than once every three (3) months from the last garage sale. 
(b)  Parking. Garage or estate sale parking shall be controlled by the resident or representative of a resident so as not to be a hazard or create congestion on adjacent streets. If the city's code enforcement or law enforcement officer determines that the garage sale or estate sale is causing excessive parking congestion or creating a traffic hazard, the code inspector or law enforcement officer may require the resident or representative of a resident to cease the garage or estate sale. 
(Ord. No. 2010-18, § 8, 2-7-2011)  
Sec. 17.08. - Restrictions on panhandling. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in an act of panhandling when either the panhandler or the person being solicited is located in, on, or at any of the following locations: 
(1)  Area within ten (10) feet (in any direction) of a bus stop; 
(2)  Area within fifteen (15) feet (in any direction) of an automatic teller machine or entrance to a bank; or 
(3)  Private property, unless the panhandler has permission from the owner of such property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to engage in an act of panhandling on any day after sunset or before sunrise. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any panhandler to: 
(1)  Approach or speak to a person in such a manner as would cause a reasonable person to believe that the person is being threatened with: 
a.  Imminent bodily injury; or 
b.  The commission of a criminal act upon the person or another person, or upon property in the person's immediate possession; 
(2)  Persist in panhandling after the person solicited has given a negative response; 
(3)  Block, either individually or as part of a group of persons, the passage of a solicited person; 
(4)  Touch a solicited person; or 
(5)  Engage in conduct that would reasonably be construed as intended to intimidate, compel or force a solicited person to accede to demands. 
(Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 2-21-2011)  
Chapter 18 - PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; finance, Ch. 7. 
State Law reference— Actuarial soundness of retirement systems, F.S. § 112.60 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE II. - OLD AGE AND SURVIVOR'S INSURANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Social Security for public employees, F.S. Ch. 650. 
 
Sec. 18.01. - Adopted. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective as of the first day of July, 1951, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of Old Age and Survivor's Insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, and by Chapter 650, Florida Statutes, and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in section 650.02, Florida Statutes, performed in the employ of the city by employees thereof. 
(b)  In pursuance of this policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1970, § 18-1)  
Sec. 18.02. - Agreement with state. 
The mayor of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the state for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by the system of old age and survivor's insurance to the employees and officials of this city which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the city as are found by the state agency to be necessary for the proper and efficient administration thereof, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed after the first day of July, 1951. 
(Code 1970, § 18-2)  
Sec. 18.03. - Employee contributions. 
Withholdings from salaries, wages, or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 18.01 are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by the laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1970, § 18-3)  
Sec. 18.04. - Contributions by city. 
There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from ad valorem taxes, such amounts, at such times, as may be required to pay promptly the contributions required of the city as employer by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1970, § 18-4)  
Sec. 18.05. - Records and reports. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall adhere to the rules and regulations of the state agency for the enforcement of the laws and regulations. 
(Code 1970, § 18-5)  
Sec. 18.06. - Acceptance of benefits. 
The city does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining of the Social Security Act as amended, for and on behalf of all the officers and employees thereof and of its departments and agencies, save and except any of such officers and employees now covered or authorized to be covered by any retirement system provided by law, and further excepting any official or employee who occupies any position, office, or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1970, § 18-6)  
Sec. 18.07. - Custodian of funds. 
The clerk of the city is hereby designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees and of the appropriated funds for the contribution of the city, and the clerk of the city is hereby made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 18-7)  
ARTICLE III. - FLORIDA RETIREMENT SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Florida Retirement System, F.S. Ch. 121. 
 
Sec. 18.08. - Declaration of policy of coverage. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective June 1, 1972, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law or excepted herein, the benefits of the Florida Retirement System as authorized by Chapter 121, Florida Statutes, and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in that law performed in the employ of the city by employees and officials thereof. 
(Code 1970, § 18-11)  
Sec. 18.09. - Exclusion of certain employees. 
There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to include in any agreement entered into under section hereof any service, position, employee, or official now covered by or eligible to be covered by an existing retirement system sponsored by the city except social security only after holding a referendum, in which all employees and officials in the affected units have the right to participate. Only those employees and officials electing coverage under the Florida Retirement System by affirmative vote in the referendum shall be eligible for coverage, and those not participating or electing not to be covered by the Florida Retirement System shall remain in their present system and shall not be eligible for coverage. After the referendum is held, all future employees shall be compulsory members of Florida Retirement System. 
(Code 1970, § 18-12)  
Sec. 18.10. - Execution of agreements. 
The mayor and city manager are hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the administrator of the Florida Retirement System for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by the Florida Retirement System to the employees and officials of this city as provided in sections 18.08 and 18.09, hereof, which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the city as are found by the administrator of the Florida Retirement System to be necessary and proper, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed on and after the first day of June, 1972. 
(Code 1970, § 18-13)  
Sec. 18.11. - Appropriation of funds. 
There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from the general revenues such amounts and at such times as may be required to pay promptly the contributions and assessments required of the city as employer, by applicable state laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated administrator of the Florida Retirement System at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1970, § 18-15)  
Sec. 18.12. - Records and reports. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state laws or regulations, and shall adhere to all laws and regulations relating to the Florida Retirement System. 
(Code 1970, § 18-16)  
Sec. 18.13. - Adoption of terms of state system. 
The city does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of the Florida Retirement System, for and on behalf of all officers and employees of its departments and agencies to be covered under the agreement. 
(Code 1970, § 18-17)  
Sec. 18.14. - Custodian of funds. 
The finance director of the city is hereby designated the custodian of all sums appropriated for the employer's contributions as provided in section 18.11 hereof. The finance director is hereby made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining records for the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1970, § 18-18)  
Chapter 19 - SIGN REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 92-34, § 1, adopted December 7, 1992, adopted the Safety Harbor Land Development Code. Section 8.00 of such LDC repealed Ch. 19, §§ 19.01—19.18, of the City Code. Formerly, such sections pertained to sign regulations and derived from Ord. No. 87-36, § 1, adopted Oct. 5, 1987. Similar sign regulations are set out in Art. XII of the LDC. 
 
Chapter 20 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; code enforcement board, § 2.10.01 et seq.; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; animals, Ch. 4; building and property maintenance regulations, Ch. 5; flood prevention and control, Ch. 9; garbage and refuse, Ch. 10; health and sanitation, Ch. 11; junked, abandoned or wrecked property, Ch. 12; signs, Ch. 19; subdivision, Ch. 21; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 23; utilities, Ch. 24; zoning, Ch. 26. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 20.01. - Applicability. 
This chapter shall be applicable to all new developments and all developments in process that do not have commission approval of final plat or final site plan, as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 11.0), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.02. - Open areaways and cellar doors to be guarded. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave open any cellar door, grating, areaway or other covering for a cellar, stairway, coal hole or other excavation in any sidewalk, alley or street, within the city, without properly and securely guarding the same. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.0), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.03. - Obstructions to be guarded. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, while constructing any sidewalk, residence, building or other improvement, or while making repairs to the same, or for any other purpose, to pile sand, dirt, brick, lumber or other material upon any street, avenue, alley, or public place, or within the street limits, within the city, without maintaining at and thereon at proper places reflectorized barricades, a lighted lamp, lighted lantern or flares between the hours of sunset and sunrise, sufficiently bright to be easily observed at a distance of three hundred (300) feet (91.44 meters). 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.4), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.04. - Removal of danger signals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, throw down, destroy or carry away from any street, alley or public place, any lamp, lantern, flare or other light, barricade or danger signal, within the city, erected or placed therein for the purpose of guarding or enclosing unsafe or dangerous places or giving warning or notice thereof. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.5), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.05. - Encumbering sidewalks, right-of-way; exception; permission. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or encumber any sidewalk, right-of-way, within the city with boxes, barrels, packages, signs, building or other material or vehicles, except temporarily when receiving or taking away goods or merchandise from adjoining premises, and except when building or improving such property, and then only after obtaining permission from the city engineer under such conditions as he may impose. 
(b)  Mail boxes, telephone and power poles and café tables and seating compliant with subsection 20.21(a) which do not create traffic visibility conflicts or hazards, shall be excluded from this requirement. 
(c)  Certain signs shall be excluded from this requirement to the extent permitted by the city's sign code. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.6), 3-15-82; Ord. No. 2001-05, § 1, 5-21-2001; Ord. No. 2016-12, § 1, 6-6-2016)  
Sec. 20.06. - New sidewalks or pavement; walking or driving on or removal of barricades prohibited; civil liability. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to walk or drive a vehicle upon any newly laid pavement or sidewalk before the same has been opened to traffic, or to remove or interfere with any barriers protecting the same, and such person, in addition to any fine that may be assessed, shall be liable for any damage done to the paving or sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.7), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.07. - Certain articles not to be thrown in street. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or place in any street or public place, within the city, any broken glass, glass bottles or other articles of glass, tacks, nails, or any other sharp pointed materials, substance or things. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.8), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.08. - Defacing or removing street signs prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, deface, break, take down or remove, or in any manner interfere with any street sign placed in a street right-of-way under authority of the appropriate public body. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.9), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.09. - Nonliability of city. 
The owner, lessee or his agent, shall assume all responsibility and save the city free and harmless from all liability for damages to persons or property in any way connected with, arising out of or incidental to the installation, maintenance or use of municipally-owned property or the granting and exercise of permit or privilege.
