He shall pay all expenses for any change of grade of municipally-owned property, and shall hereby waive all claims for damage or expense in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 2.6), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.10. - Failure of compliance by permittee. 
In any case where a permittee hereunder shall be in default or shall fail to comply with the requirements of this chapter, the city engineer shall order the completion of the work by the city and shall recover the cost from permittee as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 2.7(b)), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.11. - Penalty for violations. 
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.10), 3-15-82)  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 20.12. - Rules, regulations, standards and specifications. 
(a)  The city manager, on the recommendations from the director of public works, shall promulgate and keep in force and effect reasonable rules, regulations, standards and specifications governing the interpretation and clarification where in his sole discretion the same is desirable in connection with this chapter. 
(b)  The rules, regulations, standards and specifications shall be kept in the office of the city clerk and in the office of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 7.0), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.13. - Appeal. 
(a)  If any person, firm or corporation is aggrieved by the ruling of the city manager or director of public works or the city engineer under the literal enforcement of either this chapter or the rules and regulations which the departments from time to time promulgate, a protest in writing shall be filed by the complaining party with the city manager. 
(b)  Such protest shall be placed upon the agenda of the commission, and the commission shall by majority vote enter its findings upon such appeal and the findings shall be a final ruling as to the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 8.0), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.14. - Variances—Authorized. 
(a)  The commission may authorize a variance to these regulations where special conditions exist which are peculiar to the site; where strict adherence to the provisions of these regulations would cause unnecessary hardship or where strict adherence to the provisions of these regulations is impossible or impractical, providing that such a variance can be made without substantially impairing the purpose and intent of these regulations. 
(b)  No pre-existing conditions on neighboring lands which are contrary to these regulations shall be considered as grounds for the approval of a variance. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 8.0), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.15. - Same—Application. 
Any request for an appeal or variance to these regulations shall be submitted in writing to the city manager or his designee for transmittal to the commission along with the city manager's summary and recommendation. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 8.1), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.16. - Same—Criteria. 
The commission shall not approve any variance to these regulations unless the commission shall make findings based upon evidence presented to them in each specific case that: 
(1)  The conditions upon which the request for a variance is based are unique to the property for which the variance is sought and are not applicable generally to other property; 
(2)  The property is characterized by particular physical surroundings, shape, topographical or other similar conditions which would result in a particular hardship to the owner, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience, if the strict letter of these regulations were imposed; 
(3)  The special conditions and circumstances upon which the request for a variance is based did not result from an action by the applicant or with prior knowledge or approval of the applicant; 
(4)  The approval of the requested variance will not confer to the applicant any special privilege that is denied by these regulations to other property under similar conditions; and 
(5)  The granting of the variance will not substantially impair the purpose or intent of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 8.2), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.17. - Same—Conditions. 
(a)  The commission may prescribe, in approving variances to these regulations, appropriate conditions and safeguards as deemed necessary for the protection of surrounding property and general welfare and the purpose and intent of these regulations and the adopted comprehensive plan. 
(b)  In stipulating such conditions, the commission may require a reasonable time for compliance, however, approval of a variance shall expire within twelve (12) months of approval by the commission unless the commission shall either stipulate a longer period of time for compliance or upon application by the developer prior to the expiration date, approve an extension to the compliance period. Any extension to the compliance period shall be granted only upon good cause being shown to the commission and shall be for the shortest possible period of time consistent with the facts associated with the particular request. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 8.2), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.18. - Same—Entered in minutes. 
Any variance thus authorized by the commission shall be entered in writing in the commission minutes, and the reasoning set forth for which the variance was justified. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 8.2), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.19. - Enforcement. 
This chapter and the rules and regulations promulgated therein are deemed by the commission to be essential to the protection of the health, safety and well-being of the city, and enforcement of compliance therewith may be compelled by and on behalf of the city through its city manager or the director of public works or his designee in the manner prescribed from time to time by law. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 9.0), 3-15-82)  
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS 
 
Sec. 20.20. - Right-of-way and easement use permit required. 
No person shall begin to construct, reconstruct, repair, alter, pave, or grade any sidewalk, curb, curb cut, driveway, parkway, or street within a public right-of-way or easement without first obtaining a permit from the city engineer as provided by this article. No obstruction of what ever kind shall be planted, built, or otherwise created within the limits of the public right-of-way or easement without first obtaining a permit from the city engineer as provided by this article. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 2.1), 3-15-82; Ord. No. 2004-04, §§ 1, 2, 1-20-2004)  
Sec. 20.21. - Right-of-way and easement use permits. 
(a)  Permits for paving, grading, or use of any portion of a public right-of-way or easement for any purpose may be granted by the city engineer, when, in his or her discretion, the safety and convenience of the city can be protected. The city engineer may impose any such conditions upon said permit which are deemed necessary to protect the safety and convenience of the city. Businesses with frontage on Main Street may place cafe tables measuring up to three (3) feet in diameter and chairs without a right-of-way use permit and shall not cause the minimum accessible path to be less than three (3) feet in width. 
(b)  All such permits shall be clearly marked to indicate that they are revocable at the will of the city, and that their issuance in no way grants to the permittee or his successors any right to the continued use of such parkway or right-of-way. 
(c)  If any person undertakes any activity as a result of an emergency within a public right-of-way or easement without a permit as required under this article, a permit shall be obtained within forty-eight (48) hours of the emergency activity. An emergency shall exist if, without undertaking activity in the right-of-way or easement, there is an immediate danger of damage occurring to life or property. If it is determined by the city engineer that no emergency existed at the time of the activity, the city engineer may require removal of any objects placed within the public right-of-way or easement and/or deny the requested permit. Additionally, the person shall be subject to enforcement action as provided for in the Safety Harbor City Code or as otherwise provided for by law. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 2.2), 3-15-82; Ord. No. 2004-04, §§ 3—5, 1-20-2004; Ord. No. 2016-12, § 2, 6-6-2016)  
Sec. 20.22. - Application procedure. 
An applicant for a permit hereunder shall file with the city engineer an application showing: 
(1)  Name and address of the owner, or agent, in charge of the property abutting the proposed work area; 
(2)  Name and address of the party doing the work; 
(3)  Location of the work area; 
(4)  Attached sample drawing showing necessary details of the proposal; and 
(5)  Such other information as the city engineer shall find reasonably necessary to the determination of whether a permit should be issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 2.3), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.23. - Bond requirements and exemptions. 
The following bonds may be required to accompany an application for a driveway/road use permit hereunder: 
(1)  Construction and maintenance. In cases where the estimated cost of the project shall exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), the city engineer may require a maintenance and construction bond to be filed with the application for a permit hereunder in an amount equal to one hundred (100) percent of the estimated cost of the project and conditioned that such work shall be done in accordance with the city's standard specifications and guaranteeing the same for a period of two (2) years, thereafter the property owner shall maintain the driveway in good and safe condition. 
(2)  Indemnity. The city engineer shall have the authority to require an applicant to file a bond conditioned to protect and save harmless the city from all claims for damages or injury to persons and property sustained during the actual course of such alteration work. 
(3)  Exemptions. Utility companies serving the public through a franchise agreement with the city shall be exempt from posting bonds for construction. However, they must obtain the required permits. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 2.7(a), (c), (d)), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.24. - Fee. 
Each application shall be accompanied by a fee, established by the commission by resolution for filing, engineering and inspection, unless a building permit for major construction is in effect in which case there may be no fee. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 2.4), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.25. - Revocation. 
All permits or privileges issued or granted under this article may be revoked at any time upon order of the city engineer or of the commission, and upon such order of revocation, the owner or lessee or their agents, shall cause such municipally-owned property to be restored completely and to the entire satisfaction of the city engineer without expense to the city. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 2.5), 3-15-82)  
ARTICLE IV. - SPECIAL EVENTS 
 
Sec. 20.26. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, certain terms are defined as follows: 
Block party means a gathering of neighbors in a residential area, where such gathering occurs within the neighborhood or residential area at least partly or otherwise affects the use of a public right-of-way, and is not open to the general public. 
Larger special event means a special event involving one hundred fifty (150) or more participants or potentially involving one hundred fifty (150) or more participants, including any special event that provides an open invitation to the public to attend or any special event where the attendance by private invitation of one hundred fifty (150) or more people. 
Smaller special event means a special event involving less than one hundred fifty (150) participants. 
Special event means: 
(1)  Any organized activity, formation, parade, procession, or assembly consisting of persons, animals, vehicles or any combination thereof, that is requested to occur partly or wholly upon any public right-of-way, including but not limited to public streets, alleys, sidewalks, and trails; 
(2)  Any organized activity or set of activities conducted by an individual, group, or entity, excluding the city, for a common or collective use or benefit, and which requests the use of city-owned facilities or the provision of ancillary city services; or 
(3)  An event held on public or private property that is requested to occur in a space or area not specifically approved for such use; or that the city believes would interfere with any pedestrian or vehicular circulation; or that the city believes is likely to significantly impact motorized or non-motorized traffic congestion or traffic flow to or upon public right-of-way; or that the city believes would significantly impact the need for emergency services such as police, fire or medical aid. Any event which involves an open invitation to the public to attend is presumed to be an event that will have a direct significant impact on the public streets, rights-of-way or emergency services. 
(4)  For purposes of this article, the term "special event" shall not include any events organized or carried out by the city. 
Sponsoring party means any individual, business, organization, or other entity that is hosting, organizing, holding, or sponsoring the event. (The term does not include individuals or entities who have a minor role in the event and no significant involvement in financing or organizing the event and does not include the city.) 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.27. - Applicability. 
(a)  This article shall apply to all special events. However, all other ordinances, laws, regulations, permits, and licenses shall also apply to the special event, whether or not a special event permit is required under this article. 
(b)  It is unlawful to conduct a special event unless the special event meets the requirements of this article and other applicable ordinances, laws, rules, and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.28. - Permit required for certain events. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person or entity to hold or sponsor any special event or to participate in a special event without a sponsoring party first applying for and obtaining a special event permit from the city; provided, that certain special events may be excluded from obtaining a permit pursuant to subsection (c) below. 
(b)  A special events permit does not waive the requirement to obtain any other applicable and necessary permits, including but not limited to permits or approvals for right-of-way use, signage, electrical, fire, and building safety. The sponsoring party is responsible for obtaining all necessary permits. 
(c)  Special events that are excluded from the requirement to obtain a special event permit under this article are as follows: 
(1)  Assembly uses that occur entirely within a building; provided, that any such use is consistent with the building's certificate of occupancy and consistent with all other applicable laws and regulations, including regulations for the underlying zoning district in which the special event would occur; 
(2)  Smaller special events in public parks, provided, that for any part of this event that is to occur within the public right-of-way, a special event permit must be obtained under this article; 
(3)  Sports and other outdoor activities that are conducted on fields, playgrounds, parks, or courts that have been legally constructed for such purpose; 
(4)  Activities held on the grounds of a legally operating school for its students and their family members and/or for faculty as part of the school's program for education, orientation, commencement, or other planned school events; 
(5)  Any smaller special event held entirely on private property; and 
(6)  Block parties involving less than seventy-five (75) people; provided, that a block party permit is obtained pursuant to section 20.40 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.29. - Fees. 
(a)  Special event permits are subject to a fee schedule as may be separately adopted or established by resolution of the city commission. The intent of charging fees is to help recover the cost of providing public services or facilities related to the event. The fee schedule shall include, but not be limited to, an application fee of at least fifty dollars ($50.00) for each special event permit, except as any exemptions or reductions are specifically provided in the schedule, and may require additional fees either due upon application or prior to permit issuance for some types of events. The application fee is nonrefundable. The fee schedule for additional fees may take into account factors, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  The type of event; 
(2)  The type of activities being held; 
(3)  Whether the event is sponsored as a fundraiser for a nonprofit entity and if registration or admission fees are being charged by the nonprofit entity; 
(4)  The number of participants; 
(5)  The length of the event or span of time that the event will take; 
(6)  The use of city facilities, city equipment, or public right-of-way; 
(7)  Other factors affecting the amount of city resources likely to be needed related to the event. 
(b)  In addition to any special event fee, additional fees may be due for other permits or licenses necessary to meet state and federal laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.30. - Pre-application conference. 
(a)  Prior to submitting a permit application for a larger special event, one (1) or more authorized representatives of the sponsoring party shall participate in a pre-application conference. To arrange said conference, a sponsoring party shall contact the leisure services department. Its purpose shall be to clarify the scope of the special event, permit requirements, anticipated fees, the interdepartmental review process, and potential impacts to be addressed. 
(b)  The sponsoring party of smaller special events that is expected to occur at least partially within the public right-of-way are encouraged to request a pre-application conference in the manner described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.31. - Special event application. 
(a)  A sponsoring party shall submit its proposal for the event on an application form provided by the leisure services department for that purpose and, as needed, shall submit additional information related to the event. 
(b)  Information provided by the sponsoring party shall be true, accurate, and complete. 
(c)  Applications for smaller special events shall be submitted to the city at least sixty (60) days prior to the event. 
(d)  Applications for larger special events shall be submitted to the city at least ninety (90) days prior to the event. 
(e)  The special event permit application shall address the following: 
(1)  Name of the event; 
(2)  Purpose of the event; 
(3)  Address or other specific location or route data for where the event is to occur; 
(4)  Time of the event, including set-up and take-down activities; 
(5)  Sponsoring party's name, signature, and contact information; 
(6)  Name(s) and contact information for any other sponsoring party(ies); 
(7)  Name(s) and contact information for owners or tenants of property on which an event is to be held; provided, that this information is not required for any portion of the event occurring on city-owned property or within public right-of-way; 
(8)  Documentation that the owner(s) or tenant(s) of any property on which the event is to be held, or the owner's or tenant's authorized agent, has provided permission for the event's occurrence; 
(9)  Whether the event is being sponsored by a non-profit entity and, if so, evidence of its nonprofit status; 
(10)  Thorough description of the activities to occur, including any type of music, sound amplification system, games, performances, displays, food-handling, or sales; 
(11)  Site plan indicating the location of the event, the specific location(s) of activities occurring at the event, and the routes for access and circulation; 
(12)  Whether alcohol is to be provided or allowed anywhere on site; and what entity will provide the temporary alcohol permit; 
(13)  Description and location of any furniture, awnings, canopies, buildings, structures, inflatable structures, play equipment, large machines, or other equipment (excluding small tabletop appliances and equipment) that will be used at the event; 
(14)  Electrical and water connections to be used, if any; 
(15)  Estimated number of attendees and estimated number of persons helping with the event at the time and place that it occurs; 
(16)  Manner in which the event will be announced to potential attendees, for example, by flyers, personal invitations, internet, newsletters, newspaper, radio, community announcements, or other means; 
(17)  Whether registration, admission, parking or other fees will be required for event participants and, if so, the type and amount of each fee; 
(18)  Information about the sponsoring party's insurance or ability to provide insurance; 
(19)  Plan for staffing the event and all its activities on the day(s) of the event; 
(20)  Plan for security for any larger special event; 
(21)  Proposed location and number of any sanitary facilities to be available, whether fixed or portable; 
(22)  Traffic control plan for any larger special event and for any event using, closing, or otherwise affecting a public right-of-way as determined by the Pinellas County Sheriff's Office and any law enforcement agency with jurisdiction over the event area; 
(23)  Parking management plan for larger special events as determined by the Pinellas County Sheriff's Office; 
(24)  Plans for garbage management and recycling; 
(25)  Any proposed event signage and its location(s); and 
(26)  Additional information requested by the leisure services department related to the event and any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.32. - Waiver of application deadline—Waiver of pre-application conference. 
Upon a showing of good cause, the leisure services director may waive any required pre-application conference and shall consider an application that is filed after the filing deadline, if there is sufficient time to process and investigate the application and obtain required services. Good cause can be demonstrated by the sponsoring party showing that the circumstances that gave rise to the permit application did not reasonably allow the participants to file within the time period prescribed. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.33. - Permit process. 
(a)  No special event permit shall be issued without the approval of all affected city departments, or approval with conditions as set forth in section 20.34, through an interdepartmental review process coordinated by the leisure services department; provided that if any department does not provide a written approval, approval with conditions, or denial to the leisure services department within fourteen (14) days of receiving a smaller special event permit application for review or within twenty-nine (29) days of receiving a larger special event permit application the timeframes set forth in subsection (b) below may be extended by the leisure services department. 
(b)  The city's permit review process shall include issuance of an approval, approval with conditions as described in section 20.34, or denial no later than thirty (30) days after receiving a complete application for a larger special event and no later than fifteen (15) days after receiving a complete application for a smaller special event. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.34. - Conditions or denial. 
(a)  The leisure services department may condition the issuance of a special event permit by imposing reasonable requirements concerning time, place, and manner of the event. Such conditions shall be based solely on compliance with this article, other laws and regulations, the event's potential impact on public health, safety, and welfare, availability of necessary city resources and/or facilities, and priorities pursuant to section 20.35 of this article. Such restrictions may include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Alteration of the date, time, route or location of the event proposed on the event application; 
(2)  Elimination of an activity which cannot be mitigated to a point as to ensure public safety and welfare, or which causes undue liability to the city; 
(3)  Conditions concerning the area of assembly and disbanding of a parade or other events occurring along a route; 
(4)  Conditions concerning the accommodation of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including restricting the event to only a portion of a street or right-of-way traversed; 
(5)  Requirements for the use of traffic cones or barricades; 
(6)  Requirements for the use of city personnel and equipment; 
(7)  Requirements for the provision of first aid or sanitary facilities; 
(8)  Requirements for the use of event monitors and providing notice of permit conditions to event participants; 
(9)  Requirements to provide notice to surrounding property owners; 
(10)  Restrictions on the number and type of vehicles, animals or structures at the event, and inspection and approval of floats, structures, and decorated vehicles for fire safety; 
(11)  Requirement for the use of garbage containers, cleanup, and restoration of property; 
(12)  Restrictions on the use of amplified sound and compliance with noise ordinances, regulations, and laws; 
(13)  Compliance with any relevant ordinance or law and obtaining any legally required permit or license; or 
(14)  Restrictions on the sale and/or consumption of alcohol. 
(b)  The city may deny a special event permit application if one (1) or more of the following criteria applies and appropriate conditions cannot otherwise be placed on the permit: 
(1)  Information contained in the application, or supplemental information requested from the sponsoring party, is found to be false or nonexistent in any material detail; for purposes of this section material details shall include the existence, good standing, or type of entity of the sponsoring party with the department of state, division of corporations; or 
(2)  The sponsoring party fails to complete the application form after having been notified of the additional information or documents required; or 
(3)  The sponsoring party refuses to agree, to abide or comply with all of the conditions and terms of the permit; or 
(4)  The time, route, hours, location, or size of the special event will, in the opinion of the Pinellas County Sherriff's Office, unnecessarily disrupt the movement of traffic within the area; or 
(5)  The special event is of the size or nature that, in the opinion of the Pinellas County Sherriff's Office, requires the diversion of so great a number of sheriff deputies to the city to properly police the event, site and contiguous areas that allowing the special event would unreasonably deny police protection to the remainder of the city and its residents; or 
(6)  Another special event permit application has already been received, or has already been approved, to hold another special event at the same time and place requested by the sponsoring party, or so close in time and place as to cause undue traffic congestion, or the sheriff's office and/or other city departments are unable to meet the needs for police and other city services for both events; or 
(7)  The location of the special event will substantially interfere with any construction or maintenance work scheduled to take place upon or along public property or right-of-way, or a previously granted right-of-way use permit; or 
(8)  The event would endanger public safety or health; or 
(9)  The sponsoring party fails to comply with the liability insurance requirements, or the sponsoring party's insurance lapses or is cancelled; or 
(10)  The event would create or constitute a public nuisance; or 
(11)  The event would be likely to cause significant damage to public property or facilities; or 
(12)  Failure to meet state or federal requirements related to the event or obtain approvals from other governmental entities or agencies affected by or regulating the event; or 
(13)  The event would engage in or encourage participants to engage in illegal acts. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.35. - Prioritization of permits. 
When an event is proposed that would conflict with the time or location of another event, the following criteria shall guide the determination of priority for the special event: 
(1)  Whether a special event is being proposed for the same area or time as another event and, if so, whether multiple events can be reasonably accommodated given the location and resources, and if not, giving priority to the first event for which a permit application has been timely submitted; provided, that an event sponsored by the City of Safety Harbor shall have ultimate priority; 
(2)  Whether the timing or location of an event might conflict with other projects and activities, for example, road work or a construction project; 
(3)  History of the event or other events held by a sponsoring party as related to safety, security, and compliance with permit conditions. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.36. - Insurance and liability. 
(a)  Liability coverage required. The sponsoring party of a larger special event, if required by this article to obtain a permit and the special event would occur partially or wholly on public right-of-way or city property, must possess or obtain public liability insurance to protect against loss from liability imposed by law for damages on account of bodily injury and property damage arising from the event. A certificate of insurance shall be filed thirty (30) days prior to the event with the leisure services director, and shall name the city, its officials, employees and agents as additional insured. Insurance coverage must be maintained for the duration of the event. 
(b)  Minimum limits defined. Required coverage shall be a commercial general liability policy. Minimum limits required are one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each occurrence combined single limit bodily injury and property damage; two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) aggregate. If food or nonalcoholic beverages are sold or served at the event, the policy must also include an endorsement for product liability. If alcoholic beverages are sold or served at the event, the policy must also include an endorsement for host liquor liability. If the event involves athletic or other types of active participants, the policy must include participant coverage. The leisure services director may require additional endorsements depending upon the proposed activity. 
(c)  If vehicles are used for other than nominal and standard commute purposes, a policy of business automotive liability, on an insurance industry standard form or equivalent including coverage for owned, non-owned, leased or hired vehicles, or equivalent coverage. 
(d)  Waiver or reduction of required limits. The city manager may waive or reduce the insurance requirements of this article under the following conditions: 
(1)  The sponsoring party or an officer thereof signs a verified statement that the cost of obtaining insurance is so financially burdensome that it would prohibit the special event from occurring. The statement shall include the name and address of two (2) insurance agents or other source of insurance coverage contacted to determine insurance premium rates for insurance coverage. 
(2)  The sponsoring party or an officer thereof signs a verified statement that insurance coverage in the limits required is impossible to obtain. The statement shall include the name and address of two (2) insurance agents or other source of insurance coverage contacted. 
(3)  The city manager determines that the insurance limits are in excess of the reasonable risk presented by the proposed special event. 
(e)  Any costs incurred as a result of an event shall be borne by the sponsoring party. The city may require the posting of a bond to cover estimated costs of clean-up and disposal fees prior to issuance of a permit. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.37. - Appeal and appeal procedure. 
(a)  Right to appeal. The sponsoring party shall have the right to appeal the denial of a permit or imposition of a permit condition. The sponsoring party shall also have the right to appeal the amount of fees imposed. 
(b)  Authority. The city commission is authorized to hear any appeal from the denial of a permit or permit condition in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Written notice of appeal. A written notice of appeal shall be filed within ten (10) days after the mailing or personal delivery of a notice of denial or permit condition with the leisure services director or is thereafter barred. This appeal shall set forth the grounds for the appeal and shall include a statement on why the sponsoring party believes the decision is an error and attach any relevant documents for consideration. 
(d)  Scheduling of hearing. Upon receipt of a timely filed notice of appeal, a hearing shall be scheduled not more than forty-five (45) days from the date of the filing of the notice of appeal. Written notice of the date of the hearing shall be sent to the appellants not less than three (3) business days prior to the scheduled hearing date. The failure of the appellant to appear at the hearing shall result in a judgment by default. The decision of the city commission shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.38. - Performance requirements. 
(a)  All aspects of the special event shall be conducted consistent with applicable laws and regulations, including but not limited to this article, and with the terms and conditions of the issued permit. 
(b)  A special event shall be held for no more than three (3) consecutive days. 
(c)  Alcohol is prohibited at special events except if it is specifically allowed under the conditions of a special event permit and state/federal laws. 
(d)  If adequate fixed sanitary facilities are not available for use at the special event, portable toilets shall be provided of a number and type that complies with industry standards as determined by the leisure services director within city parks and by the city's building official anywhere else; provided, that no toilets are required for special events that last less than two (2) hours. 
(e)  Garbage receptacles and recycling containers, as required by the permit conditions, shall be provided at the event site and removed and properly disposed of after the event. Additional fees may be imposed for use of such facilities. Any remaining litter or debris shall be cleaned up and removed the same day as the event, unless a longer clean-up period is granted by the permit. 
(f)  If city equipment is not supplied, the provision of any required barricades, traffic control devices, portable toilets, and/or garbage receptacles, must be submitted to the city through documentation in the form of a work order or an invoice at least two (2) weeks in advance of the event to demonstrate that the equipment or services has been arranged by the event organizer. Additional fees may be imposed for use of such facilities. 
(g)  Any traffic control devices shall be installed and removed pursuant to the terms of the permit. 
(h)  No fires, or fireworks displays are allowed, except in a manner and location specifically approved by the city for such purpose. 
(i)  Inflatable play equipment and all membrane structures shall be properly installed per the manufacturer's instructions. 
(j)  Event sponsors shall follow requirements and guidelines of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) when applicable. 
(k)  Food handling and preparation shall be in accordance with requirements of the Pinellas County Health Department, State of Florida Department of Agriculture and Department of Business and Professional Regulation. 
(l)  A copy of any announcements that the sponsoring party or its agency produces for distribution about the proposed event shall be submitted to the leisure services department either before or within three (3) days after their distribution. 
(m)  Any smaller special event occurring outdoors and not required to obtain a permit under subsection 20.28(c)(6) of this article shall have a duration of four (4) hours or less and shall not occur between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m., except as is otherwise provided by a special event permit that the sponsor has chosen to obtain. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.39. - Revocation. 
A permit for a special event may be revoked if the city finds that the sponsoring party has failed to provide complete or accurate information in his/her permit application or has not met the terms or conditions of the permit or has failed to comply with any requirement of section 20.38 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.40. - Block parties. 
(a)  Block parties, as defined in section 20.26 of this article, may be conducted; provided, that a block party permit has been obtained from the leisure services department. 
(b)  Block party permits are limited to events that have less than seventy-five (75) participants. Block parties that have seventy-five (75) or more participants or are likely to have seventy-five (75) or more participants are to obtain a special event permit instead of a block party permit. The Pinellas County Sheriff's Office may also make a determination that the proposed block party is subject to a special event permit, rather than a block party permit, based on the likely number of participants or a finding that the event may have special impacts due to the timing of the event, nature of activities or other factors related to public health, safety, or welfare. 
(c)  Applications for a block party permit shall be submitted to the leisure services department at least ten (10) days prior to the event and shall include information required by the leisure services department, including but not limited to: 
(1)  Name, address, and signature of sponsoring party; 
(2)  Location and boundaries of the event; 
(3)  Date and time of the event; 
(4)  Use or closure of any public right-of-way, including sidewalks; 
(5)  Traffic management plan related to the closure or obstruction of any public right-of-way; 
(6)  Activities to occur, including any form of music; 
(7)  Estimated number of participants and evidence of neighbor support; 
(8)  Copy of any announcements that may have been distributed or are planned to be distributed about the event. 
(d)  A block party permit may be denied if the leisure services department finds that the event is likely to have seventy-five (75) or more participants, in which case the applicant may apply for a special event permit. 
(e)  If the leisure services department finds that the event proposed for a time or location conflicts with other events or necessary transportation access, the leisure services department will make an effort to advise the sponsoring party of other potential times or locations. 
(f)  In no case shall a block party occur between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(g)  Traffic control devices shall be placed in appropriate locations, as required by the permit. 
(h)  All litter and debris shall be removed from the site the same day as the event occurs, except as the permit allows additional clean-up time. 
(i)  All conditions of the block party permit shall be followed. Failure to follow the block party permit may result in a violation pursuant to section 20.41 of this article. 
(j)  Other laws and regulations shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.41. - Violations and penalties. 
Any person, sponsoring party or organization violating the provisions of this article shall be subject to a penalty of a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation or by imprisonment of not more than sixty (60) days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 2015-10, § 1, 6-1-2015)

ARTICLE VII. - EXCAVATIONS 
 
Sec. 20.71. - Excavations to be guarded. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or allow to be open any excavation or vault, in, on, or under any street, avenue, alley or sidewalk within the city, and fail to guard or protect people passing, riding or driving thereby, by proper guards and lights. 
(b)  All such excavations shall conform to appropriate standards and specifications as required by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.2), 3-15-82)  
Sec. 20.72. - Removal of guard rails or barricades. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to take down, remove, carry away or interfere with any fence, railing, barricade, or other guard placed about, around or at any excavation, pile of dirt, rock or other material, in a street, avenue, alley, public ground, or on private property, which has been set as a warning thereof, or to remove, extinguish, carry away or interfere with any light, lantern or flare placed at the obstruction within the city. 
(Ord. No. 82-04, § 1(§ 1.3), 3-15-82)  
Secs. 20.73—20.80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - ART IN PUBLIC PLACES 
 
Sec. 20.81. - Intent. 
The primary intent for the city public art program is to borrow, acquire and commission works of art in order to enhance the cultural environment and city identity of the city. It is further the intent of the public art program to encourage the creation of artwork and to foster the enjoyment and understanding of art by the public. In recognition of the need to provide aesthetically appealing public places for the citizenry to gather which are reflective of the city's history and traditions, the public art program will foster involvement of the community in the process of selecting artwork to be displayed. 
(Ord. No. 93-29, § 1, 10-4-93)  
Sec. 20.82. - Definitions. 
[The following terms, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them herein, except where context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
Eligible city public improvement projects means and shall be defined as any public building, facility or structure which permits public occupancy of all or a portion thereof; any public park or recreation facility. For the purposes of this definition, the following shall not be considered as eligible city public improvement projects: 
(1)  Any basic road project, including, but not limited to, construction, resurfacing, curbing, drainage, stripping and signalization. 
(2)  Any public utility project. 
(3)  Any public building, facility or structure which is not generally accessible to or visited by the public. 
(4)  Any project funded by a revenue source which, by law, cannot be utilized for the acquisition of artwork. 
(5)  Any acquisition of land. 
(6)  Any eligible public improvements for which the city commission decides not to allocate funding for public art in the construction budget. 
Integral part means any area in the interior or exterior of a municipal facility in which public art may be displayed or incorporated, including walls, ceilings, sidewalks, seating, stairways and fenestration. 
Public place means any place owned or operated by the city which is accessible to the public, including, but not limited to, buildings, parks and open spaces. 
Work of art means the application of skill and vision in the creation of a tangible or illusionary object or device guided by aesthetic principles. 
(Ord. No. 93-29, § 1, 10-4-93)  
Sec. 20.83. - Appropriation of funds for acquisition of art for eligible city public improvements. 
(a)  At the discretion of the city commission, appropriations for eligible city public improvement projects may include an amount determined by the city commission, not to exceed one (1) percent of the total project cost as bid and accepted by the city or ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), whichever is less. Such amount shall be used for the selection, acquisition, installation, maintenance and insurance of works of art to be made a part of a public facility, or placed and/or attached in, on, or adjacent to public facilities. If only a portion of the total project cost is legally eligible for works of art, that eligible portion becomes the base in making the above calculation. 
(b)  For the funds appropriated pursuant to this section and held in a public art fund, the city commission shall approve the amount of monies, if any, to be allocated for selection, acquisition and installation of individual works of art to be incorporated as a part of the eligible city public improvement project for which the monies were appropriated, or placed and/or attached in, on, or adjacent to such project, or to be placed in, on or adjacent to existing public facilities. 
(Ord. No. 93-29, § 1, 10-4-93)  
Sec. 20.84. - Public art committee. 
(a)  The city public art committee ("committee") is hereby created. The committee shall be composed of five (5) members and one (1) alternate, all of whom shall be residents of the city appointed by the city commission. The committee will serve as an advisory committee for the selection of artwork, artists or commissioning and siting associated with public art in the city. 
(b)  The regular members of the committee will, at its first meeting, elect from its own membership a chairperson and a vice-chairperson. These individuals will serve in their position for one (1) year, to be reelected on the anniversary of the first meeting each year. The vice-chairperson will act as chairperson in the chairperson's absence and will assist the chairperson in carrying out their duties. The committee shall consist of five (5) regular members and one (1) alternate member. All members of the committee shall be residents of the city at all times. No person shall be eligible for appointment to the committee while serving on another city board or committee unless such person resigns from the other board or committee prior to or coincident to commencing to serve on the committee. At least two (2) members of the committee should have an extensive art background, to mean a professional artist, art teacher, art administrator, long-time volunteer in the arts, etc. The initial terms of the members of the committee shall be three (3) regular members and one (1) alternate member appointed to a term of two (2) years and two (2) regular members appointed to a term of one (1) year. Thereafter, appointment for all members shall be a term of two (2) years. Appointment to fill any vacancy on the committee shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term of office. At meetings of the committee at which all the regular members are present, the alternate member shall sit as a nonvoting member of the committee, but shall be allowed to participate in the committee's discussion. At meetings of the committee at which one (1) regular member is absent, the alternate shall sit as a voting member of the committee. 
(c)  A majority of the voting members of the committee shall constitute a quorum necessary for the conduct of the business of the committee. Meetings shall be at the call of the chairman or, in his absence, the vice-chairman, or at the call of any three (3) regular members of the committee. The records and minutes of the deliberations and decisions of the committee shall be kept and filed with the city clerk. 
(d)  The committee will review the city staff projects potentially eligible for appropriation for artwork and potential sites for the artwork. Based on this review, the committee will recommend allocation of funds, choose the appropriate selection procedure and develop guidelines and timetables for each project. These recommendations will then guide the program for the upcoming year. 
(e)  The committee shall develop a program for the loaning of artwork to the city for the display of such artwork at public places. The committee shall be responsible for selecting and siting of loaned artwork. The city attorney will prepare a standard written agreement for the loaning of the artwork for execution by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 93-29, § 1, 10-4-93; Ord. No. 96-05, § 1, 2-19-96; Ord. No. 2015-15, § 1, 6-1-2015)  
Sec. 20.85. - Selection process and criteria. 
(a)  The selection process to be utilized for artwork purchased or commissioned by the city will be a direct selection process. Committee members may compile slides of available art for review by the committee. 
(b)  Recommendations for the purchase of artworks or commissions selected by the committee will be recorded and submitted to the city commission for the city commission's ap proval. The artist will not be officially notified until the city commission informs the committee of its approval. The approval or rejection of the committee's recommendations shall take place in a timely fashion. 
(c)  No commissioned work shall commence prior to the receipt of a signed and approved contract between the artist and the city. Ownership of all works of art commissioned by the city shall be vested in the city. 
(d)  The criteria for selection of purchased or commissioned artwork will be as follows: 
(1)  Quality of work. 
(2)  Education. 
(3)  Special training. 
(4)  Arts, grants, fellowships and awards. 
(5)  Exhibitions and sales history. 
(6)  Previous public art projects. 
(7)  Appropriateness of work to the designated site. 
(e)  The selection of artwork for loan to the city shall be in accordance with the procedures and criteria established by the committee, provided that the committee complies with the requirements of section 20.84(e). 
(f)  Artists will be encouraged to consult with conservators in order to develop appropriate conservation techniques and materials to minimize maintenance expenses. Projected maintenance cost will be considered as an additional criteria for the selection of commissioned work. Required site visits by the artists for the purpose of designing and executing the work will be included as part of the total cost of the project, which shall not exceed the total project allocation. 
(Ord. No. 93-29, § 1, 10-4-93)  
Sec. 20.86. - Public awareness and community education. 
(a)  It is recognized that works of art often significantly alter public places and stimulate the emotions of the public. The public art program shall endeavor to broaden community awareness and understanding of art forms so that they may be appreciated and positively received. 
(b)  Public awareness and education activities will be supported to bring the public, the visual arts, and artists closer together through informed discussion of art in public places, its history and benefits. Extensive efforts will be made to promote art in public places as a significant cultural resource to residents and visitors. 
(Ord. No. 93-29, § 1, 10-4-93)  
Sec. 20.87. - Acquisition; donations. 
Acquisitions of works that are purchased will be handled as described in the selection process. Artworks offered to the city as gifts will be submitted to the committee for review. The committee will use the same criteria for reviewing potential donations as is used in the selection process. Its recommendations will be passed on to the city commission for final approval. 
(Ord. No. 93-29, § 1, 10-4-93)  
Sec. 20.88. - Documentation policy. 
As a condition of acquisition, all purchases, commissions and donations must be accompanied by a color slide transparency documenting the work. In the case of three-dimensional work, this shall include documentation from three (3) different views. A duplicate of these slides will be made and kept and filed for use in case of loss or damage of the original slide. The city will establish a slide library of the city's collection, which will additionally include a locator card indicating site, artist, date of acquisition, dimensions and condition. 
(Ord. No. 93-29, § 1, 10-4-93)  
ARTICLE IX. - COMMUNICATION FACILITIES IN THE RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
 
Sec. 20.89. - Intent and purpose. 
It is the intent of the city to promote the public health, safety and general welfare by: providing for the placement or maintenance of communications facilities in the public rights-of-way within the city; adopting and administering reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with state and federal law, including Section 337.401, Florida Statutes (2002), as it may be amended, the home-rule authority of the city, and in accordance with the provisions of the Federal Telecommunications Act of 1996, the Middle Class Tax Relief and Job Creation Act of 2012, the relevant portion of which is codified at 47 U.S.C. § 1400 et seq., and other federal and state law; establishing reasonable rules and regulations necessary to manage the placement or maintenance of communications facilities in the public rights-of-way by all communications services providers; and minimizing disruption to the public rights-of-way. In regulating its public rights-of-way, the city shall be governed by and shall comply with all applicable federal and state laws. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003; Ord. No. 2016-08, § 1, 6-6-2016)  
Sec. 20.90. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given. 
Abandonment shall mean the permanent cessation of all uses of a communications facility; provided that this term shall not include cessation of all use of a facility within a physical structure where the physical structure continues to be used. 
Antenna: Communications equipment that transmits or receives electromagnetic radio frequency signals used in providing wireless services. 
City utility pole: A utility owned by the city in a right-of-way maintained by the city. 
Collocate or collocation: To install, mount, maintain, modify, operate or replace one or more wireless facilities on, under, within, or adjacent to a wireless support structure or utility pole. This term does not include the installation of a new utility pole or wireless support structure in a right-of-way. 
Communications services shall mean the transmission, conveyance or routing of voice, data, audio, video, or any other information or signals to a point, or between or among points, by or through any electronic, radio, satellite, cable, optical, microwave, or other medium or method now in existence or hereafter devised, regardless of the protocol used for such transmission or conveyance. Notwithstanding the foregoing, for purposes of this article "cable service", as defined in Section 202.11(2), Florida Statutes (2002), as it may be amended, is not included in the definition of "communications services," and cable service providers may be subject to other ordinances of the city. 
Communications services provider shall mean any person including a municipality or county providing communications services through the placement or maintenance of a communications facility in public rights-of-way. "Communications services provider" shall also include any person including a municipality or county that places or maintains a communications facility in public rights-of-way but does not provide communications services. 
Communications facility or facility or system shall mean any permanent or temporary plant, equipment and property, including but not limited to cables, wires, conduits, ducts, fiber optics, poles, antennae, converters, splice boxes, cabinets, hand holes, manholes, vaults, drains, surface location markers, appurtenances, and other equipment or pathway placed or maintained or to be placed or maintained in the public rights-of-way of the city and used or capable of being used to transmit, convey, route, receive, distribute, provide or offer communications services. 
FCC shall mean the Federal Communications Commission. 
In public rights-of-way or in the public rights-of-way shall mean in, on, over, under or across the public rights-of-way. 
Micro wireless facility: A small wireless facility having dimensions no larger than 24 inches in length, 15 inches in width, 12 inches in height, and an exterior antenna, if any, no longer than 11 inches. 
Ordinance shall mean this article. 
Person shall include any individual, child, firm, association, joint venture, partnership, estate, trust, business trust, syndicate, fiduciary, corporation, organization or legal entity of any kind, successor, assignee, transferee, personal representative, and all other groups or combinations, and shall include the city to the extent the city acts as a communications services provider. 
Place or maintain or placement or maintenance or placing or maintaining shall mean to erect, construct, install, maintain, place, repair, extend, expand, remove, occupy, locate or relocate. A communications services provider that owns or exercises physical control over communications facilities in public rights-of-way, such as the physical control to maintain and repair, is "placing or maintaining" the facilities. A person providing service only through resale or only through use of a third party's unbundled network elements is not "placing or maintaining" the communications facilities through which such service is provided. The transmission and receipt of radio frequency signals through the airspace of the public rights-of-way does not constitute "placing or maintaining" facilities in the public rights-of-way. 
Public rights-of way shall mean a public right-of-way, public utility easement, highway, street, bridge, tunnel or alley for which the city is the authority that has jurisdiction and control and may lawfully grant access to pursuant to applicable law, and includes the surface, the air space over the surface and the area below the surface. "Public rights-of-way" shall not include private property. "Public rights-of-way" shall not include any real or personal property of the city except as described above and shall not include buildings, fixtures, poles, conduits, facilities or other structures or improvements of the city, regardless of whether they are situated in the public rights-of-way. 
Registrant shall mean a communications services provider that has registered with the city in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
Registration or register shall mean the process described in this article whereby a communications services provider provides certain information to the city. 
Small wireless facility: A wireless facility that meets the following qualifications: 
a.  Each antenna associated with the facility is located inside an enclosure of no more than six cubic feet in volume or, in the case of antennas that have exposed elements, each antenna and all of its exposed elements could fit within an enclosure of no more than six cubic feet in volume; and 
b.  All other wireless equipment associated with the facility is cumulatively no more than 28 cubic feet in volume. The following types of associated ancillary equipment are not included in the calculation of equipment volume: electric meters, concealment elements, telecommunications demarcation boxes, ground-based enclosures, grounding equipment, power transfer switches, cutoff switches, vertical cable runs for the connection of power and other services, and utility poles or other support structures. 
Tower: Any structure designed and constructed primarily for the purpose of supporting one or more antennas, including self-supporting lattice towers, guy towers, or monopole towers. The term does not include radio and television transmission towers, microwave towers, common-carrier towers, cellular telephone towers, alternative tower structures and the like. 
Utility pole: A pole or similar structure that is used in whole or in part to provide communication services for electrical distribution, lighting, traffic control, signage, or a similar function. The term includes the vertical support structure for traffic lights but does not include a horizontal structure to which signal lights or other traffic control devices are attached and does not include a pole or similar structure 15 feet in height or unless an authority grants a waiver for such pole. 
Wireless facility: Equipment at a fixed location which enables wireless communication between user equipment and a communication network, including radio transceivers, antennas, wires, coaxial or fiber-optic cable or other cables, regular and backup power supplies, and comparable equipment, regardless of technological configuration, and equipment, regardless of technological configuration, and equipment associated with wireless communications. The term includes small wireless facilities. The term does not include: 
a.  The structure or improvements on, under, within, or adjacent to the structure on which the equipment is collocated; 
b.  Wireline backhaul facilities; or 
c.  Coaxial or fiber-optic cable that is between wireless structures or utility poles or that is otherwise not immediately adjacent to or directly associated with a particular antenna. 
Wireless infrastructure provider: A person who has been certified to provide telecommunications service in the state and who builds or installs wireless communication transmission equipment, wireless facilities, or wireless support structures but is not a wireless provider. 
Wireless provider: A wireless infrastructure provider or a wireless services provider. 
Wireless services: Any services provided using licensed or unlicensed spectrum, whether at a fixed location or mobile, using wireless facilities. 
Wireless services provider: A person who provides wireless services. 
Wireless support structure: A freestanding structure, such as a monopole, a guyed or self supporting tower, or another existing or proposed structure designed to support or capable of supporting wireless facilities. The term does not include a utility pole. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003; Ord. No. 2017-32, § 1, 10-16-2017)  
Sec. 20.91. - Registration for placing or maintaining communications facilities in public rights-of-way. 
(a)  A communications services provider, wireless services provider, or wireless infrastructure provider, that desires to place or maintain a communications facility in public rights-of-way in the city shall first register with the city in accordance with this article. Subject to the terms and conditions prescribed in this article and pursuant to any permit, if required, a registrant may erect, construct, place install, expand, use, maintain or repair a communications facility in public rights-of-way. 
(b)  A registration shall not convey any title, equitable or legal, to the registrant in the public rights-of-way. Registration under this article governs only the placement or maintenance of communications facilities in public rights-of-way. Other ordinances, codes or regulations may apply to the placement or maintenance in the public rights-of-way of facilities that are not communications facilities. Registration does not excuse a communications services provider, wireless services provider, or wireless infrastructure provider, from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment agreements before locating its facilities on the city or another person's facilities. Registration does not excuse a communications services provider, wireless services provider, or wireless infrastructure provider, from complying with all applicable ordinances, codes or regulations of the city, including this article. 
(c)  Each communications services provider, wireless services provider, or wireless infrastructure provider, that desires to place or maintain a communications facility in public rights-of-way in the city shall file a single registration with the city which shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name of the applicant; 
(2)  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant's primary contact person in connection with the registration, and the person to contact in case of an emergency; 
(3)  Evidence of the insurance coverage required under this article and acknowledgment that registrant has received and reviewed a copy of this article, which acknowledgment shall not be deemed an agreement; and 
(4)  The number of the applicant's certificate of authorization or license to provide communications services issued by the Florida Public Service Commission, the Federal Communications Commission, or other federal or state authority, if any. 
(d)  The city shall review the information submitted by the applicant. Such review shall be by the city manager or his or her designee. If the applicant submits information in accordance with the subsection (c) above, the registration shall be effective and the city shall notify the applicant of the effectiveness of registration in writing. If the city determines that the information has not been submitted in accordance with the subsection (c) above, the city shall notify the applicant of the noneffectiveness of registration, and reasons for the noneffectiveness, in writing. The city shall so reply to an applicant within thirty (30) days after receipt of registration information from the applicant. Noneffectiveness of registration shall not preclude an applicant from filing subsequent applications for registration under the provisions of this article. 
(e)  A registrant may cancel a registration upon written notice to the city stating that it will no longer place or maintain any communications facilities in public rights-of-way within the city and will no longer need to obtain permits to perform work in public rights-of-way. A registrant cannot cancel a registration if the registrant continues to place or maintain any communications facilities in public rights-of-way. 
(f)  Registration does not in and of itself establish a right to place or maintain or priority for the placement or maintenance of a communications facility in public rights-of-way within the city but shall establish for the registrant a right to apply for a permit, if permitting is required by the city. Registrations are expressly subject to any future amendment to or replacement of this article and further subject to any additional city ordinances, as well as any state or federal laws that may be enacted. 
(g)  A registrant shall renew its registration with the city by September 30 of each year, in accordance with the registration requirements in this article. Within thirty (30) days of any change in the information required to be submitted pursuant to subsection (c), a registrant shall provide updated information to the city. If no information in the then-existing registration has changed, the renewal may state that no information has changed. Failure to renew a registration may result in the city restricting the issuance of additional permits until the communications services provider has complied with the registration requirements of this article. 
(h)  In accordance with applicable city ordinances, codes or regulations, a permit may be required of a communications services provider, wireless services provider, or wireless infrastructure provider, that desires to place or maintain a communications facility in public rights-of-way. An effective registration shall be a condition of obtaining a permit. Notwithstanding an effective registration, permitting requirements shall apply. A permit may be obtained by or on behalf of a registrant having an effective registration if all permitting requirements are met. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003; Ord. No. 2017-32, § 2, 10-16-2017)  
Sec. 20.92. - Notice of transfer, sale or assignment of assets in public rights-of-way. 
(a)  If a registrant transfers, sells or assigns its assets located in public rights-of-way incident to a transfer, sale or assignment of the registrant's assets, the transferee, buyer or assignee shall be obligated to comply with the terms of this article. Written notice of any such transfer, sale or assignment shall be provided by such registrant to the city within twenty (20) days after the effective date of the transfer, sale or assignment. If the transferee, buyer or assignee is a current registrant, then the transferee, buyer or assignee is not required to re-register. If the transferee, buyer or assignee is not a current registrant, then the transferee, buyer or assignee shall register as provided in section 20.91 within sixty (60) days of the transfer, sale or assignment. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003; Ord. No. 2017-32, § 3, 10-16-2017)  
Sec. 20.93. - Placement or maintenance of a communications facility in public rights-of-way. 
(a)  A registrant shall not commence to place, maintain or repair a communications facility in public rights-of-way until a permit has been obtained from the city engineer as provided for by this chapter. Permits shall apply only to the areas of public rights-of-way specifically identified in the permit. However, the city may issue a blanket permit to cover certain activities, such as routine maintenance and repair activities, that may otherwise require individual permits. Registrant acknowledges that, as a condition of granting such permits, the city may impose reasonable rules or regulations governing the placement or maintenance of a communications facility in public rights-of-way. A registrant shall not be excused from compliance with this section or any other applicable code or regulation due to the necessity for an emergency repair. 
(b)  As part of any permit application to place, replace or maintain an existing communications facility in public rights-of-way, the registrant shall provide the following: 
(1)  The location of the proposed facilities, including a description of the facilities to be installed, including the type/model of antenna(s), tower(s), wireless support structure(s), height of the proposed facilities, where the facilities are to be located, and the approximate size of facilities that will be located in public rights-of-way; 
(2)  A description of the manner in which the facility will be installed, including but not limited to, anticipated construction methods or techniques; 
(3)  A maintenance of traffic plan for any disruption of the public rights-of-way; 
(4)  Information on the ability of the public rights-of-way to accommodate the proposed facility, if available; 
(5)  If appropriate given the facility proposed, an estimate of the cost of restoration to the public rights-of-way and a description of the means of repairing any damage to the rights-of-way; and 
(6)  The timetable for construction of the project or each phase thereof, and the areas of the city which will be affected; and 
(7)  Such additional information as the city finds reasonably necessary with respect to the placement or maintenance of the communications facility that is the subject of the permit application to review such permit application. 
(8)  Scaled drawing showing the location of the proposed facilities in the right-of-way including: 
a.  rights-of-way width and road pavement width; 
b.  location of all other utilities in the right-of-way; 
c.  sidewalks including sidewalk width; 
d.  an aerial map showing the location of the communication facilities, including the distance to other towers, poles, or wireless support structures; 
(9)  Camouflaging techniques in accordance with subsection 20.93(e)(3). 
(10)  All antenna and accessory equipment shall be located to avoid any physical or visual obstructions to pedestrian or vehicular traffic, or to otherwise create safety hazards to pedestrians or motorists, including clear zone and site line requirements. 
(11)  Items (1)—(9) listed above must be signed and sealed by a professional structural engineer certified in the State of Florida (unless the applicant is using exempt employees pursuant to F.S. § 471.003(2)(b)2(d), and, where a communication facility is not being collated on a currently permitted pole, tower or wireless support structure, or on the replacement of a currently permitted pole, tower, or wireless support structure, must include an accurate depiction of improvements and the relationship to the right-of-way line. 
(c)  Within 14 days of receiving a permit application to install a small wireless facility and any accessory equipment, the city shall notify the applicant by electronic mail as to whether the application is complete or the application will be deemed complete. The city shall have 60 days from receipt of a completed application to complete the review for compliance with applicable regulations. If the city does not use the 30-day negotiation period provided for in subparagraph (d) relative to the placement of small wireless facilities as provided for in subsection (d), the parties may agree to extend the review period. The city shall grant or deny the permit at the end of the extended period. The city shall notify the applicant of approval or denial by electronic mail. If the application is denied, the city shall notify the applicant the specific basis for the denial, including code provisions. The applicant may cure any deficiencies within 30 days of the date the denial notice was sent. The city shall approve or deny the revised application within 30 days of receipt of the revised application. A permit that is issued shall be effective for one year unless extended by the city. 
(d)  The city may not limit the placement of small wireless facilities on a specific utility pole or category of poles or require multiple antenna systems on a single utility pole. Within 14 days after the date of filing the application, the city may request the proposed location of a small wireless facility be moved to another location in the right-of-way and placed on an alternative authority utility pole. The city and the applicant may negotiate an alternative location including objective design standards and reasonable spacing requirements for ground based equipment for 30 days after the date of the request. At the conclusion of the negotiation period, if the alternative location is accepted by the applicant, the applicant must notify the authority of such acceptance and the application shall be deemed granted for any new location for which there is agreement. If an agreement is not reached, the applicant must notify the city of such non agreement and the authority must grant or deny the original application within 90 days after the date the application was filed. A request for an alternative location, an acceptance of an alternative location, or a rejection of an alternative location must be in writing and provided by electronic mail. 
(e)  The city shall consider the following objective design standards for small wireless facilities: 
(1)  The maximum height of a small wireless facility is ten feet above the utility pole or structure upon which the small wireless facility is to be collocated. The height for a new utility pole is limited to the tallest utility pole as of July 1, 2017 located in the same right-of-way other than a utility pole for which a waiver was previously granted measured from grade in place within 500 feet of the proposed location of the small wireless facility. If there is no utility pole within 500 feet, the maximum height for a utility pole is 50 feet. 
(2)  Each antenna associated with the facility is located inside an enclosure of no more than six cubic feet in volume or in the case of antennas that have exposed elements, each antenna and all of its exposed elements could fit within an enclosure of no more than six cubic feet in volume. 
(3)  Small wireless facilities shall use camouflage techniques, approved by the city, which incorporate architectural treatments to blend in aesthetically with the surrounding environment. 
(4)  Other wireless equipment associated with the facility shall not exceed 28 cubic feet in volume. The following types of ancillary equipment are not included in the volume calculation: electric meters, concealment elements, telecommunications demarcation boxes, ground based enclosures, grounding equipment, power transfer switches, cutoff switches, vertical cable runs, and utility poles or other support structures. 
(5)  New and replacement wireless support structures shall match the style, design, and color of existing utility poles in the vicinity unless approved by the city. 
(6)  Ground-based equipment boxes that support wireless facilities shall match the style, design and color of existing equipment boxes in the surrounding area. Foliage or another aesthetic features to obscure the view shall be used to the greatest extent possible to allow the boxes to blend in with the surrounding area. 
(7)  New utility poles to support wireless facilities shall not be permitted on Main Street within the community redevelopment district or in other areas where utilities are underground or contiguous to sites designated a local historic district. 
(8)  The rate to collocate small wireless facilities on a city utility pole may not exceed $150.00 per pole annually. 
(f)  All communications facilities shall be placed or maintained so as not to unreasonably interfere with the use of the public rights-of-way by the public and with the rights and convenience of property owners who adjoin any of the public rights-of-way. The use of trench-less technology (i.e., directional bore method) for the installation of facilities in the public rights-of-way as well as joint trenching or the co-location of facilities in existing conduit is strongly encouraged, and should be employed wherever feasible. The city may promulgate reasonable rules and regulations concerning the placement or maintenance of a communications facility in public rights-of-way consistent with this article and other applicable law. 
(g)  All safety practices required by applicable law or accepted industry practices and standards shall be used during the placement or maintenance of communications facilities. 
(h)  After the completion of any placement or maintenance of a communications facility in public rights-of-way or each phase thereof, a registrant shall, at its own expense, restore the public rights-of-way to its original condition as it was before such work. If the registrant fails to make such restoration within 30 days, the city may perform restoration and charge the costs of the restoration against the registrant in accordance with F.S. § 337.402, as it may be amended. For 12 months following the original completion of the work, the registrant shall guarantee its restoration work and shall correct any restoration work that does not satisfy the requirements of this article at its own expense. 
(i)  Removal or relocation done at the direction of the city of a registrant's communications facility in public rights-of-way shall be governed by the provisions of F.S. § 337.403 and 337.404, as it may be amended. 
(j)  A permit from the city constitutes authorization to undertake only certain activities in public rights-of-way in accordance with this article, and does not create a property right or grant authority to impinge upon the rights of others who may have an interest in the public rights-of-way. 
(k)  A registrant shall maintain its communications facility in public rights-of-way in a manner consistent with accepted industry practice and applicable law.
