Registrant shall use and exercise due caution, care and skill in performing work in the public rights-of-way and shall take all reasonable steps to safeguard work site areas. 
(l)  In connection with excavation in the public rights-of-way, a registrant shall, where applicable, comply with the Underground Facility Damage Prevention and Safety Act set forth in F.S. ch. 556, as it may be amended. 
(m)  Upon request of the city, and as notified by the city of the other work, construction, installation or repairs referenced below, a registrant may be required to coordinate placement or maintenance activities under a permit with any other work, construction, installation or repairs that may be occurring or scheduled to occur within a reasonable time-frame in the subject public rights-of-way, and registrant may be required to reasonably alter its placement or maintenance schedule as necessary so as to minimize disruptions and disturbance in the public rights-of-way. 
(n)  A registrant shall not place or maintain its communications facilities so as to interfere with, displace, damage or destroy any facilities, including but not limited to, sewers, gas or water mains, storm drains, pipes, cables or conduits of the city or any other person's facilities lawfully occupying the public rights-of-way of the city. 
(o)  The city makes no warranties or representations regarding the fitness, suitability, or availability of city public rights-of-way for the registrant's communications facilities and any performance of work, costs incurred or services provided by registrant shall be at registrant's sole risk. Nothing in this article shall affect the city authority to add, vacate or abandon public rights-of-way, and city makes no warranties or representations regarding the availability of any added, vacated or abandoned public rights-of-way for communications facilities. 
(p)  The city shall have the right to make such inspections of communications facilities placed or maintained in public rights-of-way as it finds necessary to ensure compliance with this article. 
(q)  The city reserves the right to place and maintain, and permit to be placed or maintained, sewer, gas, water, electric, storm drainage, communications, and other types of facilities, cables or conduit, and to do, and to permit to be done, any underground and overhead installation or improvement that may be deemed necessary or proper by the city in public rights-of-way occupied by the registrant. The city further reserves without limitation the right to alter, change, or cause to be changed, the grading, installation, relocation, or width of the public rights-of-way within the limits of the city and within said limits as same may from time to time be altered. 
(r)  A registrant shall, on the request of any person holding a permit issued by the city, temporarily raise or lower its communications facilities to permit the work authorized by the permit. The expense of such temporary raising or lowering of facilities shall be paid by the person requesting the same, and the registrant shall have the authority to require such payment in advance. The registrant shall be given not less than 30 days' advance written notice to arrange for such temporary relocation. 
(s)  A registrant who intends to place an antenna in the public rights-of-way shall be required to comply with section 63.00 through section 63.07 of the City of Safety Harbor Comprehensive Zoning and Land Development Code. 
(t)  The city may deny a proposed collocation of a small wireless facility in the city rights-of-way if the proposed collocation: 
(1)  Materially interferes with the sight lines or clear zones for transportation, pedestrians, or public safety purposes. 
(2)  Materially interferes with the sight lines or clear zones for transportation, pedestrians, or public safety purpose. 
(3)  Materially interferes with compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act or similar federal or state standards regarding pedestrian access or movement. 
(4)  Materially fails to comply with the 2010 edition of the Florida Department of Transportation Utility Accommodation Manual. 
(5)  Fails to comply with applicable codes included in section 20.93 above. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003; Ord. No. 2016-08, § 2, 6-6-2016; Ord. No. 2017-32, § 4, 10-16-2017)  
Sec. 20.94. - Termination of registration. 
The city may terminate a registration if: 
(1)  A federal or state authority suspends, denies, or revokes a registrant's certification or license to provide communications services; or 
(2)  The registrant's placement or maintenance of a communications facility in the public rights-of-way presents an extraordinary danger to the general public or other users of the public rights-of-way and the registrant fails to remedy the danger promptly after receipt of written notice; or 
(3)  The registrant ceases to use all of its communications facilities in public rights-of-way and has not complied with subsection 20.91(c) of this article. 
Prior to termination, the registrant shall be notified by the city manager or his or her designee with a written notice setting forth all matters pertinent to the proposed termination action. The registrant shall have sixty (30) days after receipt of such notice within which to address or eliminate the reason or within which to present a plan, satisfactory to the city manager or his or her designee, to accomplish the same. If the plan is rejected, the city manager shall provide written notice of such termination. 
In the event of termination, the former registrant shall: (a) notify the city of the assumption or anticipated assumption by another registrant of ownership of the registrant's communications facilities in public rights-of-way; or (b) provide the city with an acceptable plan for disposition of its communications facilities in public rights-of-way and restoration of the public rights-of-way. If a registrant fails to comply, the city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity including but not limited to the removal of some or all of the facilities from the public rights-of-way and restore the public rights-of-way to its original condition before the removal. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003)  
Sec. 20.95. - Existing communications facilities in public rights-of-way. 
A communications services provider, wireless services provider, or wireless infrastructure provider, with an existing communications facility in the public rights-of-way of the city has 60 days from the effective date of this article to comply with the terms of this article, including, but not limited to, registration, or be in violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003; Ord. No. 2017-32, § 5, 10-16-2017)  
Sec. 20.96. - Insurance. 
A registrant shall provide, pay for and maintain satisfactory to the city the types of insurance described herein. All insurance shall be from responsible companies duly authorized to do business in the state and having a rating reasonably acceptable to the city. The insurance requirements may be satisfied by evidence of self-insurance or other types of insurance acceptable to the city. 
The limits of coverage of insurance required shall be not less than the following: 
(1)  Worker's compensation and employer's liability insurance. 
Worker's compensation—Florida statutory requirements. 
Employer's liability—$500,000.00 limit each accident. 
$500,000.00 limit per accident. 
$500,000.00 limit per each employee. 
(2)  Comprehensive general liability. 
Bodily injury and property damage—$500,000.00 combined single limit each occurrence. 
(3)  Automobile liability. 
Bodily injury and property damage—$ 500,000.00 combined single limit each accident. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003)  
Sec. 20.97. - Indemnification. 
A registrant shall, at its sole cost and expense, indemnify, hold harmless, and defend the city, its officials, boards, members, agents, and employees, against any and all claims, suits, causes of action, proceedings, judgments for damages or equitable relief, and costs and expenses incurred by the city arising out of the placement or maintenance of its communications system or facilities in public rights-of-way, regardless of whether the act or omission complained of is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this article, provided, however, that a registrant's obligation hereunder shall not extend to any claims caused by the negligence, gross negligence or wanton or willful acts of the city. This provision includes, but is not limited to, the city reasonable attorneys' fees incurred in defending against any such claim, suit or proceedings. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed or interpreted: (a) as denying to either party any remedy or defense available to such party under the laws of the state; or (b) as a waiver of sovereign immunity beyond the waiver provided in Section 768.28, Florida Statutes (2002), as it may be amended. The indemnification requirements shall survive and be in effect after the termination or cancellation of a registration. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003)  
Sec. 20.98. - Appeals. 
Final, written decisions of the city manager or his or her designee suspending or denying a permit, denying an application for a registration or denying an application for renewal of a registration are subject to appeal. An appeal must be filed with the city manager or his/her designee within thirty (30) days of the date of the final, written decision to be appealed. Any appeal not timely filed as set forth above shall be waived. The appeal shall be reviewed pursuant to section 20.13, City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003)  
Sec. 20.99. - Enforcement. 
A registrant's failure to comply with provisions of this article shall constitute a violation of this article and shall subject the registrant to the code enforcement provisions and procedures as provided in the City Code, section 1.12. In addition, a violation of this article may be punishable as provided by the City Code or applicable Florida Law. 
Failure of the city to enforce any requirements of this article shall not constitute a waiver of the city's right to enforce that violation or subsequent violations of the same type or to seek appropriate enforcement remedies. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003)  
Sec. 20.100. - Abandonment of a communications facility. 
Upon abandonment of a communications facility owned by a registrant in public rights-of-way, the registrant shall notify the city within ninety (90) days. 
The registrant shall remove the abandoned facility at the registrant's sole expense if the within one hundred eighty (180) days of abandonment unless the city grants in writing, at its sole discretion, permission for the abandoned facility to remain in the rights-of-way. The registrant may request an extension, in writing, of this time frame for good cause. 
If the registrant fails to remove all or any portion of an abandoned facility within this time frame or obtain written permission from the city may perform such removal and charge the cost of the removal against the registrant. 
(Ord. No. 2003-07, § 1, 4-21-2003)  
Secs. 20.101—20.120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE X. - STREET LIGHTING SERVICES AND FACILITIES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-20, adopted Dec. 17, 2012, did not specifically amend this Code. At the discretion of the editor, these provisions have been included as Art. X, §§ 20.121—20.148, to read as set out herein. 
 
DIVISION 1. - INTRODUCTION 
 
Sec. 20.121. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly otherwise requires: 
Annual resolution means the resolution described in division 2 hereof, establishing the rate at which the street lighting services and facilities charges for a specific fiscal year will be computed; and the adoption of which shall be the final proceeding for the imposition of street lighting services and facilities charges, and as applicable in the form of special or non-ad valorem assessments, to fund street lighting services and facilities. 
Assessment coordinator means the city manager, or such person's designee, responsible for coordinating the calculation and collection of street lighting services and facilities charges as provided herein. 
City means the City of Safety Harbor, Florida. 
City clerk means the clerk to the city commission, or such person's designee. 
City commission means the governing body of the City of Safety Harbor, Florida. 
City manager means the chief administrative office of the city. 
Fiscal year means that period commencing October 1 of each year and continuing through the next succeeding September 30, or such other period as may be prescribed by law as the fiscal year for the city. 
Ordinance means this article. 
Property appraiser means the property appraiser of Pinellas County, Florida. 
Street lighting cost means the cost of providing street lighting services and facilities for any fiscal year, all or a portion of which will be funded through the imposition of street lighting services and facilities charges. 
Street lighting roll means the list of tax parcels subject to the street lighting services and facilities charges contemplated hereunder. 
Street lighting services and facilities charges or charges means the utility associated charges imposed by the city commission pursuant to this article to fund all or a portion of the street lighting cost. Such charges shall meet the legal requirements of a special assessment under Florida law, and when required or determined necessary, be imposed and collected as same. 
Tax collector means the tax collector of Pinellas County, Florida. 
Tax parcel means a parcel of property to which the property appraiser has assigned a distinct ad valorem property tax identification number. 
Tax roll means the real property ad valorem tax roll and database maintained by the property appraiser for the purpose of the levy and collection of ad valorem taxes. 
Uniform Assessment Collection Act means F.S. §§ 197.3632 and 197.3635, or any successor statutes authorizing the collection of non-ad valorem assessments on the same bill as ad valorem taxes, and any applicable regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 1.01, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.122. - Interpretation. 
Unless the context indicates otherwise, words importing the singular number include the plural number, and vice versa; the terms "hereof," "hereby," "herein," "hereto," "hereunder" and similar terms refer to this article; and the term "hereafter" means after, and the term "heretofore" means before, the effective date of this article. Words of any gender include the correlative words of the other gender, unless the sense indicates otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 1.02, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.123. - Findings. 
It is hereby ascertained, determined, and declared that: 
(1)  Pursuant to Article VIII, Section 2(b) of the Florida Constitution, and F.S. §§ 166.021 and 166.041, the city commission has all powers of local self-government to perform municipal functions and render municipal services except when expressly prohibited by law and such power may be exercised by the enactment of city ordinances. 
(2)  The city commission may exercise any governmental, corporate, or proprietary power for a municipal purpose except when expressly prohibited by law, and the city commission may legislate on any subject matter on which the Florida Legislature may act, except those subjects described in (a), (b), (c), and (d) of F.S. § 166.021(3). The subject matter of paragraphs (a), (b), (c), and (d) of F.S. § 166.021(3), is not relevant to imposition of the street lighting services and facilities charges contemplated hereunder. 
(3)  The special benefits conveyed by the street lighting services and facilities funded by street lighting services and facilities charges include, by way of example and not limitation, the protection and enhancement of parcel value, and enhanced use and enjoyment of parcels adjacent to or near street lighting. 
(4)  The provision of street lighting services and facilities and the operation and maintenance of street lighting provides better property identification and recognition, and enhances the safe accessibility of affected tax parcels. 
(5)  Street lighting services and facilities charges imposed pursuant to this article are imposed by the city commission, not the property appraiser or tax collector. Any activity of the property appraiser or tax collector under the provisions of this article shall be construed as ministerial. 
(6)  The street lighting services and facilities charges imposed hereunder meet the fundamental legal requirements to also constitute special assessments and non-ad valorem assessments within the meaning of the Uniform Assessment Collection Act. 
(7)  The street lighting services and facilities charges to be imposed pursuant to this article provide benefits logically related to the tax parcels served, are otherwise authorized by law, and represent a just and equitable method of funding all or a portion of the costs incurred by the city in providing street lighting services and facilities to affected tax parcels and paying for, inter alia, associated power, equipment and maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 1.03, 12-17-2012)  
Secs. 20.124, 20.125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - STREET LIGHTING SERVICES AND FACILITIES CHARGES 
 
Sec. 20.126. - General authority. 
(a)  The city commission is hereby authorized to impose street lighting services and facilities charges to fund all or any portion of the street lighting cost upon benefitted property at a rate based on the special benefit accruing to such property from the city's provision of street lighting services and facilities. All street lighting services and facilities charges shall be imposed in conformity with the procedures set forth in this division 2. 
(b)  The amount of the street lighting services and facilities charges imposed each fiscal year against each tax parcel shall be determined pursuant to an apportionment methodology based upon a fair and reasonable apportionment of the street lighting cost among properties on a basis reasonably related to the special benefit provided by street lighting services and facilities funded with street lighting services and facilities charges proceeds. The calculation of the amount of the annual street lighting services and facilities charges imposed each fiscal year shall include administration and collection costs associated with the annual street lighting services and facilities charges. In the event the street lighting services and facilities charges are collected pursuant to the Uniform Assessment Collection Act, the calculation of the amount of the annual street lighting services and facilities charges shall include the fees and charges imposed by the property appraiser and tax collector, and shall be adjusted as necessary to account for any statutory discounts which are necessitated when employing the efficiencies of collecting the street lighting services and facilities charges annually on the same bill as property taxes. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.01, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.127. - Proceedings. 
The proceedings for the imposition of street lighting services and facilities charges shall include a public hearing noticed in the manner set forth in section 20.129 hereof, and the adoption at such public hearing or anytime thereafter of an annual resolution which shall (a) contain a brief and general description of the street lighting services and facilities to be provided or made available, (b) describe the method or methods of apportioning the street lighting cost among affected tax parcels, (c) describe the tax parcels, if any, to be exempted from the street lighting services and facilities charges for legal or public policy purposes, (d) identify the rate or rates of the street lighting services and facilities charges and approve and adopt the annual street lighting roll, consistent with the requirements of section 20.128 hereof, and (e) determine the method or methods of collecting the street lighting services and facilities charges. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.02, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.128. - Street lighting roll. 
(a)  The assessment coordinator shall prepare, or direct the preparation of, the street lighting roll, which shall contain the following: 
(1)  A summary description of the tax parcels subject to the street lighting services and facilities charges conforming to the description contained on the tax roll. 
(2)  The name of the owner of the tax parcel. 
(3)  The extension or application of the rates of the proposed street lighting services and facilities charges to be imposed against each such tax parcel. 
(b)  The street lighting and facilities charges also meet the minimum requirements for a valid fee because such charges fund governmental services and facilities for which the property owner's activity or land use creates the need for the services and facilities. 
(c)  The street lighting roll shall be retained by the assessment coordinator and shall be open to public inspection. The foregoing shall not be construed to require that the street lighting roll be in printed form if the amount of the street lighting services and facilities charges for each tax parcel of property can be determined by use of the internet, a computer terminal available to the public or similar technology available to the public. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.03, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.129. - Notice. 
(a)  At least ten (10) days prior to the public hearing, the city shall publish notice of the public hearing in a newspaper generally circulated within the boundaries of the city. The notice shall provide the date, time and place of the hearing. The notice shall contain a general statement that the city commission will consider imposing street lighting services and facilities charges on various parcels of property within the city to fund all or a portion of the cost to provide street lighting services and facilities, the proposed rates or explanation of the schedule of street lighting services and facilities charges and include general information pertaining to the proposed apportionment methodology, the method of collection and a statement that all affected property owners have a right to appear at the public hearing and have the right to file written objections before or at the public hearing. The notice shall direct all interested persons to the street lighting roll and information concerning the amount of the proposed charge applicable to each parcel of property; provided, however, that such street lighting roll need not be in printed form if the amount of the street lighting services and facilities charge for each parcel of property can be determined by use of the internet, a computer terminal available to the public, or similar technology available to the public. 
(b)  In its sole discretion, the city may additionally and supplementally post the street lighting roll on the city website, or direct constituents by hyperlink or other device to an internet address or site where the street light roll may be reviewed. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.04, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.130. - Annual resolution. 
At the time named in such notice, or to which an adjournment or continuance may be taken by the city commission, the city commission shall receive any oral or written comments or objections of interested persons and may then, or at any subsequent meeting of the city commission, adopt the annual resolution which shall (a) establish the rate or rates of the street lighting services and facilities charges to be imposed in the designated fiscal year, or any portion thereof; (b) approve and adopt the street lighting roll, with such amendments and directions as it deems just and right; and (c) provide direction as to the method of collection. All tax parcels subject to the street lighting services and facilities charges shall derive a special benefit from the provision of street lighting services and facilities to be funded by the street lighting services and facilities charges, and such charges shall be fairly and reasonably apportioned among the tax parcels that receive the special benefit. All objections to the annual resolution shall be made in writing, and filed with the assessment coordinator at or before the time or adjourned time of such hearing. Adoption of the annual resolution shall constitute the final action necessary annually to impose or re-impose street lighting services and facilities charges hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.05, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.131. - Effect of annual assessment resolution. 
The street lighting services and facilities charges for the initial fiscal year and each subsequent fiscal year shall be established upon adoption of the annual resolution. The adoption of the annual resolution shall be the final adjudication of the issues presented (including, but not limited to, the amounts of the street lighting cost budgeted, the method of apportioning the street lighting cost, the rate or rates of street lighting services and facilities charges, the street lighting roll, and the levy and lien of the street lighting services and facilities charges), unless proper steps shall be initiated in a court of competent jurisdiction to secure relief within twenty (20) days from the date of the city commission action adopting the annual resolution. The initial street lighting roll, as approved by the annual resolution, shall be delivered for collection using the utility bill collection method described in section 20.142 hereof, or such other method as the city commission by resolution may designate. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.06, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.132. - Adoption of subsequent annual assessment resolutions. 
The city commission may adopt subsequent annual resolutions as a part of and during its budget adoption process for each fiscal year following the initial fiscal year for which street lighting services and facilities charges are imposed hereunder. The annual resolution shall approve the street lighting roll for the upcoming fiscal year. The street lighting roll may be prepared in accordance with the methods of apportionment set forth in the prior annual resolution but may include modifications as a matter of policy as to what, if any, portion or portions of the city's budget is paid for from legally available funds other than street lighting services and facilities charges revenues. Failure to adopt an annual resolution during the budget adoption process may be cured at any time. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.07, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.133. - Lien of street lighting services and facilities charges. 
Upon the adoption of the street lighting roll, all street lighting services and facilities charges constitute a special assessment, and are a lien against each property charged and assessed equal in rank and dignity with the liens of all state, county, district, or municipal taxes and other special or non-ad valorem assessments. Except as otherwise provided by law, until paid such lien shall be superior in dignity to all other prior liens, mortgages, titles, and claims. The lien for street lighting services and facilities charges shall be deemed perfected upon adoption by the city commission of the annual resolution. The lien for street lighting services and facilities charges collected under the uniform assessment collection method shall attach to the property included on the street lighting roll as of the prior January 1, the lien date for ad valorem taxes imposed under the tax roll. The lien for street lighting services and facilities charges collected under the utility bill method of collection shall be deemed perfected upon adoption by the city commission of the annual resolution and shall attach to the property on the date of each such annual resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.08, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.134. - Revisions to street lighting services and facilities charges. 
If any street lighting services and facilities charges made pursuant to this article are either in whole or in part annulled, vacated, or set aside by the judgment of any court, or if the city commission is satisfied that any such charges are so irregular or defective that the same cannot be enforced or collected, or if the city commission has omitted any property on the street lighting roll which property should have been so included, the city commission may take all necessary steps to impose a new charge in the form of a special assessment against any property benefited by street lighting services and facilities, following as nearly as may be practicable, the provisions of this article and in case such second street lighting services and facilities charges are annulled, vacated, or set aside, the city commission may obtain and impose other street lighting services and facilities charges until a valid charge in the form of a special assessment is imposed. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.09, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.135. - Procedural irregularities. 
Any informality or irregularity in the proceedings in connection with the levy of any street lighting services and facilities charges pursuant to this article shall not affect the validity of the same as a special assessment after the approval thereof, and any street lighting services and facilities charges as finally approved shall be competent and substantial evidence that such street lighting services and facilities charges were duly levied, that the street lighting services and facilities charges in the form of a special assessment were duly made and adopted, and that all other proceedings adequate to such charges in the form of a special assessment were duly had, taken, and performed as required by this article; and no variance from the directions hereunder shall be held material unless it be clearly shown that the party objecting was materially injured thereby. Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, any party objecting to street lighting services and facilities charges imposed pursuant to this article must file an objection with a court of competent jurisdiction within the time periods prescribed herein. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.10, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.136. - Correction of errors and omissions. 
(a)  No act of error or omission on the part of the property appraiser, tax collector, assessment coordinator, city commission, or their deputies, employees, or agents shall operate to release or discharge any obligation for payment of street lighting services and facilities charges imposed by the city commission pursuant to this article. 
(b)  When it shall appear that any street lighting services and facilities charges should have been imposed pursuant to this article against a parcel of property specially benefited by the provision of street lighting services and facilities, but that such property was omitted from the street lighting roll, the city commission may, upon provision of (i) notice to the owner by first class mail, and (ii) an opportunity for the owner to be heard before the assessment coordinator, impose the applicable street lighting services and facilities charges for the fiscal year in which such error is discovered, in addition to the applicable street lighting services and facilities charges due for the prior fiscal year. Such total street lighting services and facilities charges shall become delinquent if not fully paid upon the expiration of sixty (60) days from the date of such notice. The street lighting services and facilities charges so imposed shall constitute a lien against such property equal in rank and dignity with the liens of all state, county, district, or municipal taxes and non-ad valorem assessments, and superior in rank and dignity to all other prior liens, mortgages, titles and claims in and to or against the real property involved and may be collected as provided in division 3 hereof. 
(c)  The assessment coordinator shall have the authority at any time, upon his or her own initiative or in response to a timely filed petition from the owner of any property subject to street lighting services and facilities charges, based upon presentation of competent and substantial evidence, to correct any error in applying the rate of the street lighting services and facilities charges, or the applicable apportionment method to any particular parcel of property, not otherwise requiring the provision of mailed notice pursuant to this article or the Uniform Assessment Collection Act. Additionally, because the size and nature of the tax roll may yield anomalies, the assessment coordinator is authorized to apply sound public administration judgment and delete or remove individual tax parcels from the street lighting roll that due to specific circumstances do not receive a special benefit, are not developable (e.g. subsurface rights, submerged, slivers, right-of-way, common elements) or are reasonably determined to be inappropriate, infeasible or impracticable to include on the street lighting roll, and do not merit the expenditure of public funds and resources to impose or collect such street lighting services and facilities charges. Any such corrections shall be considered valid ab initio and shall in no way otherwise affect the enforcement of the street lighting services and facilities charges. All requests from affected property owners for any such changes, modifications or corrections shall be referred to, and processed by, the assessment coordinator and not the property appraiser or tax collector. 
(d)  After the street lighting roll has been delivered to the tax collector in accordance with the Uniform Assessment Collection Act, any changes, modifications, or corrections thereto shall be made in accordance with the procedures applicable to correcting errors and insolvencies on the tax roll upon timely written request and direction of the assessment coordinator. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 2.11, 12-17-2012)  
Secs. 20.137—20.140. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - COLLECTION OF STREET LIGHTING SERVICES AND FACILITIES CHARGES 
 
Sec. 20.141. - Collection. 
(a)  The process of collection is driven by many equitable, practical legal and economic factors. The utility bill collection method is cost efficient and takes advantage of the existing utility billing system employed by the city for its water and sewer utility system. 
(b)  Unless otherwise directed by the city commission, the street lighting services and facilities charges shall be collected pursuant to the utility bill collection method. Any hearing or notice required by this article may be combined with any other hearing or notice required by this article or the Uniform Assessment Collection Act. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 3.01, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.142. - Utility bill collection method. 
The city may elect to collect the street lighting services and facilities charges by any other method which is authorized by law, or provided by this section as follows: 
(1)  The city shall divide the annual street lighting services and facilities charges for any given fiscal year into monthly installments and collect each installment on the water and sewer utility bill mailed each month by the city. 
(2)  Payment of the monthly installment of the street lighting services and facilities charges shall be due at the same time and in the same manner as any other fee or charge appearing on the utility bill; provided, however, that in the event a monthly payment is received for less than the full amount due and owing on the utility bill, such payment shall be applied first toward the balance of the street lighting services and facilities charges then outstanding, then toward the balance of any stormwater, sanitation and recycling fees appearing on such utility bill and then outstanding, and the balance shall be applied toward any sewer and water charges appearing on such utility bill and then outstanding. 
(3)  In the event of non-payment of the street lighting services and facilities charges, the city may initiate collection procedures including filing a notice of lien on the subject property for the balance due or enforce collection through any other method allowed or provided by law. 
(4)  The city shall have the right to appoint or retain an agent to foreclose and collect all delinquent street lighting services and facilities charges in any manner allowed or provided by law. 
(5)  Payment of delinquent street lighting services and facilities charges may be enforced in any manner authorized by law, including but not limited to (i) termination of unpaid water utility service as and in the event of underpayment or non-payment of the entire payment due on the utility bill, (ii) foreclosure action or suit in equity and causing the foreclosure of such property in a method now or hereafter provided by law for foreclosure of mortgages on real property, and/or (iii); causing an amount equivalent to the delinquent street lighting services and facilities charges, not previously subject to collection using the uniform method of collection under the Uniform Assessment Collection Act, to be collected on the tax bill for a subsequent year. Any delinquent street lighting services and facilities charges and the costs, fees and expenses otherwise reasonably attributable to an affected tax parcel, may be collected subsequently pursuant to the Uniform Assessment Collection Act; provided however, that (1) notice is provided to the owner in the manner required by the Uniform Assessment Collection Act and this article, and (2) any existing lien of record on the affected tax parcel for the delinquent street lighting services and facilities charges are supplanted by the lien resulting from certification of the street lighting roll, as applicable, to the tax collector. 
(6)  All costs, fees and expenses, including reasonable attorney fees and title search expenses, related to any collection expenses, or foreclosure action as described herein shall be included in any pay-off or settlement, or judgment or decree rendered therein. At the sale pursuant to decree in any such action, the city may be the purchaser to the same extent as an individual person or corporation. The city may join in one (1) collection or foreclosure action the collection of street lighting services and facilities charges against any or all property subject thereto in accordance with the provisions hereof. All delinquent owners whose property is subjected to collection for amounts past due or foreclosed shall be liable for an apportioned amount of reasonable costs and expenses incurred by the city and its agents, including reasonable attorney fees, in collection of such delinquent street lighting services and facilities charges and any other costs incurred by the city as a result of such delinquent street lighting services and facilities charges and the same shall be collectible as a part of or in addition to, the costs of such actions. 
(7)  Any city commission action required in the collection of street lighting services and facilities charges may be by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 3.02, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.143. - Alternative collection authority; use of Uniform Assessment Collection Act. 
(a)  As an alternative to the utility bill collection method set forth in section 20.142 hereof, the city commission may decide to collect all or part of the street lighting roll and applicable street lighting services and facilities charges pursuant to any lawful collection method, including but not limited to the uniform method of collection provided for in the Uniform Assessment Collection Act; provided, however that all of the procedures required by the Uniform Assessment Collection Act can be and are timely complied with. Any alternative collection method may be authorized by resolution. 
(b)  If the city commission decides to use the uniform method of collection provided for in the Uniform Assessment Collection Act, the assessment coordinator shall publish notice which shall conform to the requirements set forth in the Uniform Assessment Collection Act and, in addition to the requirements set forth in this article, the assessment coordinator shall provide notice of the proposed street lighting services and facilities charges by first class mail to the owner of each parcel of property subject to the street lighting services and facilities charges which shall conform to the requirements set forth in the Uniform Assessment Collection Act. Such mailed notice may be provided by including the street lighting services and facilities charges in the property appraiser's notice of proposed property taxes and proposed or adopted non-ad valorem street lighting services and facilities charges under F.S. § 200.069, or its successor in function. The assessment coordinator may provide proof of any notice provided in conjunction with this article by affidavit. Failure of the owner to receive notice due to mistake or inadvertence shall nevertheless not affect the validity of the street lighting roll nor release or discharge any obligation for payment of street lighting services and facilities charges imposed by the city commission pursuant to this article. 
(c)  The city commission may also establish by resolution such reasonable procedures or directions to confirm and comply with the Uniform Assessment Collection Act, or any other lawful collection method, as may be practicable and necessary. 
(d)  The city commission may establish by resolution a maximum rate of street lighting services and facilities charges provided that notice of such maximum rate is, when applicable, provided pursuant to the Uniform Assessment Collection Act. The failure of the owner to receive such notice due to mistake or inadvertence shall not affect the validity of the street lighting roll nor release or discharge any obligation for payment of street lighting services and facilities charges imposed by the city commission pursuant to this article. 
(e)  The street lighting roll, as approved by the annual resolution, shall be certified and, when applicable, delivered to the tax collector as required by the Uniform Assessment Collection Act. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 3.03, 12-17-2012)  
Secs. 20.144, 20.145. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 20.146. - Applicability. 
This article achieves a paramount public purpose and provides for the health, safety and welfare of the community and its property owners. The city's authority to impose street lighting services and facilities charges pursuant hereto shall be applicable throughout the city. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 4.01, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.147. - Severability. 
The provisions of this article are severable; and if any section, subsection, sentence, clause or provision is held invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions of this article shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 4.02, 12-17-2012)  
Sec. 20.148. - Alternative method. 
This article shall be deemed to provide an additional and alternative method for the doing of the things authorized hereby and shall be regarded as supplemental and additional to powers conferred by other laws, and shall not be regarded as in derogation of any powers now existing or which may hereafter come into existence. This article, being necessary for the welfare of the inhabitants of the city, shall be liberally construed to effect the purposes hereof. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 4.03, 12-17-2012)
