Chapter 22 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; finance, Ch. 7; local business tax receipts, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference— Municipal finance and taxation, F.S. § 166.201 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC SERVICE TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Public service tax authorized, F.S. §§ 166.231 and 166.232. 
 
Sec. 22.01. - Levy. 
(a)  There is hereby levied by the city on each and every sale in the city of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural or manufactured), and a tax based upon the charge made by the seller of ten (10) percent of such charge, which tax shall, in every case, be paid by the purchaser, for the use of the city, to the seller of such electricity, gas or such metered or bottled gas (natural or manufactured), at the time of paying the charge therefor to the seller thereof, but not less often than monthly. 
(b)  There is hereby levied by the city on each and every sale in the city of local telephone service and intrastate telephone toll service and other telephone service taxable under Florida Statutes 166.231, a tax based upon the charge made by the seller of seven (7) percent of such charge, which tax shall, in every case be paid by the purchaser for the use of the city, to the seller of such local telephone service or intrastate toll service at the time of paying the charge therefor to the seller thereof, but not less often than monthly. 
(Code 1970, § 23-14; Ord. No. 85-72, § 1, 11-18-85)  
Sec. 22.02. - Collection. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural or manufactured), or local telephone service, to collect from the purchaser, for the use of the city, the tax hereby levied, at the time of collecting the selling price charged for each transaction, and to report and pay over, on or before the fifteenth day of each calendar month, unto the treasurer of the city, all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding calendar month. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any seller to collect the price of any sale of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural or manufactured), or telephone service, without, at the same time, collecting the tax hereby levied in respect to such sale or sales, unless such seller shall elect to assume and pay such tax without collecting the same from the purchaser. 
(c)  Any seller failing to collect such tax at the time of collecting the price of any sale, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax, shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax in like manner as if the same had been actually paid to the seller, and the city manager shall cause to be brought all suits and actions and to take all proceedings in the name of the city as may be necessary for the recovery of such tax. The seller shall not be liable for the payment of such tax upon uncollected bills. 
(d)  If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay to the seller, the seller's the charge, and the tax hereby imposed and as hereby required, on account of the sale for which such charge is made, or either, the seller shall have and is hereby vested with the right, power and authority to immediately discontinue further service to such purchaser until the tax and the seller's bill shall have been paid in full. 
(Code 1970, § 23-15)  
Sec. 22.03. - Records of seller; inspection by city. 
Each and every seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural or manufactured), and local telephone service shall keep complete records showing all sales in the city of such commodities or service, which records shall show the price charged upon each sale, the date thereof, and the date of payment therefor. The records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city during business hours on all business days. The duly authorized agents of the city shall have the right, power and authority to make such transcripts thereof during such times as they may desire. 
(Code 1970, § 23-16)  
Sec. 22.04. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The United States of America, State of Florida, and political subdivisions and agencies thereof are hereby exempted from payment of the taxes hereby imposed. 
(b)  The tax shall not apply to sales of long distance telephone service or to coin box telephones. 
(c)  The tax shall not apply to the "increase base" and the "fuel adjustment charge" related to the sale of electricity. All other associated charges, including any additional charges added to the fuel charge, shall be taxed. 
(d)  Purchases by any recognized church in the state for use exclusively for church purposes are exempt. 
(Code 1970, § 23-17; Ord. No. 97-25, § 1, 12-1-97)  
Sec. 22.05. - Computation of tax. 
In all cases where the seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural or manufactured), or local telephone service collects the price thereof at monthly periods, the tax hereby levied may be computed on the aggregate amount of sales during such period, provided that the amount of tax to be collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Code 1970, § 23-18)  
Sec. 22.06. - Failure or refusal to collect or pay tax. 
Any purchaser wilfully failing or refusing to pay the tax hereby imposed, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax, and any seller violating the provisions hereof, or any officer, agent, or employee of any seller violating the provisions hereof, shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or imprisonment for not more than ten (10) days, or to both such fine and imprisonment for each and every violation, in the discretion of the judge. 
(Code 1970, § 23-19)  
Sec. 22.07. - Disposition of revenues collected. 
All revenue received, collected and derived from the taxes levied by this article shall be deposited by the treasurer of the city in its general operating account, and is hereby appropriated for the uses and purposes set forth in the annual operating budget for each fiscal year during which this article remains in effect. The taxes shall be included from year to year, in the city's budgets and appropriation ordinances. 
(Code 1970, § 23-20)  
ARTICLE III. - EXCISE TAX 
 
Sec. 22.08. - Property insurance premiums—Assessment and imposition; appropriation. 
(a)  There is hereby assessed and imposed on every insurance company, corporation, or other insurer now engaged in or carrying on, or who shall hereafter engage in or carry on, the business of property insurance, as shown by the records of the state department of insurance, an excise or license tax amounting to one and eighty-five one-hundredths (1.85) percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policyholders on all premiums collected on property insurance policies covering property within the corporate limits of the city. In the case of multiple peril policies with a single premium for both the property and casualty coverages in such policies, seventy (70) percent of such premium shall be used as the basis for the one and eighty-five one-hundredths (1.85) percent tax above. 
(b)  All money from taxes imposed by this section is hereby appropriated to the firefighters retirement and trust of the city, which shall be administered in accordance with the applicable provisions of Chapter 175, Florida Statutes. 
(c)  The tax herein assessed and imposed shall be in addition to all other license taxes now levied or hereafter levied by the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-13, § 2, 4-1-96)  
Sec. 22.09. - Same—Collection. 
The excise or license tax herein provided for shall be payable and collected in the manner provided for by Chapter 175, Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 96-13, § 3, 4-1-96)  
Secs. 22.10—22.30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - COMMUNICATIONS SERVICES TAX CONVERSION RATES 
 
Sec. 22.31. - Intent. 
It is the intent of the city to adopt the communications services tax conversion rate as stated in sections 202.20(1)(a) and (b), as amended, and additionally to make an election under section 337.401(3)(c)(1), Florida Statutes (2000), as amended by section 34, enrolled CS/CS/SB 1878 by the 2001 Florida Legislature, regarding whether or not to require and collect permit fees from any providers of communications services that use or occupy the city's roads or rights-of-way for the provision of communications services. 
(Ord. No. 2001-17, § 1, 7-2-2001)  
Sec. 22.32. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this article, the term "communications services" shall have the meaning set forth in section 202.11(3), Florida Statutes, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2001-17, § 2, 7-2-2001)  
Sec. 22.33. - Adoption of communications services tax conversion rates. 
The city adopts the communications services tax conversion rate of 6.9 percent effective for the period October 1, 2001 through September 30, 2002 as stated in section 202.20(1)(a) Florida Statutes (2000), as amended, and the communications services tax conversion rate of 6.4 percent to take effect October 1, 2002 as stated in section 202.20(1)(b) Florida Statutes (2000), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2001-17, § 3, 7-2-2001)  
Sec. 22.34. - Election not to require and collect permit fees. 
The city elects not to require and collect rights-of-way use permit fees from any provider of communications services that uses or occupies the city's roads or rights-of-way for the provision of communications services as provided in section 337.401(3)(c)(1), Florida Statutes (2000), as amended by section 34, enrolled CS/CS/SB 1878 by the 2001 Florida Legislature, and this election shall take effect October 1, 2001. 
(Ord. No. 2001-17, § 4, 7-2-2001)  
Sec. 22.35. - Election to increase local communications services tax conversion rates. 
Pursuant to section 337.401(3)(c)(1), Florida Statutes (2000), as amended by section 34, enrolled CS/CS/SB 1878 by the 2001 Florida Legislature, the city elects to increase its total rates for the local communications services tax conversion rates of 6.9 percent and 6.4 percent as computed under section 202.20, Florida Statutes (2000), as amended, by an amount of 0.12 percent, and this election shall take effect October 1, 2001. 
(Ord. No. 2001-17, § 5, 7-2-2001)  
Sec. 22.36. - Notice to the department of revenue. 
The city clerk is hereby directed to provide a certified copy of this article to the department of revenue by certified mail by July 16, 2001. 
(Ord. No. 2001-17, § 6, 7-2-2001)  
Sec. 22.37. - Exemption. 
Providers of communications services are hereby exempted from the payment of any right-of-way use permit fees imposed by Article III, Chapter 20 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2001-17, § 7, 7-2-2001)  
Sec. 22.38. - Severability of parts of Code. 
All ordinances, or parts thereof, in conflict or inconsistent herewith are hereby repealed and superseded. However, all ordinances granting franchises and franchise agreements that are in conflict or inconsistent herewith, are hereby repealed and suspended only as to the part inconsistent with this article, and the remainder of any such ordinances or franchise agreements shall remain in full force and effect. If any section, sentence, clause, or provision of this article is held invalid, the remainder of this article shall not be affected by such invalidity. 
(Ord. No. 2001-17, § 8, 7-2-2001)  
Secs. 22.39—22.50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ADDITIONAL HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION 
 
Sec. 22.51. - Additional homestead exemption. 
(a)  The city, acting by and through its city commission, by the authority of the provisions of the Charter, and by the authority of F.S. § 196.075, hereby grants both of the following additional homestead exemptions on real property as may be applicable to residents sixty-five (65) and older: 
(b)  Up to fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for persons sixty-five (65) or older who have legal or equitable title to real estate within the city and maintain permanent residence thereon, and whose household income does not exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00); and/or 
(c)  The amount of the assessed value of the property for any person who has legal or equitable title to real estate with a just value less than two hundred and fifty thousand dollars ($250,000) and has maintained permanent residence thereon for at least twenty-five (25) years, who is sixty-five (65) or older, and whose household income does not exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000) as prescribed in subsection (b) above and as calculated in subsection (d), below. 
(d)  The income limitation shall be adjusted annually, on January 1, by the percentage change in the average cost of living index in the period January 1 st through December 31 st of the immediate prior year, compared with the same period for the year prior to that year, in accordance with F.S. § 196.075(3). The index is the average of the monthly consumer-price-index figures for the stated 12-month period, relative to the United States as a whole, issued by the United States Department of Labor. 
(e)  The statement of household income must be supported by copies of federal income tax returns for the prior year, wage and earning statements (W-2 forms), any request for an extension of time to file returns, and any other documents necessary for review by the department of revenue, for each member of the household, to be submitted for inspection by the Pinellas County Property Appraiser. 
(f)  The taxpayer's sworn statement shall attest to the accuracy of the documents and grant permission to allow a review of the documents if requested by the Pinellas County Property Appraiser. 
(g)  Submission of supporting documentation is not required for the renewal of an exemption under Section 196.075, Florida Statutes, unless such documentation is requested by the property appraiser. 
(Ord. No. 2004-16, § 1, 10-18-2004; Ord. No. 2006-17, § 1, 10-16-2006; Ord. No. 2007-09, § 1, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 2016-22, § 1, 11-7-2016)  
Chapter 23 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; building and property maintenance regulations, Ch. 5; fire protection and prevention, Ch. 8; flood prevention and control, Ch. 9; junked, abandoned or wrecked property, Ch. 12; parks and recreation, Ch. 16; subdivisions, Ch. 21. 
State Law reference— Motor vehicles, F.S. § 316.001 et seq.; powers of local authorities, F.S. § 316.008; Uniform Disposition of Traffic Infractions Act, F.S. chapter 318. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 23.01. - Adoption of Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law. 
There is hereby adopted by reference the Florida Uniform Traffic Control Law, Chapter 316, Florida Statutes, as amended, which law shall be in full force and effect in the city as if fully set forth herein, and shall be considered as part of this Code. 
(Code 1970, § 25-1)  
Sec. 23.02. - Adoption of Florida Uniform Disposition of Traffic Infractions Act. 
There is hereby adopted by reference the Florida Uniform Disposition of Traffic Infractions Act, Chapter 318, Florida Statutes, as amended, which act shall be in full force and effect in the city as if fully set forth herein, and shall be considered as part of this Code.  
Sec. 23.03. - Speed limits. 
The speed limit of all city roads at all times shall be twenty-five (25) miles per hour or as may be designated by the city commission. The speed limit for all state roads located within the corporate limits shall be established by the state department of transportation, and for all county roads in coordination with the County. 
(Code 1970, § 25-2; Ord. No. 91-28, § 1, 11-18-91; Ord. No. 94-16, § 1, 6-20-94; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 2-20-95)  
Sec. 23.04. - Railroad trains. 
No railroad train or locomotive shall be operated within the corporate limits of the city, at a rate of speed greater than twenty-five (25) miles per hour. 
(Code 1970, § 25-3)  
Sec. 23.05. - Pedestrian crossings. 
(a)  The city manager is authorized to designate certain intersections within the corporate limits of the city as requiring regulation of pedestrian traffic. 
(b)  At such intersections so designated, pedestrian crosswalks shall be clearly marked, and signs shall be erected notifying pedestrian traffic that jaywalking is prohibited at such intersections. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to cross any street or avenue at such intersection or within fifty (50) feet thereof, other than within the crosswalk so marked. 
(Code 1970, § 25-5)  
Sec. 23.06. - Trees, shrubs or other objects obstructing view at intersections—Declared nuisance. 
Any person who plants, fixes or maintains any tree, shrubbery, or any other object upon any parkway or private property within the city adjacent to the intersection of any streets in the city, which obstructs the driving vision of the operator of any vehicle properly upon a street approaching such intersection is hereby declared to be guilty of committing a nuisance. 
(Code 1970, § 25-8)  
Sec. 23.07. - Same—Notice. 
(a)  Whenever the code enforcement officer for the city, after investigation, shall determine that any tree, shrubbery or other object planted or fixed upon any parkway or private property in the city adjacent to a street intersection, obstructs the driving vision of the vehicles passing over or through such street intersection, he shall cause to be served upon the owner or occupant of the property abutting such parkway, or the owner of the property upon which such trees, shrubbery or other objects are planted or fixed in violation of section 23.06, a written notice requiring such owner or occupant to remove such tree, shrubbery or other object, or to trim such tree or shrubbery or reduce the height and width of other objects so as not to violate the provisions of section 23.06. 
(b)  The notice herein provided for shall be served upon the owner or occupant of the property herein described and shall require the owner to comply with the directions contained in such written notice, within ten (10) days. Such notice shall be served in accordance with sections 13.03 and 13.04 of the City Code. 
(Code 1970, § 25-9; Ord. No. 95-11, § 2, 2-20-95)  
Sec. 23.08. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Section 3 of Ordinance No. 95-11, adopted February 20, 1995, repealed § 23.08 in its entirety. Formerly, § 23.08 pertained to appeal to city commission for trees, shrubs or other objects obstructing view at intersections and derived from § 25-10 of the 1970 Code.  
Sec. 23.09. - Failure to correct notice requiring removal of trees, shrubs or other objects obstructing view at intersects; action by city. 
(a)  If, after the service of the notice herein provided, the owner or occupant does not comply with the directions contained in such notice within the time specified, the city may choose to abate the nuisance in accordance with the procedure set forth in sections 13.05 and 13.06 of the City Code. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the city from utilizing the enforcement procedure contained in section 2.10.06 of the City Code. 
(b)  Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the owner of any property from erecting or maintaining buildings or structures as permitted by ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1970, § 25-11; Ord. No. 95-11, § 4, 2-20-95)  
ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Powers of local authorities, F.S. § 316.008; parking regulations, F.S. §§ 316.1945 and 316.195; handicapped parking, F.S. § 316.1964. 
 
Sec. 23.10. - Parking restrictions. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle for a period of time longer than two (2) hours on Main Street between Tenth Avenue and First Avenue when signs are erected giving notice thereof. 
(b)  No person shall park a vehicle for a period of time longer than forty-eight (48) hours on all other streets or avenues within the corporate limits of the city. The forty-eight-hour restriction is on a continuous basis and the changing of the position of a vehicle from one point directly to another point within the same block shall be deemed one (1) continuous parking period. 
(c)  Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a law enforcement officer or official traffic control device, it shall be unlawful to stop, stand or park a vehicle: 
(1)  Upon a sidewalk in such a manner as to block or impair the passage of pedestrian traffic on such sidewalk, either completely or partially. This shall not be construed to prohibit temporary parking of delivery vehicles either in commercial zones or residential neighborhoods. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway; 
(3)  Within an intersection; 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant; 
(5)  On a crosswalk; 
(6)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; except where approved designated parking spaces are located at a lesser distance from the intersection. 
(7)  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a street; 
(8)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station within seventy-five (75) feet of such entrance; 
(9)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic; 
(10)  On the side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge of curb or street, or what is commonly known as double parking; 
(11)  Upon any bridge; 
(12)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping, standing or parking; 
(13)  Within any specifically designated and marked space reserved for parking by a disabled permit only as provided in Sections 316.1955 and 316.1956, Florida Statutes, unless such vehicle is chauffeuring a disabled person and is making a momentary stop to load or unload such disabled person; 
(14)  Upon or within a designated bicycle path or bicycle lane; 
(15)  When signs are erected giving notice thereof, to park a vehicle for longer than such time as is prescribed by such signs in such areas designated in such signs. For purposes of this regulation, the changing of the position of a vehicle from one point directly to another point within the same block shall be deemed one (1) continuous parking period; 
(16)  Within a bus stop when such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately marked; 
(17)  To park, stand or stop a vehicle in such a manner as to impede, hinder or restrain the normal flow of traffic on a street. This provision shall not apply to emergency vehicles and city or commercially owned vehicles engaged in the collection of solid waste or recyclable materials; 
(18)  To park or stand a vehicle in a street other than parallel with the edge of the street headed in the direction of traffic, and with the curbside wheels of the vehicle within twelve (12) inches of the edge of the street or curb, except upon those streets which have been marked or signed for angle parking where such vehicles shall be parked at the angle to the curb indicated by such mark or signs; or 
(19)  To park or stand a vehicle upon any street or right-of-way for the primary purpose of displaying it for sale and/or washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency. An exception may be permitted, subject to compliance with any other applicable requirements of the City Code, in those cases where a vehicle is parked on a street immediately adjacent to the vehicle owner's principal place of residence and access to any form of off-street parking is not available. 
(20)  To park, stand or stop a vehicle in such a manner as to impede the curbside delivery of mail when notice has been given by a postal carrier to discontinue the blocking of access to a mailbox in order to allow the delivery of mail. 
(21)  To stop, stand or park a vehicle, for purposes of loading or unloading passengers, in an area where signs are erected giving notice thereof, between the hours as designated by the city manager and on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1970, § 25-4; Ord. No. 83-28, § 1, 7-5-83; Ord. No. 85-22, § 1, 6-3-85; Ord. No. 98-05, § 1, 4-20-98; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 1, 4-2-2006)  
Sec. 23.11. - Parking in residential districts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in any residential district as defined in the zoning code exceeding ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross vehicle weight, and/or exceeding twenty-one (21) feet in length, and/or exceeding eight (8) feet in height, and/or eight (8) feet in width. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to recreational vehicles, or similar types of vehicles, provided that such vehicles are not parked on vacant, undeveloped property. For purposes of this section, the term "recreational vehicle" shall be defined in the same manner as the term "recreational vehicle" is defined in the City's Comprehensive Zoning and Land Development Code. 
(Ord. No. 82-02, § 1(§ 25.4.1), 3-15-82; Ord. No. 98-11, § 1, 6-1-98)  
Sec. 23.12. - Recreational vehicles. 
(a)  No recreational vehicles or similar types of vehicles may be used as living quarters or storage on any property except property in areas zoned R-6, Mobile Home District, subject to conditional use approval. 
(b)  Recreational vehicles parked on property in any zoning district other than the R-6, Mobile Home District, shall comply with the size restrictions and locational standards specified in the following table: 
Recreational Vehicle 	Lot Placement 	Minimum Lot Size 
35 feet or less in length 	Any yard with front yard, side yard, or rear yard placement within 10 feet of a side lot line or parked in a paved driveway with the recreational vehicle oriented perpendicular to the main building, except that where there is a paved semicircular driveway with two means of ingress/egress there shall be no requirement that the recreational vehicle be oriented perpendicular to the main building. 	Minimum lot area of 6,000 square feet and minimum lot width of 50 feet. 
Greater than 35 feet in length 	Must be located in a side or rear yard no closer than 5 feet to a lot line with a 6-foot high opaque fence or hedge required to screen the recreational vehicle from adjoining properties. 	Minimum lot area of 10,000 square feet and minimum lot width of 75 feet 
 
(c)  One (1) recreational vehicle or one (1) recreational vehicle on a trailer that is designed to transport said recreational vehicle is permitted per address. All recreational vehicles shall be registered and operable. 
(d)  On corner lots with two (2) front yards (as defined in section 23.05 of the Land Development Code), a recreational vehicle may be parked in a front yard with adjoins a side street not forward of the primary facade of the main building or in the rear yard of a through lot provided the recreational vehicle is concealed from public view by a six-foot opaque fence or hedge. 
(e)  All recreational vehicles shall be stored in safe condition. Under no circumstances shall drums, barrels, concrete blocks, lumber, or similar devices be utilized for storage or recreational vehicles. 
(f)  In all cases where a recreational vehicle is parked, the grass located under such vehicle shall be trimmed to the same height as the rest of the yard. 
(g)  Recreational vehicle repair shall be limited to minor maintenance and in no case shall repair be conducted as a business, for profit, or in a manner which renders a vehicle inoperative, except where vehicle maintenance is permitted in the C-1A, Restricted Commercial District, M-1, Light Industrial District, or M-3, General Industrial District. 
(h)  Recreational vehicles or similar types of vehicles shall not be parked upon any public street for a period longer than six (6) hours, unless signs are posted prohibiting on-street parking or identifying a different period of time. For purposes of this provision, the changing of the position of a vehicle from one (1) point directly to another point within the same block shall be deemed one (1) continuous parking period. 
(i)  For purposes of this section, the term "recreational vehicle" shall be defined in the same manner as that term is defined in the City's Comprehensive Zoning and Land Development Code. 
(j)  Nothing contained herein shall prohibit any governmental agency from utilizing a temporary structure on any property in the city controlled by such governmental agency; providing that permission for such utilization of the property has been approved by the city manager. 
(k)  This section shall not apply where temporary housing is required due to a natural disaster and the city or county has instituted emergency actions to allow same. 
(Ord. No. 98-11, § 2, 6-1-98; Ord. No. 2008-25, § 1, 12-15-2008; Ord. No. 2019-08, § 8, 8-5-2019) 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 98-11, adopted June 1, 1998, amended § 23.12 to read as herein set out. Prior to such amendment, § 23.12 pertained to trailers and house cars and derived from § 25-7 of the 1970 Code; and Ord. No. 95-11, §§ 5—7, adopted Feb. 20, 1995.  
Sec. 23.13. - Parking or moving vehicles in violation; removal and impoundment by law enforcement agency. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his/her name to stand or park in any street in this city in violation of this article or of any of the ordinances of the city regulating the standing or parking of vehicles. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move a vehicle not owned by such person in such a manner as to be in violation of the regulations of this chapter. 
(c)  The designated law enforcement agency of the city is authorized to take up or cause to be taken up or removed to a place designated by such law enforcement agency any vehicle parked in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter and is authorized and empowered to keep same in such place until all fines and charges assessed for moving and storage against the owner and the vehicle have been paid or satisfactory bond arranged. 
(Ord. No. 98-05, § 2, 4-20-98) 
Editor's note— Section 2 of Ord. No. 98-05, adopted Apr. 20, 1998, amended § 23.13 to read as herein set out. Prior to such amendment, § 23.13 pertained to prohibited parking near fire stations or hydrants and derived from § 25-6 of the 1970 Code.  
Sec. 23.14. - Parking fines. 
(a)  The fine for each violation of the parking restrictions set forth in section 23.10 shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00), except for violation of designated parking for disabled persons, which shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any fines not paid within fifteen (15) days of the day of the violation shall be doubled. 
(b)  The procedural guidelines for the disposition of parking tickets for the city shall be as set forth in County Court Administrative Order 90-19 and any future amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 98-05, § 3, 4-20-98; Ord. No. 2006-07, § 2, 4-2-2006)  
Chapter 24 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; building and property maintenance regulations, Ch. 5; finance, Ch. 7; flood prevention and control, Ch. 9; garbage and refuse, Ch. 10; health and sanitation, Ch. 11; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 20; subdivisions, Ch. 21; zoning, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Water and sewer systems, F.S. Chapter 367; Florida Safe Drinking Water Act, F.S. § 403.850 et seq.; water supply assistance, F.S. § 373.1961; environmental control, D.S. Chapter 403. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 24.01. - Water and sewer systems combined. 
The existing water system and the existing sewer system of the city consisting of sanitary and stormwater sewer facilities, and including additions, extensions and improvements to be made to the water system and the sewer system, be and the same are hereby combined into a single utility system to be known as Water and Sewer System of the City of Safety Harbor. 
(Code 1970, § 26-1)  
Sec. 24.02. - Specified facilities combined. 
The water and sewer system shall include, but without being limited to, all wells, tanks, standpipes, pumps, pipes, mains, treatment plants, pumping stations, disposal plants, meters, stormwater sewers and drainage facilities and all other property, both real and personal, and equipment used in or connected with the operation or maintenance of such system or the furnishing of water for individual, commercial, industrial, municipal or other use to the residents and inhabitants of the city and the territory adjacent thereto, or used and connected with the removal of sewage and liquid waste and stormwater from the buildings, streets and other sewage and stormwater outlets in the city and the area adjacent thereto by the city. 
(Code 1970, § 26-2)  
Sec. 24.03. - Supervision and direction of combined system. 
The water and sewer system shall be under the supervision and direction of the city manager, but the city manager may appoint with the approval of the commissioners a superintendent of the water and sewer system who shall have general supervision of the water and sewer system under the direction of and who shall report to the city manager. Any such superintendent so appointed shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager and may be removed by him with the consent of the commissioners. 
(Code 1970, § 26-3)  
ARTICLE II. - SEWERS 
 
Sec. 24.04. - Sanitary sewer system declared a public utility. 
The present sanitary sewage system now in existence in the city, together with any and all extensions thereof and replacements thereto, and the sanitary sewerage disposal systems are hereby established and declared to be a public utility, for the use and benefit of the city in the maintenance of public health and general conditions throughout the city. 
(Code 1970, § 26-4)  
Sec. 24.05. - Authorized personnel only to enter public sewer or make connections thereto; fee. 
(a)  No person, other than an authorized city employee, shall enter any public sewer or appurtenance thereof or make any connections thereto without a written permit from the proper municipal authority. 
(b)  All such connections shall be in accordance with rules and regulations which shall be adopted from time to time by the commission, which rules and regulations shall provide for a charge for making any connection, in such amount as the commission may fix and establish, and shall be made only with the permission of the commission or their duly authorized representative and shall be made only by a licensed plumber. 
(Code 1970, § 26-5)  
Sec. 24.06. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  No person shall make or maintain any connection with any public or private sewer or appurtenance thereof whereby they may be conveyed into the same suffocating, corrosive, inflammable or explosive liquid, gas, vapor, substance or material, or car-washing wastes. 
(b)  No person shall do any act or thing which may impair or obstruct the flow of any public sewer or clog up any appurtenance thereof, or place therein any substance, solid or liquid, other than the waste products for which sewers are provided. 
(c)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1970, § 26-6)  
Sec. 24.07. - Interceptors; when required; expense of maintaining. 
Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the city, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand and other harmful ingredients. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the city sewer inspector and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection; and all costs with regard to the interceptor, including but not limited to purchase and installation, shall be borne by the user. 
(Code 1970, § 26-6.1)  
Sec. 24.08. - Written permit required to tap, cut or use sanitary system. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to tap, cut or in anywise use any line, branch or part of the sanitary sewage system or utility without a written permit issued by the building official of the city and without the payment of all rates and charges required by the city for the use of such utility. 
(Code 1970, § 26-7)  
Sec. 24.09. - Sewer development fees. 
(a)  Sewer development fees for all sewer service connections to the municipal sewer system (except as herein noted) installed pursuant to building permits for units issued after December 20, 1976, shall be four hundred dollars ($400.00) for the first water closet plus one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each additional water closet in each unit. 
(b)  There shall be no distinction made as to single-family living units or multifamily living units. 
(c)  All structures erected pursuant to building permits issued prior to December 20, 1976, but subsequent to June 3, 1974, and which were unable to connect to the municipal sewer system due to the unavailability of such service by the city shall pay the following sewer development fee: 
(1)  For the residential units, the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the first water closet plus one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each additional water closet. 
(2)  For commercial units, the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each water closet or urinal. 
(d)  All structures erected pursuant to a building permit issued prior to June 3, 1974, and which were unable to connect to the municipal sewer system due to the unavailability of such service by the city shall pay the following sewer development fee: 
(1)  Single-family units and multiple units, up to three (3) units, shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(2)  For all multiple units in excess of three (3) units, there shall be an additional charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) per unit. 
(Code 1970, § 26-8)  
Sec. 24.10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 92-34, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 1992, adopted the Safety Harbor Land Development Code. Section 8.00 of such LDC repealed § 24.10 of the City Code. Formerly, such section pertained to sewage connection and notice requirements and derived from § 26-9 of the 1970 Code.  
Sec. 24.11. - Private sewerage systems. 
No repairs may be made to any existing septic tank or similar private sewerage disposal unit after sewerage service shall be made available to the owner of the property on which such private disposal system is located, and the making of any repairs shall be deemed a violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1970, § 26-10)

(b)  For purposes of definition, each physical connection to the public sewage system shall constitute a separate account. 
(c)  For purposes of definition, each single-family residence, trailer or mobile home, apartment (whether owned or rented), and each hotel or motel room shall be considered a single dwelling or living unit. Commercial shall include all businesses or operations not included under the residential category. 
(d)  In cases where a business combines living accommodations with business or commercial occupations and the business occupations are not served by a separate connection to the sewerage system, the monthly service charge shall be the base unit fee (determined by multiplying the total number of living units times the base monthly living unit charge) or eighty (80) percent of the water bill, whichever is greater. 
(e)  Cases in which the above are not applicable shall be treated as special situations and the monthly charges therefor shall be established by the city manager on an equitable basis. 
(f)  The rates for all accounts outside the city limits shall be the same as set forth above plus twenty-five (25) percent. Charges for service outside the city limits, in proper instances, may be established by ordinance under the provisions of Chapter 180.191(b), Florida Statutes. 
(Code 1970, § 26-11; Ord. No. 82-24, § 1, 9-7-82; Ord. No. 88-27, § 1, 9-6-88; Ord. No. 90-22, § 1, 10-1-90; Ord. No. 91-18, § 1, 6-17-91; Ord. No. 94-26, § 1, 9-19-94; Ord. No. 95-41, § 1, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 2006-03, § 1, 2-6-2006; Ord. No. 2008-11, § 1, 5-19-2008; Ord. No. 2016-29, § 1, 12-19-2016)  
Sec. 24.13. - Charges effective date. 
The sewer service charge as set forth in section 24.12 shall be effective to all properties which are presently connected or hereafter connected to the public sewage collection system and shall be terminated only upon physical disconnection of units from the collection system. Whenever sewer service is made available to previously unsewered areas, the same service charges set forth in section 24.12 shall become effective ninety (90) days after notification of the availability of the service or upon connection to the system, whichever occurs first. 
(Code 1970, § 26-12)  
Sec. 24.14. - When bills due and payable; discontinuance of service for nonpayment. 
(a)  All bills for sewer charges shall be payable within twenty (20) days after the original date of billing, and if the amount of such sewer service charge shall not be paid within twenty (20) days from the rendition of such bill, the city shall discontinue furnishing water to such premises, and shall disconnect the same from the waterworks system, and shall proceed forthwith to recover the amount of such sewer service charge in such lawful manner as it may deem advisable. 
(b)  If any bill for sewer service charges rendered in connection with any premises not connected with the waterworks system of the city shall not be paid within twenty (20) days from the rendition of the original bill, the owner, tenant, or occupant of such premises shall cease, if ordered to do so by the city, from disposing of sewage or industrial wastes originating from or on such premises by discharge thereof directly or indirectly into the sewer system of the city until such sewer service charge shall be paid. If such owner, tenant or occupant shall not cease such disposal, then the city manager may disconnect such premises from the sewer system. Additionally the commission shall proceed forthwith to recover the amount of such sewer service charge in such lawful manner as it may deem advisable. 
(c)  In addition, should such owner, tenant, or occupant not cease such disposal or not pay the sewer service charge at the expiration of such twenty-day period, it shall be the duty of any public or private corporation, board, body or person supplying water to, or selling water for the use of, such premises, to shut off the supply of water to such premises within five (5) days after the receipt of notice of the sewer service charge delinquency from the municipality. 
(d)  If the public or private corporation, board, body or person shall not, at the expiration of such five-day period, cease to supply water to, or sell water for the use of, such premises, then the municipality may shut off the supply of water to those premises. 
(Code 1970, § 26-13)  
ARTICLE III. - WATER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Florida Safe Drinking Water Act, F.S. § 403.850 et seq. 
 
Sec. 24.15. - Due date for payment. 
All water billings are due when rendered and are payable monthly. The bill for water usage will be mailed to consumers monthly, either as a separate bill or in conjunction with other city utility billings. The failure to receive a bill will not constitute a claim for nonpayment of same nor release the customer from any penalties charged for such nonpayment. 
(Code 1970, § 26-14; Ord. No. 81-35, § 2(§ 26-14), 9-21-81)  
Sec. 24.16. - Delinquent accounts; cut-off; service charge. 
(a)  All water accounts will become delinquent twenty (20) days after the due date as shown on the billing. Water service will be disconnected after five (5) days' notice to the customer. Such notice will also be provided to the tenant, if the tenant is not the customer and if the city knows the customer is not the occupant of the premises. After an account has become delinquent, it will not be reconnected until the delinquent account has been paid in full and the following service charge has been collected: 
Service charge ..... $15.00 
(b)  The service charge will be imposed on all delinquent accounts not paid one (1) day prior to disconnection. 
(c)  Water will be turned on as soon as practicable within reasonable hours as established by the city manager, after the delinquent bill and service fee has been paid. 
(d)  In order to discourage delinquent payment and encourage prompt payment of water bills, the service charge for a second delinquency within ninety (90) days shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for subsequent delinquencies within one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(Code 1970, § 26-15; Ord. No. 81-35, § 3, 9-21-81; Ord. No. 85-03, § 1, 4-1-85; Ord. No. 87-18, § 1, 6-15-87; Ord. No. 93-10, § 1, 5-3-93; Ord. No. 98-12, § 1, 5-4-98)  
Sec. 24.17. - Water meters, installation. 
(a)  All meters shall be installed and all connections made only by the duly authorized agents and employees of the city water department. 
(b)  All damages to meters or meter boxes caused by the negligence of the consumer shall be charged to the owner of the property upon which such damage occurs. 
(Code 1970, § 26-16)

(e)  Water leaks. Where a customer can establish that more water was consumed during any month than the customer's average water consumption because of a water leak, water consumed above the average for that account will be billed at the current base or minimum rate. Any account can elect this option only once every twelve (12) months. The customer has the burden to establish that extra water consumption was a result of a water leak by producing a repair bill from a plumber or by other means satisfactory to the city manager or his designee. The average water consumption for an account will be calculated by using the water consumption for the account for the immediate past twelve (12) months. 
(f)  Revenues. Five (5) percent of the net revenues generated by the combined water and sewer funds annually shall be used to develop and implement an effluent system.

Customers shall be eligible for the water intensive rate upon meeting the following criteria: 
(1)  Industries defined by SWFWMD as water intensive. 
(2)  Threshold consumptions will be defined by SWFWMD or a survey of other local water utilities. 
(3)  A water audit by a recognized firm must be done by the water customer at their expense. 
(4)  The recommendations of the water audit must be implemented within nine months by the water customer. 
(Code 1970, § 26-17; Ord. No. 81-35, § 4(26-17), 9-21-81; Ord. No. 85-40, § 2, 8-5-85; Ord. No. 87-21, § 2, 7-20-87; Ord. No. 89-35, § 2, 10-16-89; Ord. No. 91-02, § 1, 1-21-91; Ord. No. 91-18, § 2, 6-17-91; Ord. No. 93-10, §§ 2—4, 5-3-93; Ord. No. 94-24, §§ 1—3, 9-19-94; Ord. No. 95-40, §§ 1—3, 9-18-95; Ord. No. 98-12, § 2, 5-4-98; Ord. No. 2006-02, §§ 1—3, 2-6-2006; Ord. No. 2008-10, §§ 1—4, 5-19-2008; Ord. No. 2016-28, §§ 1—3, 12-19-2016)  
Sec. 24.19. - Water rates outside city limits. 
(a)  The city expressly reserves the right to refuse to supply city water outside the corporate limits. 
(b)  The rates for all accounts outside the city limits shall be the same as set forth above plus twenty-five (25) percent. Charges for service outside the city limits, in proper instances, may be established by ordinance under the provisions of Chapter 180.191(b), Florida Statutes. 
(Code 1970, § 26-18)  
Sec. 24.20. - Water meters installed in all human habitations; exceptions. 
(a)  A separate water meter shall be installed for the purpose of measuring the water supplied by the water and sewer department of the city to each and every residence, dwelling or other human habitation, regardless of ownership, except as herein provided. Stores and offices shall also be bound by this provision. Out-buildings, sheds, and garages, and similar auxiliary buildings not used as habitations, and servants' quarters, may be attached to the same meter as the main dwelling. 
(b)  This rule shall not apply to hotels, apartments, multiple individual dwelling units or groups of commercial or industrial buildings under the ownership or management of one individual, firm or corporation. The water supplied to such groups of buildings may be measured through a single meter, but the city expressly reserves the right to specify a meter of appropriate size to properly handle the volume to be measured; and to charge for such meter and its installation under the terms and conditions set forth in section 24.22. 
(Code 1970, § 26-19)  
Sec. 24.21. - Meters property of city. 
Meters shall remain forever the property of the city. They shall not be moved, turned off or on, or in any way tampered with or molested, or their operation adjusted or interfered with except by an authorized agent of the city water department, except that in case of an accident or serious emergency from which damage to property or persons might result, the service valve may be operated if a city employee is not available in a reasonable time, provided further that such operation is reported at the earliest practicable time to the office of the city manager at city hall. 
(Code 1970, § 26-20)  
Sec. 24.22. - Water service, administrative and tap-in charges. 
(a)  When it is necessary to tap the city water mains to make a connection to a meter, the person, firm or corporation for whom the installation is made shall pay a fee to be known as a water connection charge. This charge shall not be refundable. 
(b)  Charges shall be as follows: 
Meter 
Size 	Inside 
City Limits 	Outside

(c)  Four (4) inch meters shall be installed by the developer under the supervision and inspection of the city. 
(d)  A service charge of seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) shall be made for turning on water service; there shall be no charge for disconnecting water service. A request to read and leave on the water service in connection with a transfer of occupancy or ownership shall be construed as a turn-on charge. 
(e)  No water service shall be turned on until provision is made to pay all charges for all city utility services provided prior to the turn-on date. 
(Code 1970, § 26-21; Ord. No. 85-03, § 2, 4-1-85)  
Sec. 24.23. - Service deposits. 
(a)  All customers shall be charged service deposits according to the schedule of charges in the following chart in accordance with this section of Code. 
	Customer (Property Owner) Deposit

All accounts in the name of a person or entity other than the owner of the property being served shall be charged a water service deposit double the amount shown in the above chart except that the deposit for a five-eighth ( 5/8 ) inch meter shall be one hundred sixty dollars ($160.00) inside city limits and two hundred dollars ($200.00) outside city limits. 
(b)  This deposit is in addition to the seven dollar and fifty cents ($7.50) "turn-on" charge provided for herein. This deposit shall be refunded when the service is discontinued, provided that all charges for water due to date shall have been paid. This provision shall not be retroactive, but if service is discontinued to any present user because of nonpayment, service shall not be resumed until such a deposit has been made and all debts due the water department from the party have been liquidated in full. 
(c)  On new construction accounts, water may be provided to the contractor subject to a deposit as specified in subsection (a) above, refundable on cancellation and upon payment of the construction account for water used, and provided further that this deposit shall be forfeited if the building is occupied prior to the cancellation and payment of the construction account for water used. 
(d)  (1)  The deposit for an owner occupied residential or commercial establishment, a nonprofit community service organization, or a registered condominium association account may be returned upon request after twenty-four (24) months of good account experience. For the purpose of this section "good account experience" means not more than two (2) past-due reminders in any twenty-four-month period, no disconnection of service for nonpayment, no dishonored checks, no evidence of meter tampering and no evidence of fraudulent use of the utilities system. 
(2)  Customers with a record of timely payments may have existing deposits transferred to a new premises or establishment without an increase in existing deposit amounts. This deposit shall be refunded after the service is permanently discontinued to a particular user provided that all charges or service due, up to and including date of discontinuance, shall have been paid. All deposits shall be applied to charges for services. 
(3)  Whenever any deposit shall have been made with the city, as required by this chapter, and service shall have been discontinued, and such deposit, or a balance thereof, shall be unclaimed by the person entitled to receive such deposit or balance thereof for a period of one (1) year, then any such deposit or balance thereof shall be deemed to be unclaimed and abandoned and shall become the property of the city. 
(e)  The city may increase the deposit requirement for an account previously cut off for non-timely payment, for an account that has presented a subsequently dishonored check, or for an account having a record of unpaid utility charges at a previous service location in the city. These accounts may be required to post a deposit of twice the stated deposit value or a deposit equal to four (4) months of average charges, whichever is greater. This recalculation will apply to all accounts regardless of whether the deposit has previously been refunded for "good account experience." 
(f)  Deposits pursuant to this section held by the city shall accrue interest, which shall be an index rate established as of October 1 each year and the index rate shall remain in effect to the next September 30. The interest rate shall be the average of the yearly rate on the interest earned on state board of administration local government system funds trust investment pool for the period October through September immediately preceding the October 1 adjustment date. The interest rate shall be adjusted annually on October 1. Annual payment will occur as a credit posted to the customer's account commencing with the first bill rendered on or after November 1. A customer who terminates service, whose service is terminated or whose deposit is returned will receive a prorated interest credit to the termination date on the final bill or the refund date. 
(Code 1970, § 26-22; Ord. No. 84-23, § 2, 5-21-84; Ord. No. 88-33, § 1, 11-7-88; Ord. No. 2003-16, §§ 1—4, 1-5-2004)  
Sec. 24.24. - Shutoff valve; specifications. 
(a)  Between the meter and the buildings to be supplied with water, a suitable shutoff valve shall be installed by the owner or user of the property with which the meter is connected in a location at all times easily visible and accessible to employees of the city water and sewer department. 
(b)  Such valve shall not be covered by shrubbery, lattices, boxes or other covering, nor shall it be beneath the house or in an outbuilding which at times may be locked. 
(c)  Failure to observe this provision shall justify the city in refusing water service until the rule is complied with. 
(Code 1970, § 26-23)  
Sec. 24.25. - Liability for repairs to service pipes. 
(a)  All repairs to water service pipes from the connections with the city water meter inward shall be at the expense of the property owner. 
(b)  All damages to meters and/or meter boxes caused by the negligence of the consumer shall be charged to the owner of the property upon which such damage occurs. 
(Code 1970, § 26-24)  
Sec. 24.26. - Steam boilers, etc., connected with water system. 
(a)  Wherever steam boilers, water heating plants of any and all kinds, or other similar apparatus or devices are connected to the waterworks system of the city by any user or owner whatsoever, damage caused by such connection to the property of the city water and sewer department shall be chargeable to such user or owner. 
(b)  Service pipes for such service must have a suitable check valve installed in the water line to prevent hot water from entering the city water mains or damaging the meter. Such check valves shall be installed with the approval of the city manager or his designee, but such approval shall not release the user from liability for damage due to the failure of such check valve to function. 
(c)  Five-eights-inch meters connected to residences, stores or offices need not have such check valves, but if a hot water heater in use in such edifices becomes overheated and back-pressures hot water into the meter, resulting damage shall be paid for by the user or owner of the property on which the meter is located. 
(Code 1970, § 26-25)  
Sec. 24.27. - Access to buildings by city employees. 
The city manager, or any employee designated by him, shall have access at all reasonable hours to the premises served by the city water and sewer department for the purpose of inspecting piping and equipment. 
(Code 1970, § 26-26)  
Sec. 24.28. - Waterworks apparatus, not to be molested. 
Fire hydrants, service control valves, check valves, tanks, pumps and/or any other equipment used in connection with the waterworks system of the city shall not be molested or interfered with by any person whomsoever. The operation of all apparatus and equipment connected with the city water plant and distribution system shall be solely and exclusively in the charge of its duly authorized caretakers and operators. The premises and buildings in which pumps, water tanks, etc., are located shall not be trespassed upon by any person other than those legally in charge of operation and maintenance of the same. 
(Code 1970, § 26-27)  
Sec. 24.29. - Permit required for use of fire hydrants. 
A permit shall be required from the city manager or his designee before water is drawn from any fire hydrant or other service outlet, except by the fire department in the regular discharge of its duties, and only after arrangements have been made for payment to the city for water so drawn, at a just and reasonable rate. 
(Code 1970, § 26-28)  
Sec. 24.30. - Quantity of water recorded conclusive; exception. 
The quantity recorded by a water meter shall be taken to be the amount of water passing through the meter, which amount shall be accepted as conclusive by both the customer and the city except when the meter is found to be registering inaccurately or has ceased to register in accordance with section 24.31.1. In such cases the quantity will be determined by and the customer shall pay for an amount based on the customer's average water consumption. The average water consumption for an account will be calculated by using the water consumption for the account for the immediate past twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 91-18, § 3, 6-17-91) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 91-18, § 3, adopted June 17, 1991, amended § 24.30 to read as herein set out and added a new § 24.31. Section 24.31 already existed in the Code, and consequently, was renumbered as 24.31.1. Prior to such amendment, § 24.30 pertained to testing water meters and derived from § 26-29 of the 1970 Code.  
Sec. 24.31. - Water meter testing. 
The city's water department reserves the right to remove or test any water meter at any time and to substitute another meter in its place. In case of a disputed account involving the question of accuracy of the meter, such meter will be tested by the city upon written request of the applicant; provided, however, that the meter in question has not been tested by the city within the past year. In the event the meter so tested is found to have an error in registration in excess of three (3) percent as based upon the arithmetical average of one-fourth load and full load of the meter, to the prejudice of the customer, there will be no charge for the testing, but should the test show error in registration of less than three (3) percent or should the test show error to the prejudice of the city, there will be a charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) for testing meters. If a test shows an error to the prejudice of the customer, then the quantity of water shall be determined by and the customer shall pay for an amount based on the customer's average water consumption as defined in Section 24.31.1. If a test shows no error, then the quantity recorded by the water meter shall be the amount of water passing through the meter and the customer shall pay for such amount. 
(Ord. No. 91-18, § 4, 6-17-91)  
Sec. 24.31.1. - Consumption of water charges upon failure of meter to register. 
If the water meter on any premises becomes defective so that the amount of water consumed for the current month cannot be ascertained, the owner of the premises shall pay for that month an amount equal to the average amount charged for the month preceding and the month following the failure of the water meter. 
(Code 1970, § 26-30) 
Note— See editor's note, § 24.30.
